# Understanding About Modern History

The modern history of India begins after 1857 and continues till 1947. This article explains the spectrum of India’s modern history until its independence in detail.

##### Table of Content

The modern history of the world is said to have begun after the Middle Ages. After the Age of Reason and the Age of Enlightenment, historical events are said to have entered the modern period. This holds true especially for events after the beginning of the Industrial Revolution. The modern history of India is said to begin after 1850. There are some seminal periods of the modern history of India that shaped the consequent events that occurred long after these periods.

## **The Beginning of the Modern History of India**

In 1857, there was a large scale rebellion of Indian soldiers against the British colonisers. There were several reasons behind this uprising. Some broad causes of the rebellion are as follows:

* The gunpowder cartridges of the Enfield rifles had material that was incompatible with the religious practices of both Hindus and Muslims.
* The long-standing dissatisfaction with the British taxation policies.
* The racist tendencies of the British officers against their Indian troops.
* The policy of land annexation practised by the Britishers.

The trigger point was the rebellion of the sepoy Mangal Pandey. After Mangal Pandey, soldiers all over the country started joining peasant armies forming in several districts in different parts of the country.

Consequences of the war of 1857:

* All administration and government of India were transferred to the British Crown from the East India Company.
* The British Crown controlled all the land of the East India Company.
* As a result of the government being transferred, the British Crown held sway over most of the country because they had considerable influence in the princely states.

### **The British Raj (1858-1947)**

After the 1857 rebellion, the British government started the colonisation of India in earnest. They built the railroads and irrigation system. The focus shifted to producing workers for the technologically advanced British empire, and some 60,000 Indians had enrolled by the end of 1890. 

Several political organisations were formed. The most prominent among these was the Indian National Congress, the All India Muslim League, and the Akhil Bhartiya Hindu Mahasabha. The latter two were openly influenced by a religious perspective in their politics. The Indian National Congress did not take part in socio-religious movements. 

Several periods of note occurred during the British Raj. Some of them are as follows:

* **The India Renaissance:** There was a period of social reforms, predominantly in the Bengali region, focused on the treatment of women in the society, religious orthodoxies, caste, marriage, the dowry system. It is said to have begun with Raja Ram Mohan Roy and ended with Rabindranath Tagore.
* **Famines:** India suffered through some of the worst famines of history under British rule. These were usually the result of a combination of natural factors and destructive and insensitive British policies.
* **World War I:** Nearly one million Indian troops served the British empire during the First World War. Out of these, almost 74,000 lost their lives.
* **World War II:** Almost two and a half million Indians were a part of the British war effort in World War II. It was during this time that the Quit India Movement was launched. The Indian National Congress had condemned Nazi Germany but did not support Indian troops being a part of the war till India got complete freedom from the Crown.

## **The Indian Independence Movement (1885-1947)**

The Indian independence movement was one of the most significant political movements in the modern history of India. The rise of Indian nationalism was due to several factors. Some historians say it was because the British rule was exploitative. Some say that it was because the British were unfair and racially discriminatory towards Indians. Still, others argue that it was a combination of these and more factors.

The Indian independence movement went through several stages. The first significant change brought about by the movement was the formation of an advisory council for the Viceroy of India. The other achievement was the appointment of Indians to this council in 1861. These were efforts in the direction of self-rule.

But later events brought about a demand for complete independence. The call for Swaraj was given by Bal Gangadhar Tilak. The Swadeshi movement also came up as a part of the umbrella movement of the Indian Independence movement. This was propagated by Bipin Chandra Pal, Lala Lajpat Rai, and Bal Gangadhar Tilak. The partition of Bengal was another impetus in the movement for complete independence. It was a major cause of a feeling of disenfranchisement among Indians.

* **After the First World War:** The British government adopted a “carrot and stick” approach after the First World War. This was done as a recourse against the rising nationalist movement and as compensation for the Indian troops in World War-I. After 1920, the non-violent movement led by Mahatma Gandhi used peaceful methods of protest that saw the participation of people from all over the country.
* **After the Second World War:** The year 1946 saw great upheaval in the country’s political milieu. Several mutinies happened in the different armed forces. Along with these mutinies, the Indian National Congress won 8 out of 11 provinces in elections. Late in 1946, the Labour government that was in power in Britain decided that it would end British rule in India. They stated that the transfer of power would be completed by June 1948.

### **Independence and Partition**

India was split into the Dominion of India and the Dominion of Pakistan. It is one of the most tragic events in recent history. Millions of people were displaced, and hundreds of thousands of people were killed in the riots that accompanied the partition. The trauma of the events has had long-lasting effects on the socio-political setup of both countries.

## **Conclusion**

The history of modern India is a testament to the making of a nation. It tells the story of how people came together and achieved a goal that was seemingly impossible. History is important because it is a record of human effort and progress.

The modern history of India is considered to have begun in 1850. The majority of this period is occupied with the colonial history of India under British rule. The modern period is said to end around 1945.

In terms of global history, modern history is said to begin after the Middle Ages. Technically speaking, the modern history of the world is said to have begun after the beginning of the Age of Reason and the Age of Enlightenment in the 17th and 18th centuries, especially the beginning of the Industrial Revolution.

The study of history is essential to developing a deeper, more productive understanding of the world. When we have knowledge of past events, we can gain knowledge of the patterns that tend to repeat. # Modern Indian History: From about the middle of the eighteenth century until the present – significant events, personalities, and issues

Last updated on by [Alex Andrews George](https://www.clearias.com/author/alex-andrews-george/)

**Learn about modern Indian history from about the middle of the eighteenth century until the present. Read to know more about the significant events, personalities and issues in modern India.**

Modern Indian history refers to the period of [Indian history](https://www.clearias.com/indian-history/) beginning in the middle of the 18th century, following the [collapse of the mighty Mughal Empire](https://www.clearias.com/india-in-1750/), and continuing through to the present day.

This period is characterized by the rise of nationalist movements, the struggle for independence from British colonial rule, and the formation of the modern nation-state of India.

Key figures in modern Indian history include Mahatma Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru, and Sardar Patel.

The period has also seen significant economic and social changes and the rise of India as a major player in the global economy.

## Modern Indian History: From the Mughal Empire to Independence and Beyond

Modern Indian history covers a wide range of events and developments, from the decline of the Mughal Empire and the rise of British colonial rule to the Indian independence movement and the challenges faced by the newly independent nation.

### The decline of the Mughal Empire

The middle of the 18th century marked the beginning of the decline of the Mughal Empire (Early Mughals) in India, which had been a dominant political and cultural force for centuries.

This period saw the rise of regional powers, such as the Marathas who began to challenge the Mughal rule. The British East India Company too tried to gain control of large parts of India through a series of military conquests and economic manipulation.

Wish to know more? Read: [India in 1750 – Decline of the Mughal Empire, Rule of Later Mughals, and Emergence of Successor States](https://www.clearias.com/india-in-1750/)

### The emergence of the British as the central controlling authority

During the 19th century, the British established a firm hold on India. The British started implementing their policies in India. The British used India as a colonial market which resulted in a significant ‘Drain of Wealth’ from India to the United Kingdom. The British policy of ‘Divide and Rule’ created tension among communities in India and affected its unity and integration. However, some of the British measures like the creation of a centralized bureaucracy, the introduction of Western-style education, and the expansion of infrastructure, such as railways and telegraph lines gave India a modern outlook.

Wish to know more? Read: [The British Expansion in India – East India Company, Presidencies, Governor-generals, and Battles](https://www.clearias.com/british-expansion-in-india/)

### Dissatisfaction against the Foreign rule

Unlike the Mughals, the British never integrated completely with the Indians. Many Indians were not happy under foreign rule and white supremacy. The Indian nationalist movement began to take shape in the late 19th century. Leaders such as Bal Gangadhar Tilak and Bipin Chandra Pal called for greater Indian self-rule.

Wish to know more? Read:

* [The Changes introduced by the British in India](https://www.clearias.com/changes-introduced-by-british-in-india/)
* [Popular Uprisings and Revolts against the British](https://www.clearias.com/popular-uprisings-revolts-against-british/)
* [Socio-Religious Movements in India](https://www.clearias.com/socio-religious-movements-india/)

### Nationalist Movements and Independence

However, it was Mahatma Gandhi who truly galvanized the Indian people and led the country on the path of non-violent resistance against British colonial rule. With the support of millions of Indians, Gandhi’s campaigns of civil disobedience and non-cooperation forced the British government to negotiate with Indian leaders and eventually grant independence in 1947.

Wish to know more?

Also read: [India’s struggle for independence: The Indian Freedom Movement](https://www.clearias.com/indias-struggle-for-independence/)

### Building of a new nation under Nehru

The period following independence saw the country under the leadership of Jawaharlal Nehru, India’s first Prime Minister. Nehru implemented policies of planned economic development and industrialization, which led to rapid economic growth and social change in India. However, Nehru’s focus on socialism and state control also led to inefficiencies and slow growth in certain sectors.

### Wars with Pakistan and China

India’s relations with Pakistan, which was formed as a separate country for Muslims, have been marked by conflict and tension, including multiple wars and ongoing disputes over the region of Kashmir. India has also faced political instability, with frequent changes in government and a rise in regional, religious, and caste-based politics.

### Economic Liberlisation and Globalisation

In the 1990s, under Prime Minister P.V Narasimha Rao and his Finance Minister Dr. Manmohan Singh, India adopted economic liberalization policies, leading to a significant increase in economic growth and foreign investment. This also led to a rapid expansion of the middle class and significant improvements in living standards for many Indians.

### Significant progress in spite of challenges

India has continued to grow economically and politically in the 21st century, with a rising global profile and increasing influence in international affairs. The country has also made significant progress in areas such as technology, space exploration, and renewable energy. However, India still faces many challenges, including poverty, inequality, and communal tensions.

## Significant Events in the Modern Indian History

[Subscribe to the ClearIAS YouTube Channel](https://www.youtube.com/clearias?sub_confirmation=1) for more informative videos on UPSC preparation, tips, and strategies. Stay updated with our latest content and enhance your exam readiness.

There have been many significant events in modern Indian history from 1750 to 1947. One of the most important events during this period was the British colonization of India, which began in the 18th century and lasted until the middle of the 20th century.

The Indian Rebellion of 1857, also known as the Indian Mutiny, was a major event that marked the beginning of the end of British East India Company rule in India and led to the British Crown taking direct control of the country.

The Non-Cooperation Movement led by Mahatma Gandhi in the 1920s, the Salt Satyagraha in 1930 and the Quit India Movement in 1942 were some of the key events in the Indian independence movement. These events led to a growing sense of nationalism among Indians and ultimately led to the country gaining independence from British rule in 1947. This was a significant event not only for India but also for the entire subcontinent, as it led to the creation of Pakistan as well.

Another important event in Indian history was the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi in 1948. Gandhi was a key leader in the independence movement and his death had a profound impact on the country.

The Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 and 1971, the economic liberalization of 1991, the Pokhran nuclear test of 1998, the Kargil War of 1999 and the 26/11 Mumbai terrorist attack of 2008 are some of the other notable events in modern Indian history.

### Indian Rebellion of 1857

Also known as the Indian Mutiny or the First War of Independence, this was a major rebellion against British colonial rule in India.

### Birth of the Indian National Congress (INC) in 1885

The Indian National Congress, a political party which became the primary voice of the Indian independence movement, was founded in 1885.

### The partition of Bengal in 1905

The partition of Bengal in 1905 by the British government was an attempt to weaken the growing nationalist movement through the ‘Divide and Rule’ policy. Many Indians opposed this.

### The Jallianwala Bagh Massacre of 1919

The Jallianwala Bagh Massacre of 1919, where British troops killed hundreds of unarmed Indian civilians, was a turning point in Indian history and increased the resentment towards British rule.

### Non-Cooperation Movement in 1920

Led by Mahatma Gandhi, this movement was a major campaign of civil disobedience and non-violent resistance against British colonial rule.

### The Civil Disobedience Movement in 1930

The Salt Satyagraha in 1930 led by Mahatma Gandhi, was a peaceful protest against the British salt monopoly and became a symbol of resistance to British rule.

### The Government of India Act 1935

The Government of India Act 1935 was passed, which aimed to give Indians more representation in government but was widely criticized for falling short of true self-government.

### World War II

The forced involvement of India in World War II put a heavy burden on the economy and increased resentment towards British rule.

### The Quit India Movement in 1942

The Quit India Movement in 1942, was a mass civil disobedience movement called by Mahatma Gandhi for immediate independence of India, it was one of the most aggressive movements against British colonial rule.

### The Indian Independence Act of 1947

This act passed by the British parliament granted independence to India and Pakistan on 15th August 1947.

### Partition of India in 1947

In 1947, British India was partitioned into the independent nations of India and Pakistan, with a large-scale population exchange of Hindus and Muslims.

### India-China War 1962

The war fought between India and China in 1962 over the disputed border region resulted in a Chinese victory.

### The Green Revolution of the 1960s and 1970s

The period of increase in agricultural production in India in the 1960s and 1970s was due to the introduction of high-yielding varieties of seeds, fertilizers, and irrigation facilities.

### Indian Nuclear Program in 1974

In 1974 India successfully detonated a nuclear device, becoming the 6th nuclear weapons state in the world.

### The Emergency in 1975

In 1975, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared a state of emergency in India, suspending civil liberties and democratic institutions.

### The assassination of Indira Gandhi in 1884

Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister of India was assassinated by her own bodyguards in 1984.

### Economic Liberalization in 1991

In 1991, under Prime Minister P.V Narasimha Rao and his finance minister Dr. Manmohan Singh, India adopted economic liberalization policies.

### The Mumbai Bombings in 1993

A series of bombings in Mumbai in 1993, orchestrated by organized crime groups, resulted in the deaths of over 250 people.

### Rise of Right-wing Politics from the late 1990s

From the late 1990s, India saw the rise of right-wing, Hindu nationalist politics, led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).

### The Kargil War of 1999

A conflict between India and Pakistan in 1999, fought in the Kargil district of Kashmir, resulted in an Indian victory.

### The Gujarat Riots of 2002

In 2002, Hindu-Muslim riots broke out in the state of Gujarat, resulting in the deaths of over 1000 people, mostly Muslims.

### The 26/11 Mumbai Terror Attacks in 2008

A series of terrorist attacks in Mumbai in 2008, carried out by a Pakistan-based militant group, resulted in the deaths of over 160 people.

### The Anna Hazare Movement in 2011

The movement led by Anna Hazare in 2011, demanded the implementation of the Jan Lokpal Bill, a proposed anti-corruption law.

### The 2014 General Election

The BJP led by Narendra Modi emerged as the single largest party in the general elections, leading to Modi becoming the Prime Minister.

### Demonetization in 2016

In 2016, the Indian government demonetized the 500 and 1000 rupee notes, effectively rendering 86% of the cash in circulation invalid.

### The abrogation of Article 370 in 2019

In 2019, the Indian government revoked the special status of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, sparking widespread protests and criticism from various political parties and human rights organizations

### The COVID-19 Pandemic

India was hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, with a lot of cases and deaths.

## Significant Personalities in Modern Indian History

There have been many significant personalities in modern Indian history who have played a crucial role in shaping the country.

### Mahatma Gandhi

Considered the “Father of the Nation,” [Mahatma Gandhi](https://www.clearias.com/mahatma-gandhi/) led the Indian independence movement through non-violent civil disobedience and is considered one of the most influential figures in Indian history.

### Jawaharlal Nehru

India’s first Prime Minister, [Jawaharlal Nehru](https://www.clearias.com/jawaharlal-nehru/) played a key role in shaping the country’s foreign and domestic policies following independence.

### Sardar Patel

Known as the “Iron Man of India,” [Sardar Patel](https://www.clearias.com/sardar-vallabhbhai-patel/) played a key role in the integration of the princely states into the Indian Union following independence.

### B. R. Ambedkar

An Indian jurist, economist, politician and social reformer, [Ambedkar](https://www.clearias.com/ambedkar/) was the main architect of the Indian Constitution and champion for the rights of Dalits (formerly known as “untouchables”) and other marginalized communities.

### Subhas Chandra Bose

A prominent Indian nationalist leader, [Subhas Chandra Bose](https://www.clearias.com/subhas-chandra-bose/) was a key figure in the Indian independence movement and advocated for a more aggressive approach to achieving freedom from British rule.

### Rajendra Prasad

India’s first President, [Rajendra Prasad](https://www.clearias.com/dr-rajendra-prasad/) played a key role in the drafting of the Indian Constitution and in the early years of the Indian Republic.

### Maulana Abul Kalam Azad

A prominent Muslim leader, [Maulana Abul Kalam Azad](https://www.clearias.com/maulana-abul-kalam-azad/) was a key figure in the Indian independence movement and served as India’s first Education Minister following independence.

### C. Rajagopalachari

A freedom fighter and one of the first leaders of the Indian National Congress, [Rajagopalachari](https://www.clearias.com/c-rajagopalachari/) served as the last Governor-General of India and later as the Chief Minister of Madras state.

### Bhagat Singh

[Bhagat Singh](https://www.clearias.com/bhagat-singh/) was an Indian revolutionary socialist who was influential in the Indian independence movement, he is considered to be one of the most influential revolutionaries of the Indian independence movement, and is often referred to as Shaheed Bhagat Singh, the word “Shaheed” meaning “martyr” in Arabic.

### Indira Gandhi

India’s first female Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi was a powerful political figure who implemented policies of economic development and industrialization, but also faced criticism for authoritarianism and human rights abuses.

### Rajiv Gandhi

The son of Indira Gandhi, Rajiv Gandhi served as Prime Minister of India and was responsible for introducing several economic and technological advancements in the country.

### V. P. Singh

The 7th Prime Minister of India, Singh was a leader of the Janata Dal party and is remembered for his efforts to address issues of caste discrimination and corruption.

### Atal Bihari Vajpayee

A former Prime Minister of India, Vajpayee was a leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and played a key role in shaping India’s foreign policy.

### Manmohan Singh

India’s first Sikh Prime Minister, Dr. Manmohan Singh served two terms as Prime Minister and is credited with implementing economic liberalization policies that led to significant growth in the Indian economy.

### Narendra Modi

The current Prime Minister of India, Modi is a leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and has implemented a range of economic and social policies during his time in office.

## Major Issues in the Modern Indian History

Modern India witnessed many problems and issues. The major issues in the history of modern India include poverty, inequality, caste discrimination, communal tensions etc. Most of these issues are still prevalent in India.

### (1) Colonialism and the Drain of Wealth

The impact of [British colonialism on India](https://www.clearias.com/colonization/), including the exploitation of resources and the suppression of Indian culture and identity, was a major issue in modern Indian history.

### (2) Communal Tensions and Religious Violence

India has a diverse population made up of many different religious and ethnic groups. Communal tensions and religious violence, particularly between Hindus and Muslims, have been recurring issues in modern Indian history.

### (3) Caste Discrimination

[India’s caste system](https://www.clearias.com/caste-system-in-india/), which has traditionally determined a person’s social status and occupation based on birth, has been a major issue in modern Indian history. Discrimination and violence against lower castes, particularly Dalits (formerly known as “untouchables”), have been widespread.

### (4) Poverty

Despite significant economic growth in recent decades, [poverty](https://www.clearias.com/poverty/) remains a major issue in India. Millions of Indians still live in extreme poverty.

### (5) Inequality

There is a wide gap between the rich and the poor.

### (6) Political Instability and Corruption

India has seen frequent changes in government and political instability, with a rise in regional and caste-based politics. Corruption has also been a major issue, with many politicians and bureaucrats being accused of corrupt practices.

### (7) Separatist movements

India is a diverse country. Many regions have their own distinct cultural and linguistic identities. Separatist movements in many states/regions in India have been a major issue in modern Indian history.

### (8) Human rights violations

The suppression of civil liberties and democratic institutions, violence against marginalized communities, and extrajudicial killings are reported in India.

### (9) Environmental degradation

India’s rapid economic growth has led to a significant increase in pollution and environmental degradation, with issues such as deforestation, water pollution, and air pollution becoming increasingly severe.

### (10) Political Instability

The 1990s and 2000s saw a rise in regional and caste-based politics. This resulted in coalition politics and political instability. Even though not without criticism, the popularity of right-wing politics resulted in a stable majority government in India after 2014.

### (11) India-Pakistan Conflicts

The relationship between [India and Pakistan](https://www.clearias.com/india-pakistan/), which have a long-standing dispute over the region of Kashmir, has been a major issue in modern Indian history. The two countries have fought several wars, and tensions between them remain high.

### (12) India-China Conflicts

[India and China](https://www.clearias.com/india-china-border-disputes/) engaged in war in 1962 over territorial disputes and conflicts, which resulted in a Chinese victory. There are ongoing border disputes in the Himalayan region.

### (13) Internal Security Issues

Internal security issues in India include a range of challenges that affect the country’s stability and safety. Some of the major internal security issues in India include [Insurgency](https://www.clearias.com/north-east-india-insurgency-issues/), [Terrorism](https://www.clearias.com/terrorism/), Naxalism, [Cybercrimes](https://www.clearias.com/cybercrime/) etc.

## Conclusion

In conclusion, modern Indian history is a [multifaceted story](https://www.clearias.com/how-to-study-modern-indian-history/) of political struggles, economic development, and social change.

From the decline of the Mughal Empire to the rise of the nationalist movement, from the [struggle for independence](https://www.clearias.com/indias-struggle-for-independence/) to the [challenges of building a modern nation-state](https://www.clearias.com/post-independence-consolidation-and-reorganization-within-the-country/), the [history of India](https://www.clearias.com/indian-history/) is a story of a people’s determination to shape their own destiny.

The early modern period began in the 16th century, when the Mughal Empire conquered most of the Indian subcontinent, signaling the proto-industrialisation, becoming the biggest global economy and manufacturing power. The Mughals suffered a gradual decline in the early 18th century, largely due to the rising power of the Marathas, who took control of extensive regions of the Indian subcontinent, and numerous Afghan invasions. [Anatomically modern humans](/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans "Anatomically modern humans") first arrived on the [Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent") between 73,000 and 55,000 years ago.[[1]](#cite_note-1) The earliest known human remains in South Asia date to 30,000 years ago. [Sedentariness](/wiki/Sedentism "Sedentism") began in South Asia around 7000 BCE; by 4500 BCE, settled life had spread,[[2]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright201044,_51-2) and gradually evolved into the [Indus Valley Civilisation](/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation "Indus Valley Civilisation"), one of three early [cradles of civilisation](/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization "Cradle of civilization") in the [Old World](/wiki/Old_World "Old World"),[[3]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright20101-3)[[4]](#cite_note-auto-4) which flourished between 2500 BCE and 1900 BCE in present-day [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") and north-western India. Early in the second millennium BCE, [persistent drought](/wiki/4.2_kiloyear_event "4.2 kiloyear event") caused the population of the Indus Valley to scatter from large urban centres to villages. [Indo-Aryan tribes](/wiki/Rigvedic_tribes "Rigvedic tribes") moved into the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab") from [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia") in several [waves of migration](/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration_theory "Indo-Aryan migration theory"). The [Vedic Period](/wiki/Vedic_Period "Vedic Period") of the Vedic people in northern India (1500–500 BCE) was marked by the composition of their extensive collections of hymns ([Vedas](/wiki/Vedas "Vedas")). The social structure was loosely stratified via the [varna system](/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism) "Varna (Hinduism)"), incorporated into the highly evolved present-day [Jāti](/wiki/J%C4%81ti "Jāti") system. The pastoral and nomadic Indo-Aryans spread from the Punjab into the [Gangetic plain](/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain "Indo-Gangetic Plain"). Around 600 BCE a second urbanization occurred resulting in a new interregional culture; then, smaller [janapadas](/wiki/Janapada "Janapada") (realms) were consolidated into [mahajanapadas](/wiki/Mahajanapadas "Mahajanapadas") (great states). This period saw the rise of new [ascetic](/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a "Śramaṇa") movements and religious concepts,[[5]](#cite_note-Flood_273-274-5) including the rise of [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism") and [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"). The latter [was synthesized](/wiki/Hindu_synthesis "Hindu synthesis") with the preexisting religious cultures of the subcontinent, giving rise to [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism").

[Chandragupta Maurya](/wiki/Chandragupta_Maurya "Chandragupta Maurya") overthrew the [Nanda Empire](/wiki/Nanda_Empire "Nanda Empire") and established the first great empire in ancient India, the [Maurya Empire](/wiki/Maurya_Empire "Maurya Empire"). India's Mauryan king [Ashoka](/wiki/Ashoka "Ashoka") is widely recognised for the violent [Kalinga War](/wiki/Kalinga_War "Kalinga War") and his historical acceptance of [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") and his attempts to spread [nonviolence](/wiki/Nonviolence "Nonviolence") and [peace](/wiki/Peace "Peace") across his empire. This period marks the rapid dissemination of Śramaṇic religions.

The Maurya Empire would collapse in 185 BCE, on the assassination of the then-emperor [Brihadratha](/wiki/Brihadratha_Maurya "Brihadratha Maurya") by his general [Pushyamitra Shunga](/wiki/Pushyamitra_Shunga "Pushyamitra Shunga"). The [Shunga Empire](/wiki/Shunga_Empire "Shunga Empire") in the north and north-east of the subcontinent would fracture into various smaller polities. Whereas, in the North West, the [Greco-Bactrians](/wiki/Greco-Bactrian_Kingdom "Greco-Bactrian Kingdom") would found the [Indo-Greek Kingdoms](/wiki/Indo-Greek_Kingdom "Indo-Greek Kingdom"), which were replaced by successive invasions from [Indo-Scythians](/wiki/Indo-Scythian_Kingdom "Indo-Scythian Kingdom"), [Indo-Parthians](/wiki/Indo-Parthian_kingdom "Indo-Parthian kingdom") and [Kushan Empires](/wiki/Kushan_Empire "Kushan Empire"). The [Gupta Empire](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") from Greater [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha "Magadha"), in the 4th to 6th centuries CE, would reunify these regions as mentioned in the [Iron pillar of Delhi](/wiki/Iron_pillar_of_Delhi "Iron pillar of Delhi"). This period, witnessing a [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu") religious and intellectual resurgence is known as the [Classical](/wiki/Classical_India "Classical India") or [Golden Age of India](/wiki/Golden_Age_of_India "Golden Age of India"). Aspects of Indian civilisation, administration, culture, and religion spread to much of Asia, which led to the establishment of Indianised kingdoms in the region, forming [Greater India](/wiki/Greater_India "Greater India").[[6]](#cite_note-6)[[5]](#cite_note-Flood_273-274-5)

The Gupta Empire would gradually wane due to multiple invasions from the [Huna people](/wiki/Huna_people "Huna people") and loss of core territories. Huna invasions would be checked by regional rulers including [Yashodharman](/wiki/Yashodharman "Yashodharman") supported by the [Later Guptas](/wiki/Later_Gupta_dynasty "Later Gupta dynasty"), then again by [Harsha](/wiki/Harsha "Harsha"). The large scale invasion of Huna peoples and their assimilation led to the syncretic [Pratihara dynasty](/wiki/Pratihara_dynasty "Pratihara dynasty"). The most significant event between the 7th and 11th centuries was the [Tripartite struggle](/wiki/Tripartite_struggle "Tripartite struggle") centred on [Kannauj](/wiki/Kannauj "Kannauj") resulting in Pratihara victory.

[Southern India](/wiki/History_of_South_India "History of South India") saw the rise of multiple imperial powers from the middle of the fifth century. The [Chola dynasty](/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty") conquered southern India in the 11th century. In the early medieval period, [Indian mathematics](/wiki/Indian_mathematics "Indian mathematics"), including [Hindu numerals](/wiki/Hindu_numeral_system "Hindu numeral system"), influenced the development of mathematics and astronomy in the [Arab world](/wiki/Arab_world "Arab world"), including the creation of the [Hindu-Arabic numeral system](/wiki/Hindu-Arabic_numeral_system "Hindu-Arabic numeral system").[[7]](#cite_note-7)

[Islamic conquests](/wiki/Muslim_conquests_in_the_Indian_subcontinent "Muslim conquests in the Indian subcontinent") made limited inroads into modern Afghanistan and [Sindh](/wiki/Sindh "Sindh") as early as the 8th century,[[8]](#cite_note-8) followed by the invasions of [Mahmud Ghazni](/wiki/Mahmud_Ghazni "Mahmud Ghazni").[[9]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeri2005146-9) The [Delhi Sultanate](/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate "Delhi Sultanate"), established in 1206 by Central Asian Turks, ruled much of northern India in the 14th century. It was governed by various Turkic and Afghan dynasties, including the [Indo-Turkic](/wiki/Indo-Turkic "Indo-Turkic") [Tughlaqs](/wiki/Tughlaq_dynasty "Tughlaq dynasty").[[10]](#cite_note-auto3-10)[[11]](#cite_note-auto2-11) The empire declined in the late 14th century following the invasions of [Timur](/wiki/Timur "Timur")[[12]](#cite_note-12) and saw the advent of the [Malwa](/wiki/Malwa_Sultanate "Malwa Sultanate"), [Gujarat](/wiki/Gujarat_Sultanate "Gujarat Sultanate"), and [Bahmani](/wiki/Bahmani_Sultanate "Bahmani Sultanate") sultanates, the last of which split in 1518 into the five [Deccan sultanates](/wiki/Deccan_sultanates "Deccan sultanates"). The wealthy [Bengal Sultanate](/wiki/Bengal_Sultanate "Bengal Sultanate") also emerged as a major power, lasting over three centuries.[[13]](#cite_note-13) During this period, multiple strong Hindu kingdoms, notably the [Vijayanagara Empire](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire") and [Rajput states](/wiki/List_of_Rajput_dynasties_and_states "List of Rajput dynasties and states") under the [Kingdom of Mewar](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mewar "Kingdom of Mewar") emerged and played significant roles in shaping the cultural and political landscape of India.[[14]](#cite_note-14)[[15]](#cite_note-15)

The early modern period began in the 16th century, when the [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire") conquered most of the Indian subcontinent,[[16]](#cite_note-exeter-16) signaling the [proto-industrialisation](/wiki/Proto-industrialisation "Proto-industrialisation"), becoming the biggest global economy and manufacturing power.[[17]](#cite_note-17)[[18]](#cite_note-18)[[19]](#cite_note-19) The Mughals suffered a gradual decline in the early 18th century, largely due to the rising power of the [Marathas](/wiki/Maratha_Confederacy "Maratha Confederacy"), who took control of extensive regions of the Indian subcontinent, and numerous [Afghan invasions](/wiki/Indian_campaign_of_Ahmad_Shah_Durrani "Indian campaign of Ahmad Shah Durrani").[[20]](#cite_note-20)[[21]](#cite_note-21)[[22]](#cite_note-22) The [East India Company](/wiki/East_India_Company "East India Company"), acting as a sovereign force on behalf of the [British government](/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of the United Kingdom"), gradually acquired control of huge areas of India between the middle of the 18th and the middle of the 19th centuries. Policies of [company rule in India](/wiki/Company_rule_in_India "Company rule in India") led to the [Indian Rebellion of 1857](/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857 "Indian Rebellion of 1857"). India was afterwards ruled directly by the [British Crown](/wiki/The_Crown "The Crown"), in the [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj"). After [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), a nationwide struggle for independence was launched by the [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress"), led by [Mahatma Gandhi](/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi"). Later, the [All-India Muslim League](/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League "All-India Muslim League") would advocate for a separate Muslim-majority [nation state](/wiki/Nation_state "Nation state"). The British Indian Empire was partitioned in August 1947 into the [Dominion of India](/wiki/Dominion_of_India "Dominion of India") and [Dominion of Pakistan](/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan "Dominion of Pakistan"), each gaining its independence.

### Paleolithic

Main article: [South Asian Stone Age](/wiki/South_Asian_Stone_Age "South Asian Stone Age")

[Hominin](/wiki/Hominini "Hominini") expansion from Africa is estimated to have reached the [Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent") approximately two million years ago, and possibly as early as 2.2 million years ago.[[26]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147-26)[[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075-27)[[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170-28) This dating is based on the known presence of *[Homo erectus](/wiki/Homo_erectus "Homo erectus")* in [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia") by 1.8 million years ago and in East Asia by 1.36 million years ago, as well as the discovery of stone tools at [Riwat](/wiki/Riwat "Riwat") in [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan").[[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075-27)[[29]](#cite_note-29) Although some older discoveries have been claimed, the suggested dates, based on the dating of [fluvial sediments](/wiki/Fluvial_processes "Fluvial processes"), have not been independently verified.[[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170-28)[[30]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-30)

The oldest hominin fossil remains in the Indian subcontinent are those of *Homo erectus* or *[Homo heidelbergensis](/wiki/Homo_heidelbergensis "Homo heidelbergensis")*, from the [Narmada Valley](/wiki/Narmada_River "Narmada River") in central India, and are dated to approximately half a million years ago.[[27]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20075-27)[[30]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-30) Older fossil finds have been claimed, but are considered unreliable.[[30]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-30) Reviews of archaeological evidence have suggested that occupation of the Indian subcontinent by hominins was sporadic until approximately 700,000 years ago, and was geographically widespread by approximately 250,000 years ago.[[30]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChauhan2010147–160-30)[[28]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetraglia2010167–170-28)

According to a historical demographer of South Asia, Tim Dyson:

> Modern human beings—*Homo sapiens*—originated in Africa. Then, intermittently, sometime between 60,000 and 80,000 years ago, tiny groups of them began to enter the north-west of the Indian subcontinent. It seems likely that initially they came by way of the coast. It is virtually certain that there were *Homo sapiens* in the subcontinent 55,000 years ago, even though the earliest fossils that have been found of them date to only about 30,000 years before the present.[[31]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDyson20181-31)

According to Michael D. Petraglia and [Bridget Allchin](/wiki/Bridget_Allchin "Bridget Allchin"):

> Y-Chromosome and Mt-DNA data support the colonisation of South Asia by modern humans originating in Africa. ... Coalescence dates for most non-European populations average to between 73–55 ka.[[32]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPetragliaAllchin20076-32)

Historian of South Asia, [Michael H. Fisher](/wiki/Michael_H._Fisher "Michael H. Fisher"), states:

> Scholars estimate that the first successful expansion of the Homo sapiens range beyond Africa and across the Arabian Peninsula occurred from as early as 80,000 years ago to as late as 40,000 years ago, although there may have been prior unsuccessful emigrations. Some of their descendants extended the human range ever further in each generation, spreading into each habitable land they encountered. One human channel was along the warm and productive coastal lands of the Persian Gulf and northern Indian Ocean. Eventually, various bands entered India between 75,000 years ago and 35,000 years ago.[[33]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisher201823-33)

Archaeological evidence has been interpreted to suggest the presence of [anatomically modern humans](/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans "Anatomically modern humans") in the Indian subcontinent 78,000–74,000 years ago,[[34]](#cite_note-34) although this interpretation is disputed.[[35]](#cite_note-35)[[36]](#cite_note-36) The occupation of South Asia by modern humans, initially in varying forms of isolation as hunter-gatherers, has turned it into a highly diverse one, second only to Africa in human genetic diversity.[[37]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDyson201828-37)

According to Tim Dyson:

> Genetic research has contributed to knowledge of the prehistory of the subcontinent's people in other respects. In particular, the level of genetic diversity in the region is extremely high. Indeed, only Africa's population is genetically more diverse. Related to this, there is strong evidence of 'founder' events in the subcontinent. By this is meant circumstances where a subgroup—such as a tribe—derives from a tiny number of 'original' individuals. Further, compared to most world regions, the subcontinent's people are relatively distinct in having practised comparatively high levels of endogamy.[[37]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDyson201828-37)

### Neolithic

[Settled life](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") emerged on the subcontinent in the western margins of the [Indus River](/wiki/Indus_River "Indus River") alluvium approximately 9,000 years ago, evolving gradually into the [Indus Valley Civilisation](/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation "Indus Valley Civilisation") of the third millennium BCE.[[2]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright201044,_51-2)[[39]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDyson20184-5-39) According to Tim Dyson: "By 7,000 years ago agriculture was firmly established in Baluchistan... [and] slowly spread eastwards into the Indus valley." Michael Fisher adds:[[40]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisher201833-40)

> The earliest discovered instance ... of well-established, settled agricultural society is at Mehrgarh in the hills between the Bolan Pass and the Indus plain (today in Pakistan) (see Map 3.1). From as early as 7000 BCE, communities there started investing increased labor in preparing the land and selecting, planting, tending, and harvesting particular grain-producing plants. They also domesticated animals, including sheep, goats, pigs, and oxen (both humped zebu [*Bos indicus*] and unhumped [*Bos taurus*]). Castrating oxen, for instance, turned them from mainly meat sources into domesticated draft-animals as well.[[40]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisher201833-40)

## Bronze Age (c. 3300 – 1800 BCE)

### Indus Valley Civilisation

Main article: [Indus Valley Civilisation](/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation "Indus Valley Civilisation")

See also: [List of Indus Valley Civilisation sites](/wiki/List_of_Indus_Valley_Civilisation_sites "List of Indus Valley Civilisation sites")

The [Bronze Age in the Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Bronze_Age_India "Bronze Age India") began around 3300 BCE.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*] The Indus Valley region was one of three early [cradles of civilisation](/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization "Cradle of civilization") in the [Old World](/wiki/Old_World "Old World"); the Indus Valley civilisation was the most expansive,[[3]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright20101-3) and at its peak, may have had a population of over five million.[[4]](#cite_note-auto-4)

The civilisation was primarily centred in modern-day Pakistan, in the Indus river basin, and secondarily in the [Ghaggar-Hakra River](/wiki/Ghaggar-Hakra_River "Ghaggar-Hakra River") basin. The mature Indus civilisation flourished from about 2600 to 1900 BCE, marking the beginning of urban civilisation on the Indian subcontinent. It included cities such as [Harappa](/wiki/Harappa "Harappa"), [Ganweriwal](/wiki/Ganweriwal "Ganweriwal"), and [Mohenjo-daro](/wiki/Mohenjo-daro "Mohenjo-daro") in modern-day Pakistan, and [Dholavira](/wiki/Dholavira "Dholavira"), [Kalibangan](/wiki/Kalibangan "Kalibangan"), [Rakhigarhi](/wiki/Rakhigarhi "Rakhigarhi"), and [Lothal](/wiki/Lothal "Lothal") in modern-day India.

Inhabitants of the ancient Indus River valley, the Harappans, developed new techniques in metallurgy and handicraft, and produced copper, bronze, lead, and tin.[[42]](#cite_note-42) The civilisation is noted for its cities built of brick, and its roadside drainage systems, and is thought to have had some kind of municipal organisation. The civilisation also developed an [Indus script](/wiki/Indus_script "Indus script"), the earliest of the [ancient Indian scripts](/wiki/Ancient_scripts_of_the_Indian_subcontinent "Ancient scripts of the Indian subcontinent"), which is presently undeciphered.[[43]](#cite_note-43) This is the reason why [Harappan language](/wiki/Harappan_language "Harappan language") is not directly attested, and its affiliation is uncertain.[[44]](#cite_note-44)

After the collapse of Indus Valley civilisation, the inhabitants migrated from the river valleys of Indus and Ghaggar-Hakra, towards the Himalayan foothills of Ganga-Yamuna basin.[[45]](#cite_note-45)

### Ochre Coloured Pottery culture

During the 2nd millennium BCE, [Ochre Coloured Pottery culture](/wiki/Ochre_Coloured_Pottery_culture "Ochre Coloured Pottery culture") was in Ganga Yamuna Doab region. These were rural settlements with agriculture and hunting. They were using copper tools such as axes, spears, arrows, and swords, and had domesticated animals.[[47]](#cite_note-47)

## Iron Age (c. 1800 – 200 BCE)

See also: [Iron Age in India](/wiki/Iron_Age_in_India "Iron Age in India")

### Vedic period (c. 1500 – 600 BCE)

Main articles: [Vedic period](/wiki/Vedic_period "Vedic period"), [Historical Vedic religion](/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion "Historical Vedic religion"), and [Vedas](/wiki/Vedas "Vedas")

See also: [Indo-Aryan peoples](/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples "Indo-Aryan peoples") and [Indo-Aryan migrations](/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migrations "Indo-Aryan migrations")

Starting c. 1900 BCE, [Indo-Aryan tribes](/wiki/Rigvedic_tribes "Rigvedic tribes") moved into the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab") from [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia") in several [waves of migration](/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration_theory "Indo-Aryan migration theory").[[48]](#cite_note-48)[[49]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200431-49) The [Vedic period](/wiki/Vedic_period "Vedic period") is when the Vedas were composed of liturgical hymns from the Indo-Aryan people. The Vedic culture was located in part of north-west India, while other parts of India had a distinct cultural identity. Many regions of the Indian subcontinent transitioned from the [Chalcolithic](/wiki/Chalcolithic "Chalcolithic") to the [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") in this period.[[50]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008255-50)

The Vedic culture is described in the texts of [Vedas](/wiki/Vedas "Vedas"), still sacred to Hindus, which were orally composed and transmitted in [Vedic Sanskrit](/wiki/Vedic_Sanskrit "Vedic Sanskrit"). The Vedas are some of the oldest extant texts in India.[[51]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAntonovaBongard-LevinKotovsky197951-51) The Vedic period, lasting from about 1500 to 500 BCE,[[52]](#cite_note-52)[[53]](#cite_note-53) contributed to the foundations of several cultural aspects of the Indian subcontinent.

#### Vedic society

Historians have analysed the Vedas to posit a Vedic culture in the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab"), and the upper [Gangetic Plain](/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain "Indo-Gangetic Plain").[[50]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008255-50) The [Peepal](/wiki/Peepal "Peepal") tree and cow were sanctified by the time of the [Atharva Veda](/wiki/Atharva_Veda "Atharva Veda").[[55]](#cite_note-55) Many of the concepts of [Indian philosophy](/wiki/Indian_philosophy "Indian philosophy") espoused later, like [dharma](/wiki/Dharma "Dharma"), trace their roots to Vedic antecedents.[[56]](#cite_note-56)

Early Vedic society is described in the [Rigveda](/wiki/Rigveda "Rigveda"), the oldest Vedic text, believed to have been compiled during the 2nd millennium BCE,[[57]](#cite_note-57)[[58]](#cite_note-58) in the north-western region of the Indian subcontinent.[[59]](#cite_note-59) At this time, Aryan society consisted of predominantly tribal and pastoral groups, distinct from the Harappan urbanisation which had been abandoned.[[60]](#cite_note-60) The early Indo-Aryan presence probably corresponds, in part, to the [Ochre Coloured Pottery culture](/wiki/Ochre_Coloured_Pottery_culture "Ochre Coloured Pottery culture") in archaeological contexts.[[61]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A11-61)[[62]](#cite_note-Witzel1989-62)

At the end of the Rigvedic period, the Aryan society expanded from the north-western region of the Indian subcontinent into the western [Ganges](/wiki/Ganges "Ganges") plain. It became increasingly agricultural and was socially organised around the hierarchy of the four *[varnas](/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism) "Varna (Hinduism)")*, or social classes.[[63]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200843,_48,_51,_86–87-63) This social structure was characterised by the exclusion of some indigenous peoples by labelling their occupations impure.[[64]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200441–43-64) During this period, many of the previous small tribal units and chiefdoms began to coalesce into [Janapadas](/wiki/Janapada "Janapada") (monarchical, state-level polities).[[65]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008200-65)

#### Sanskrit epics

Main articles: [Mahabharata](/wiki/Mahabharata "Mahabharata") and [Ramayana](/wiki/Ramayana "Ramayana")

See also: [List of historic Indian texts](/wiki/List_of_historic_Indian_texts "List of historic Indian texts") and [List of Hindu texts](/wiki/List_of_Hindu_texts "List of Hindu texts")

The Sanskrit epics *Ramayana* and *Mahabharata* were composed during this period.[[66]](#cite_note-66) The *Mahabharata* remains the longest single poem in the world.[[67]](#cite_note-67) Historians formerly postulated an "epic age" as the milieu of these two epic poems, but now recognise that the texts went through multiple stages of development over centuries.[[68]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh200818–19-68) The existing texts of these epics are believed to belong to the post-Vedic age, between c. 400 BCE and 400 CE.[[68]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh200818–19-68)[[69]](#cite_note-69)

#### Janapadas

Main article: [Janapada](/wiki/Janapada "Janapada")

See also: [Battle of the Ten Kings](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Ten_Kings "Battle of the Ten Kings") and [List of ancient Indo-Aryan peoples and tribes](/wiki/List_of_ancient_Indo-Aryan_peoples_and_tribes "List of ancient Indo-Aryan peoples and tribes")

The [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age_India "Iron Age India") in the Indian subcontinent from about 1200 BCE to the 6th century BCE is defined by the rise of Janapadas, which are [realms](/wiki/Realms "Realms"), [republics](/wiki/Republics "Republics") and [kingdoms](/wiki/Monarchy "Monarchy")—notably the Iron Age Kingdoms of [Kuru](/wiki/Kuru_(kingdom) "Kuru (kingdom)"), [Panchala](/wiki/Panchala "Panchala"), [Kosala](/wiki/Kosala "Kosala") and [Videha](/wiki/Videha "Videha").[[70]](#cite_note-70)[[71]](#cite_note-71)

The [Kuru kingdom](/wiki/Kuru_kingdom "Kuru kingdom") (c. 1200–450 BCE) was the first state-level society of the Vedic period, corresponding to the beginning of the Iron Age in north-western India, around 1200–800 BCE,[[72]](#cite_note-72) as well as with the composition of the [Atharvaveda](/wiki/Atharvaveda "Atharvaveda").[[73]](#cite_note-Witzel_1995-73) The Kuru state organised the Vedic hymns into collections and developed the [srauta](/wiki/Srauta "Srauta") ritual to uphold the social order.[[73]](#cite_note-Witzel_1995-73) Two key figures of the Kuru state were king [Parikshit](/wiki/Parikshit "Parikshit") and his successor [Janamejaya](/wiki/Janamejaya_II "Janamejaya II"), who transformed this realm into the dominant political, social, and cultural power of northern India.[[73]](#cite_note-Witzel_1995-73) When the Kuru kingdom declined, the centre of Vedic culture shifted to their eastern neighbours, the Panchala kingdom.[[73]](#cite_note-Witzel_1995-73) The archaeological [PGW](/wiki/Painted_Grey_Ware_culture "Painted Grey Ware culture") (Painted Grey Ware) culture, which flourished in north-eastern India's [Haryana](/wiki/Haryana "Haryana") and western [Uttar Pradesh](/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh "Uttar Pradesh") regions from about 1100 to 600 BCE,[[61]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A11-61) is believed to correspond to the [Kuru](/wiki/Kuru_Kingdom "Kuru Kingdom") and [Panchala](/wiki/Pa%C3%B1c%C4%81la "Pañcāla") kingdoms.[[73]](#cite_note-Witzel_1995-73)[[74]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200848-74)

During the Late Vedic Period, the kingdom of [Videha](/wiki/Videha "Videha") emerged as a new centre of Vedic culture, situated even farther to the East (in what is today Nepal and [Bihar](/wiki/Bihar "Bihar") state);[[62]](#cite_note-Witzel1989-62) reaching its prominence under the king [Janaka](/wiki/Janaka "Janaka"), whose court provided patronage for [Brahmin](/wiki/Brahmin "Brahmin") sages and [philosophers](/wiki/Indian_philosophy "Indian philosophy") such as [Yajnavalkya](/wiki/Yajnavalkya "Yajnavalkya"), [Aruni](/wiki/Aruni "Aruni"), and [Gārgī Vāchaknavī](/wiki/G%C4%81rg%C4%AB_V%C4%81chaknav%C4%AB "Gārgī Vāchaknavī").[[75]](#cite_note-75) The later part of this period corresponds with a consolidation of increasingly large states and kingdoms, called *[Mahajanapadas](/wiki/Mahajanapadas "Mahajanapadas")*, across Northern India.

### Second urbanisation (c. 600 – 200 BCE)

The period between 800 and 200 BCE saw the formation of the *[Śramaṇa](/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a "Śramaṇa")* movement, from which [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism") and [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") originated. The first [Upanishads](/wiki/Upanishads "Upanishads") were written during this period. After 500 BCE, the so-called "second urbanisation"[[note 1]](#cite_note-77) started, with new urban settlements arising at the Ganges plain.[[77]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200847-78) The foundations for the "second urbanisation" were laid prior to 600 BCE, in the [Painted Grey Ware culture](/wiki/Painted_Grey_Ware_culture "Painted Grey Ware culture") of the [Ghaggar-Hakra](/wiki/Ghaggar-Hakra_River "Ghaggar-Hakra River") and Upper Ganges Plain; although most PGW sites were small farming villages, "several dozen" PGW sites eventually emerged as relatively large settlements that can be characterised as towns, the largest of which were fortified by ditches or moats and embankments made of piled earth with wooden palisades.[[78]](#cite_note-79)

The Central Ganges Plain, where [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha_(Mahajanapada) "Magadha (Mahajanapada)") gained prominence, forming the base of the [Maurya Empire](/wiki/Maurya_Empire "Maurya Empire"), was a distinct cultural area,[[79]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200847–48-80) with new states arising after 500 BCE.[[80]](#cite_note-81)[[81]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200841,_43-82) It was influenced by the Vedic culture,[[82]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200861-83) but differed markedly from the Kuru-Panchala region.[[83]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200848–51-84) It "was the area of the earliest known [cultivation of rice in South Asia](/wiki/History_of_rice_cultivation#Indian_subcontinent "History of rice cultivation") and by 1800 BCE was the location of an advanced Neolithic population associated with the sites of Chirand and Chechar".[[84]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200849-85) In this region, the Śramaṇic movements flourished, and Jainism and Buddhism originated.[[74]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200848-74)

#### Buddhism and Jainism

Main articles: [Upanishads](/wiki/Upanishads "Upanishads") and [Śramaṇa](/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a "Śramaṇa")

Further information: [History of Hinduism](/wiki/History_of_Hinduism "History of Hinduism"), [History of Buddhism](/wiki/History_of_Buddhism "History of Buddhism"), [History of Jainism](/wiki/History_of_Jainism "History of Jainism"), [Indian religions](/wiki/Indian_religions "Indian religions"), and [Indian philosophy](/wiki/Indian_philosophy "Indian philosophy")

Upanishads and Śramaṇa movements

A page of *[Isha Upanishad](/wiki/Isha_Upanishad "Isha Upanishad")* manuscript.

[Mahavira](/wiki/Mahavira "Mahavira"), the 24th and last [Tirthankara](/wiki/Tirthankara "Tirthankara") of [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism").

[Gautama Buddha](/wiki/Gautama_Buddha "Gautama Buddha")'s cremation stupa, [Kushinagar](/wiki/Kushinagar "Kushinagar") (Kushinara).

The time between 800 BCE and 400 BCE witnessed the composition of the earliest [Upanishads](/wiki/Upanishads "Upanishads"),[[85]](#cite_note-Flood_1996_82-86)[[86]](#cite_note-87)[[87]](#cite_note-88) which form the theoretical basis of [classical Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism"), and are also known as the *[Vedanta](/wiki/Vedanta "Vedanta")* (conclusion of the [Vedas](/wiki/Vedas "Vedas")).[[88]](#cite_note-89)

The increasing urbanisation of India in the 7th and 6th centuries BCE led to the rise of new ascetic or "Śramaṇa movements" which challenged the orthodoxy of rituals.[[85]](#cite_note-Flood_1996_82-86) [Mahavira](/wiki/Mahavira "Mahavira") (c. 599–527 BCE), proponent of [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism"), and [Gautama Buddha](/wiki/Gautama_Buddha "Gautama Buddha") (c. 563–483 BCE), founder of Buddhism, were the most prominent icons of this movement. Śramaṇa gave rise to the concept of the cycle of birth and death, the concept of [samsara](/wiki/Samsara "Samsara"), and the concept of liberation.[[89]](#cite_note-90) Buddha found a [Middle Way](/wiki/Middle_Way "Middle Way") that ameliorated the extreme [asceticism](/wiki/Asceticism "Asceticism") found in the *[Śramaṇa](/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a "Śramaṇa")* religions.[[90]](#cite_note-91)

Around the same time, [Mahavira](/wiki/Mahavira "Mahavira") (the 24th *[Tirthankara](/wiki/Tirthankara "Tirthankara")* in Jainism) propagated a theology that was to later become Jainism.[[91]](#cite_note-92) However, Jain orthodoxy believes the teachings of the *Tirthankaras* predates all known time and scholars believe [Parshvanatha](/wiki/Parshvanatha "Parshvanatha") (c. 872 – c. 772 BCE), accorded status as the 23rd *Tirthankara*, was a historical figure. The Vedas are believed to have documented a few *Tirthankaras* and an ascetic order similar to the *Śramaṇa* movement.[[92]](#cite_note-93)

#### Mahajanapadas

Main article: [Mahajanapadas](/wiki/Mahajanapadas "Mahajanapadas")

The period from c. 600 BCE to c. 300 BCE featured the rise of the [Mahajanapadas](/wiki/Mahajanapadas "Mahajanapadas"), sixteen powerful [kingdoms](/wiki/Realm "Realm") and [oligarchic](/wiki/Oligarchic "Oligarchic") republics in a belt stretching from [Gandhara](/wiki/Gandhara "Gandhara") in the north-west to [Bengal](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal") in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent—including parts of the trans-[Vindhyan](/wiki/Vindhya_Range "Vindhya Range") region.[[93]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008260–261-94) Ancient [Buddhist texts](/wiki/Buddhist_texts "Buddhist texts"), like the *[Aṅguttara Nikāya](/wiki/A%E1%B9%85guttara_Nik%C4%81ya "Aṅguttara Nikāya")*,[[94]](#cite_note-95) make frequent reference to these sixteen great kingdoms and republics—[Anga](/wiki/Anga "Anga"), [Assaka](/wiki/Assaka "Assaka"), [Avanti](/wiki/Avanti_(India) "Avanti (India)"), [Chedi](/wiki/Chedi_Kingdom "Chedi Kingdom"), [Gandhara](/wiki/Gandhara "Gandhara"), [Kashi](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kashi "Kingdom of Kashi"), [Kamboja](/wiki/Kambojas "Kambojas"), [Kosala](/wiki/Kosala "Kosala"), [Kuru](/wiki/Kuru_(India) "Kuru (India)"), [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha_(Mahajanapada) "Magadha (Mahajanapada)"), [Malla](/wiki/Malla_(tribe) "Malla (tribe)"), [Matsya](/wiki/Matsya_(tribe) "Matsya (tribe)") (or Machcha), [Panchala](/wiki/Panchala "Panchala"), [Surasena](/wiki/Surasena "Surasena"), [Vṛji](/wiki/Vajjika_League "Vajjika League"), and [Vatsa](/wiki/Vatsa "Vatsa"). This period saw the second major rise of urbanism in India after the [Indus Valley Civilisation](/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation "Indus Valley Civilisation").[[95]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A107-96)

Early "republics" or [*gaṇasaṅgha*](/wiki/Ga%E1%B9%87asa%E1%B9%85gha "Gaṇasaṅgha"),[[96]](#cite_note-Thapar-97) such as [Shakyas](/wiki/Shakya "Shakya"), [Koliyas](/wiki/Koliya "Koliya"), [Mallakas](/wiki/Malla_(tribe) "Malla (tribe)"), and [Licchavis](/wiki/Licchavi_(tribe) "Licchavi (tribe)") had republican governments. *Gaṇasaṅgha*s,[[96]](#cite_note-Thapar-97) such as the Mallakas, centered in the city of [Kusinagara](/wiki/Kusinagara "Kusinagara"), and the [Vajjika League](/wiki/Vajjika_League "Vajjika League"), centred in the city of [Vaishali](/wiki/Vaishali_(ancient_city) "Vaishali (ancient city)"), existed as early as the 6th century BCE and persisted in some areas until the 4th century CE.[[97]](#cite_note-98) The most famous clan amongst the ruling confederate clans of the Vajji Mahajanapada were the [Licchavis](/wiki/Licchavi_(tribe) "Licchavi (tribe)").[[98]](#cite_note-99)

This period corresponds in an archaeological context to the [Northern Black Polished Ware](/wiki/Northern_Black_Polished_Ware "Northern Black Polished Ware") culture. Especially focused in the Central Ganges plain but also spreading across vast areas of the northern and central Indian subcontinent, this culture is characterised by the emergence of large cities with massive fortifications, significant population growth, increased social stratification, wide-ranging trade networks, construction of public architecture and water channels, specialised craft industries, a system of weights, [punch-marked coins](/wiki/Punch-marked_coins "Punch-marked coins"), and the introduction of writing in the form of [Brahmi](/wiki/Brahmi_script "Brahmi script") and [Kharosthi](/wiki/Kharosthi "Kharosthi") scripts.[[99]](#cite_note-100)[[100]](#cite_note-101) The language of the gentry at that time was [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit"), while the languages of the general population of northern India are referred to as [Prakrits](/wiki/Prakrit "Prakrit").

Many of the sixteen kingdoms had merged into four major ones by the time of [Gautama Buddha](/wiki/Gautama_Buddha "Gautama Buddha"). These four were Vatsa, Avanti, Kosala, and Magadha.[[95]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReddy2003A107-96)

#### Early Magadha dynasties

Main articles: [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha "Magadha") and [Greater Magadha](/wiki/Greater_Magadha "Greater Magadha")

See also: [Magadha period](/wiki/Magadha_period "Magadha period"), [Pradyota dynasty](/wiki/Pradyota_dynasty "Pradyota dynasty"), [Haryanka dynasty](/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty "Haryanka dynasty"), and [Shaishunaga dynasty](/wiki/Shaishunaga_dynasty "Shaishunaga dynasty")

Magadha formed one of the sixteen [Mahajanapadas](/wiki/Mahajanapadas "Mahajanapadas") ([Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit"): "Great Realms") or [kingdoms in ancient India](/wiki/Kingdoms_of_Ancient_India "Kingdoms of Ancient India"). The core of the kingdom was the area of [Bihar](/wiki/Bihar "Bihar") south of the [Ganges](/wiki/Ganges "Ganges"); its first capital was [Rajagriha](/wiki/Rajagriha "Rajagriha") (modern Rajgir) then [Pataliputra](/wiki/Pataliputra "Pataliputra") (modern [Patna](/wiki/Patna "Patna")). Magadha expanded to include most of Bihar and Bengal with the conquest of [Licchavi](/wiki/Licchavi_(kingdom) "Licchavi (kingdom)") and [Anga](/wiki/Anga "Anga") respectively,[[101]](#cite_note-102) followed by much of eastern Uttar Pradesh and Orissa. The ancient kingdom of Magadha is heavily mentioned in Jain and Buddhist texts. It is also mentioned in the [Ramayana](/wiki/Ramayana "Ramayana"), [Mahabharata](/wiki/Mahabharata "Mahabharata") and [Puranas](/wiki/Puranas "Puranas").[[102]](#cite_note-103) The earliest reference to the Magadha people occurs in the [Atharva-Veda](/wiki/Atharva-Veda "Atharva-Veda") where they are found listed along with the [Angas](/wiki/Anga "Anga"), [Gandharis](/wiki/Gandhara "Gandhara"), and Mujavats. Magadha played an important role in the development of [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism") and [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"). Republican communities (such as the community of Rajakumara) are merged into Magadha kingdom. Villages had their own assemblies under their local chiefs called Gramakas. Their administrations were divided into executive, judicial, and military functions.

Early sources, from the Buddhist [Pāli Canon](/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon "Pāli Canon"), the [Jain Agamas](/wiki/Jain_Agamas_(%C5%9Av%C4%93t%C4%81mbara) "Jain Agamas (Śvētāmbara)") and the Hindu [Puranas](/wiki/Puranas "Puranas"), mention Magadha being ruled by the [Pradyota dynasty](/wiki/Pradyota_dynasty "Pradyota dynasty") and [Haryanka dynasty](/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty "Haryanka dynasty") (c. 544–413 BCE) for some 200 years, c. 600–413 BCE. King [Bimbisara](/wiki/Bimbisara "Bimbisara") of the [Haryanka dynasty](/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty "Haryanka dynasty") led an active and expansive policy, conquering Anga in what is now eastern Bihar and [West Bengal](/wiki/West_Bengal "West Bengal"). King Bimbisara was overthrown and killed by his son, Prince [Ajatashatru](/wiki/Ajatashatru "Ajatashatru"), who continued the expansionist policy of Magadha. During this period, [Gautama Buddha](/wiki/Gautama_Buddha "Gautama Buddha"), the founder of Buddhism, lived much of his life in the Magadha kingdom. He attained enlightenment in [Bodh Gaya](/wiki/Bodh_Gaya "Bodh Gaya"), gave his first sermon in [Sarnath](/wiki/Sarnath "Sarnath") and the [first Buddhist council](/wiki/Buddhist_councils "Buddhist councils") was held in Rajgriha.[[103]](#cite_note-104) The Haryanka dynasty was overthrown by the [Shaishunaga dynasty](/wiki/Shaishunaga_dynasty "Shaishunaga dynasty") (c. 413–345 BCE). The last Shishunaga ruler, Kalasoka, was assassinated by [Mahapadma Nanda](/wiki/Mahapadma_Nanda "Mahapadma Nanda") in 345 BCE, the first of the so-called Nine Nandas (Mahapadma Nanda and his eight sons).

#### Nanda Empire and Alexander's campaign

Main article: [Nanda Empire](/wiki/Nanda_Empire "Nanda Empire")

See also: [Indian campaign of Alexander the Great](/wiki/Indian_campaign_of_Alexander_the_Great "Indian campaign of Alexander the Great")

The [Nanda Empire](/wiki/Nanda_Empire "Nanda Empire") (c. 345–322 BCE), at its peak, extended from Bengal in the east, to the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab") in the west and as far south as the [Vindhya Range](/wiki/Vindhya_Range "Vindhya Range").[[104]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMookerji198828–33-105) The [Nanda dynasty](/wiki/Nanda_dynasty "Nanda dynasty") built on the foundations laid by their [Haryanka](/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty "Haryanka dynasty") and [Shishunaga](/wiki/Shishunaga_dynasty "Shishunaga dynasty") predecessors.[[105]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUpinder_Singh2008273-106) Nanda empire have built a vast army, consisting of 200,000 [infantry](/wiki/Infantry "Infantry"), 20,000 [cavalry](/wiki/Cavalry "Cavalry"), 2,000 war [chariots](/wiki/Ratha "Ratha") and 3,000 [war elephants](/wiki/War_elephant "War elephant") (at the lowest estimates).[[106]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMookerji198834-107)[[107]](#cite_note-108)

#### Maurya Empire

Main article: [Maurya Empire](/wiki/Maurya_Empire "Maurya Empire")

Maurya Empire

[Maurya Empire](/wiki/Maurya_Empire "Maurya Empire") at its peak under [Ashoka the Great](/wiki/Ashoka_the_Great "Ashoka the Great").

[Ashokan pillar](/wiki/Ashokan_pillar "Ashokan pillar") at [Vaishali](/wiki/Vaishali_(ancient_city) "Vaishali (ancient city)"), 3rd century BCE.

The Maurya Empire (322–185 BCE) unified most of the Indian subcontinent into one state, and was the [largest empire](/wiki/List_of_largest_empires "List of largest empires") ever to exist on the Indian subcontinent.[[108]](#cite_note-109) At its greatest extent, the Mauryan Empire stretched to the north up to the natural boundaries of the [Himalayas](/wiki/Himalayas "Himalayas") and to the east into what is now [Assam](/wiki/Assam "Assam"). To the west, it reached beyond modern Pakistan, to the [Hindu Kush](/wiki/Hindu_Kush "Hindu Kush") mountains in what is now Afghanistan. The empire was established by [Chandragupta Maurya](/wiki/Chandragupta_Maurya "Chandragupta Maurya") assisted by Chanakya ([Kautilya](/wiki/Kautilya "Kautilya")) in [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha_(Mahajanapada) "Magadha (Mahajanapada)") (in modern [Bihar](/wiki/Bihar "Bihar")) when he overthrew the [Nanda Empire](/wiki/Nanda_Empire "Nanda Empire").[[109]](#cite_note-110)

Chandragupta rapidly expanded his power westwards across central and western India, and by 317 BCE the empire had fully occupied north-western India. The Mauryan Empire defeated [Seleucus I](/wiki/Seleucus_I_Nicator "Seleucus I Nicator"), founder of the [Seleucid Empire](/wiki/Seleucid_Empire "Seleucid Empire"), during the [Seleucid–Mauryan war](/wiki/Seleucid%E2%80%93Mauryan_war "Seleucid–Mauryan war"), thus gained additional territory west of the Indus River. Chandragupta's son [Bindusara](/wiki/Bindusara "Bindusara") succeeded to the throne around 297 BCE. By the time he died in c. 272 BCE, a large part of the Indian subcontinent was under Mauryan suzerainty. However, the region of [Kalinga](/wiki/Kalinga_(historical_region) "Kalinga (historical region)") (around modern day [Odisha](/wiki/Odisha "Odisha")) remained outside Mauryan control, perhaps interfering with trade with the south.[[110]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003178–180-111)

Bindusara was succeeded by [Ashoka](/wiki/Ashoka "Ashoka"), whose reign lasted until his death in about 232 BCE.[[111]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003204–206-112) His campaign against the Kalingans in about 260 BCE, though successful, led to immense loss of life and misery. This led Ashoka to shun violence, and subsequently to embrace Buddhism.[[110]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003178–180-111) The empire began to decline after his death and the last Mauryan ruler, [Brihadratha](/wiki/Brihadratha_Maurya "Brihadratha Maurya"), was assassinated by [Pushyamitra Shunga](/wiki/Pushyamitra_Shunga "Pushyamitra Shunga") to establish the [Shunga Empire](/wiki/Shunga_Empire "Shunga Empire").[[111]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003204–206-112)

Under Chandragupta Maurya and his successors, internal and external trade, agriculture, and economic activities all thrived and expanded across India thanks to the creation of a single efficient system of finance, administration, and security. The Mauryans built the [Grand Trunk Road](/wiki/Grand_Trunk_Road "Grand Trunk Road"), one of Asia's oldest and longest major roads connecting the Indian subcontinent with Central Asia.[[112]](#cite_note-113) After the [Kalinga War](/wiki/Kalinga_War "Kalinga War"), the Empire experienced nearly half a century of peace and security under Ashoka. Mauryan India also enjoyed an era of social harmony, religious transformation, and expansion of scientific knowledge. Chandragupta Maurya's embrace of [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism "Jainism") increased social and religious renewal and reform across his society, while Ashoka's embrace of Buddhism has been said to have been the foundation of the reign of social and political peace and non-violence across India.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*] Ashoka sponsored Buddhist missions across the [Indo-Mediterranean](/wiki/Indo-Mediterranean "Indo-Mediterranean"), into [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"), [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Southeast_Asia "Buddhism in Southeast Asia"), [West Asia](/wiki/West_Asia "West Asia"), [North Africa](/wiki/North_Africa "North Africa"), and [Mediterranean Europe](/wiki/Southern_Europe "Southern Europe").[[113]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200467-114)

The *[Arthashastra](/wiki/Arthashastra "Arthashastra")* written by [Chanakya](/wiki/Chanakya "Chanakya") and the [Edicts of Ashoka](/wiki/Edicts_of_Ashoka "Edicts of Ashoka") are the primary written records of the Mauryan times. Archaeologically, this period falls in the era of [Northern Black Polished Ware](/wiki/Northern_Black_Polished_Ware "Northern Black Polished Ware"). The Mauryan Empire was based on a modern and efficient economy and society in which the sale of merchandise was closely regulated by the government.[[114]](#cite_note-115) Although there was no banking in the Mauryan society, [usury](/wiki/Usury "Usury") was customary. A significant amount of written records on slavery are found, suggesting a prevalence thereof.[[115]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAntonovaBongard-LevinKotovsky197991-116) During this period, a high-quality steel called [Wootz steel](/wiki/Wootz_steel "Wootz steel") was developed in south India and was later exported to China and Arabia.[[116]](#cite_note-117)

#### Sangam period

Main articles: [Sangam period](/wiki/Sangam_period "Sangam period"), [Sources of ancient Tamil history](/wiki/Sources_of_ancient_Tamil_history "Sources of ancient Tamil history"), [Sangam literature](/wiki/Sangam_literature "Sangam literature"), and [Five Great Epics](/wiki/Five_Great_Epics "Five Great Epics")

See also: [Three Crowned Kings](/wiki/Three_Crowned_Kings "Three Crowned Kings"), [Tamilakam](/wiki/Tamilakam "Tamilakam"), and [List of Tamil monarchs](/wiki/List_of_Tamil_monarchs "List of Tamil monarchs")

[Tamilakam](/wiki/Tamilakam "Tamilakam"), located at the tip of [South India](/wiki/South_India "South India") during the Sangam period, ruled by [Chera dynasty](/wiki/Chera_dynasty "Chera dynasty"), [Chola dynasty](/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty") and the [Pandyan dynasty](/wiki/Pandyan_dynasty "Pandyan dynasty").

[Ilango Adigal](/wiki/Ilango_Adigal "Ilango Adigal"), author of [Silappatikaram](/wiki/Silappatikaram "Silappatikaram"), one of the [five great epics](/wiki/The_Five_Great_Epics_of_Tamil_Literature "The Five Great Epics of Tamil Literature") of [Tamil literature](/wiki/Tamil_literature "Tamil literature").[[117]](#cite_note-118)

During the Sangam period [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language "Tamil language") literature flourished from the 3rd century BCE to the 4th century CE. Three Tamil dynasties, collectively known as the [Three Crowned Kings](/wiki/Three_Crowned_Kings "Three Crowned Kings") of [Tamilakam](/wiki/Tamilakam "Tamilakam"): [Chera dynasty](/wiki/Chera_dynasty "Chera dynasty"), [Chola dynasty](/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty"), and the [Pandya dynasty](/wiki/Pandya_dynasty "Pandya dynasty") ruled parts of southern India.[[118]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999204–205-119)

The Sangam literature deals with the history, politics, wars, and culture of the Tamil people of this period.[[119]](#cite_note-120) Unlike Sanskrit writers who were mostly Brahmins, Sangam writers came from diverse classes and social backgrounds and were mostly non-Brahmins.[[120]](#cite_note-121)

Around c. 300 BCE – c. 200 CE, [Pathupattu](/wiki/Pathupattu "Pathupattu"), an anthology of ten mid-length book collections, which is considered part of [Sangam Literature](/wiki/Sangam_Literature "Sangam Literature"), were composed; the composition of eight anthologies of poetic works [Ettuthogai](/wiki/Ettuthogai "Ettuthogai") as well as the composition of eighteen minor poetic works [Patiṉeṇkīḻkaṇakku](/wiki/Pati%E1%B9%89e%E1%B9%87k%C4%AB%E1%B8%BBka%E1%B9%87akku "Patiṉeṇkīḻkaṇakku"); while [Tolkāppiyam](/wiki/Tolk%C4%81ppiyam "Tolkāppiyam"), the earliest grammarian work in the [Tamil language](/wiki/Tamil_language "Tamil language") was developed.[[121]](#cite_note-122) Also, during Sangam period, two of [the Five Great Epics of Tamil Literature](/wiki/The_Five_Great_Epics_of_Tamil_Literature "The Five Great Epics of Tamil Literature") were composed. [Ilango Adigal](/wiki/Ilango_Adigal "Ilango Adigal") composed *[Silappatikaram](/wiki/Silappatikaram "Silappatikaram")*, which is a non-religious work, that revolves around [Kannagi](/wiki/Kannagi_(Tamil_mythology) "Kannagi (Tamil mythology)"),[[122]](#cite_note-123) and *[Manimekalai](/wiki/Manimekalai "Manimekalai")*, composed by [Chithalai Chathanar](/wiki/Chithalai_Chathanar "Chithalai Chathanar"), is a sequel to *Silappatikaram*, and tells the story of the daughter of [Kovalan](/wiki/Kovalan "Kovalan") and [Madhavi](/wiki/Madhavi_(Silappatikaram) "Madhavi (Silappatikaram)"), who became a [Buddhist](/wiki/Buddhist "Buddhist") [Bhikkhuni](/wiki/Bhikkhun%C4%AB "Bhikkhunī").[[123]](#cite_note-124)[[124]](#cite_note-125)

## Classical period (c. 200 BCE – 650 CE)

Main article: [Classical India](/wiki/Classical_India "Classical India")

* [Ancient India](/wiki/Ancient_India "Ancient India") during the rise of the [Shunga Empire](/wiki/Shunga_Empire "Shunga Empire") from the North, [Satavahana dynasty](/wiki/Satavahana_dynasty "Satavahana dynasty") from the [Deccan](/wiki/Deccan "Deccan"), and [Pandyan dynasty](/wiki/Pandyan_dynasty "Pandyan dynasty") and [Chola dynasty](/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty") from the [southern part of India](/wiki/South_India "South India").
* Great Chaitya in the [Karla Caves](/wiki/Karla_Caves "Karla Caves"). The shrines were developed over the period from the 2nd century BCE to the 5th century CE.
* [Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves](/wiki/Udayagiri_and_Khandagiri_Caves "Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves") is home to the [Hathigumpha inscription](/wiki/Hathigumpha_inscription "Hathigumpha inscription"), which was inscribed under [Kharavela](/wiki/Kharavela "Kharavela"), then Emperor of [Kalinga](/wiki/Kalinga_(historical_kingdom) "Kalinga (historical kingdom)") of the [Mahameghavahana dynasty](/wiki/Mahameghavahana_dynasty "Mahameghavahana dynasty").
* Relief of a multi-storied temple, 2nd century CE, [Ghantasala](/wiki/Ghantasala,_Krishna_district "Ghantasala, Krishna district") Stupa.[[125]](#cite_note-126)[[126]](#cite_note-127)
