The time between the Maurya Empire in the 3rd century BCE and the end of the [Gupta Empire](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") in the 6th century CE is referred to as the "Classical" period of India.[[127]](#cite_note-stein-128) The [Gupta Empire](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") (4th–6th century) is regarded as the [Golden Age of India](/wiki/Golden_Age_of_India "Golden Age of India"), although a host of kingdoms ruled over India in these centuries. Also, the [Sangam literature](/wiki/Sangam_literature "Sangam literature") flourished from the 3rd century BCE to the 3rd century CE in southern India.[[128]](#cite_note-129) During this period, [India's economy](/wiki/Economic_history_of_India "Economic history of India") is estimated to have been the largest in the world, having between one-third and one-quarter of the world's wealth, from 1 CE to 1000 CE.[[129]](#cite_note-130)[[130]](#cite_note-131)

### Early classical period (c. 200 BCE – 320 CE)

#### Shunga Empire

Main article: [Shunga Empire](/wiki/Shunga_Empire "Shunga Empire")

Shunga Empire

East Gateway and Railings, [Bharhut](/wiki/Bharhut "Bharhut") [Stupa](/wiki/Stupa "Stupa"), 2nd century BCE.

Shunga art [Ancient vina](/wiki/Ancient_vina "Ancient vina"), 1st century BCE.

Royal family, 1st century BCE in West Bengal.

The Shungas originated from [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha_(Mahajanapada) "Magadha (Mahajanapada)"), and controlled large areas of the central and eastern Indian subcontinent from around 187 to 78 BCE. The dynasty was established by [Pushyamitra Shunga](/wiki/Pushyamitra_Shunga "Pushyamitra Shunga"), who overthrew the last [Maurya emperor](/wiki/Maurya_Empire "Maurya Empire"). Its capital was [Pataliputra](/wiki/Pataliputra "Pataliputra"), but later emperors, such as [Bhagabhadra](/wiki/Bhagabhadra "Bhagabhadra"), also held court at [Vidisha](/wiki/Vidisha "Vidisha"), modern [Besnagar](/wiki/Besnagar "Besnagar").[[131]](#cite_note-132)

Pushyamitra Shunga ruled for 36 years and was succeeded by his son [Agnimitra](/wiki/Agnimitra "Agnimitra"). There were ten Shunga rulers. However, after the death of Agnimitra, the empire rapidly disintegrated;[[132]](#cite_note-133) inscriptions and coins indicate that much of northern and central India consisted of small kingdoms and city-states that were independent of any Shunga hegemony.[[133]](#cite_note-134) The empire is noted for its numerous wars with both foreign and indigenous powers. They fought with the [Mahameghavahana dynasty](/wiki/Mahameghavahana_dynasty "Mahameghavahana dynasty") of [Kalinga](/wiki/Kalinga_(historical_region) "Kalinga (historical region)"), [Satavahana dynasty](/wiki/Satavahana_dynasty "Satavahana dynasty") of [Deccan](/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau"), the [Indo-Greeks](/wiki/Indo-Greeks "Indo-Greeks"), and possibly the [Panchalas](/wiki/Panchala "Panchala") and [Mitras of Mathura](/wiki/Mitra_dynasty_(Mathura) "Mitra dynasty (Mathura)").

Art, education, philosophy, and other forms of learning flowered during this period including architectural monuments such as the Stupa at [Bharhut](/wiki/Bharhut "Bharhut") and the renowned Great Stupa at [Sanchi](/wiki/Sanchi "Sanchi"). The Shunga rulers helped to establish the tradition of royal sponsorship of learning and art. The script used by the empire was a variant of [Brahmi](/wiki/Brahmi "Brahmi") and was used to write the [Sanskrit language](/wiki/Sanskrit_language "Sanskrit language"). The Shunga Empire played an imperative role in patronising [Indian culture](/wiki/Indian_culture "Indian culture") at a time when some of the most important developments in Hindu thought were taking place.

#### Satavahana Empire

Main article: [Satavahana Empire](/wiki/Satavahana_Empire "Satavahana Empire")

Satavahana Empire

[Sanchi Stupa Two and Southern Gateway](/wiki/Sanchi "Sanchi"), 1st century CE ([UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site")).

Indian ship on lead coin of [Vasisthiputra Sri Pulamavi](/wiki/Vasisthiputra_Sri_Pulamavi "Vasisthiputra Sri Pulamavi"), testimony to the naval, seafaring and trading capabilities of the Sātavāhanas during the 1st–2nd century CE.

The Śātavāhanas were based from [Amaravati](/wiki/Amaravathi,_Palnadu_district "Amaravathi, Palnadu district") in [Andhra Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh") as well as [Junnar](/wiki/Junnar "Junnar") ([Pune](/wiki/Pune "Pune")) and Prathisthan ([Paithan](/wiki/Paithan "Paithan")) in [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra"). The territory of the empire covered large parts of India from the 1st century BCE onward. The Sātavāhanas started out as feudatories to the [Mauryan dynasty](/wiki/Mauryan_dynasty "Mauryan dynasty"), but declared independence with its decline.

The Sātavāhanas are known for their patronage of Hinduism and Buddhism, which resulted in Buddhist monuments from [Ellora](/wiki/Ellora_Caves "Ellora Caves") (a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site")) to [Amaravati](/wiki/Amaravathi_village,_Guntur_district "Amaravathi village, Guntur district"). They were one of the first Indian states to issue coins with their rulers embossed. They formed a cultural bridge and played a vital role in trade as well as the transfer of ideas and culture to and from the [Indo-Gangetic Plain](/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain "Indo-Gangetic Plain") to the southern tip of India.

They had to compete with the [Shunga Empire](/wiki/Shunga_Empire "Shunga Empire") and then the [Kanva dynasty](/wiki/Kanva_dynasty "Kanva dynasty") of [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha_(Mahajanapada) "Magadha (Mahajanapada)") to establish their rule. Later, they played a crucial role to protect large part of India against foreign invaders like the [Sakas](/wiki/Sakas "Sakas"), [Yavanas](/wiki/Yavanas "Yavanas") and [Pahlavas](/wiki/Pahlavas "Pahlavas"). In particular, their struggles with the [Western Kshatrapas](/wiki/Western_Kshatrapas "Western Kshatrapas") went on for a long time. The notable rulers of the Satavahana Dynasty [Gautamiputra Satakarni](/wiki/Gautamiputra_Satakarni "Gautamiputra Satakarni") and [Sri Yajna Sātakarni](/wiki/Sri_Yajna_S%C4%81takarni "Sri Yajna Sātakarni") were able to defeat the foreign invaders like the [Western Kshatrapas](/wiki/Western_Kshatrapas "Western Kshatrapas") and to stop their expansion. In the 3rd century CE, the empire was split into smaller states.[[134]](#cite_note-135)

#### Trade and travels to India

Further information: [Silk Road transmission of Buddhism](/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism "Silk Road transmission of Buddhism")

The [spice trade](/wiki/Spice_trade "Spice trade") in [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala "Kerala") attracted traders from all over the Old World to India. India's Southwest coastal port [Muziris](/wiki/Muziris "Muziris") had established itself as a major spice trade centre from as early as 3,000 BCE, according to [Sumerian records](/wiki/Sumer "Sumer"). [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish "Jewish") traders arrived in [Kochi](/wiki/Kochi "Kochi"), [Kerala, India](/wiki/Kerala,_India "Kerala, India") as early as 562 BCE.[[135]](#cite_note-136) The [Greco-Roman world](/wiki/Greco-Roman_world "Greco-Roman world") followed by trading along the [incense route](/wiki/Incense_route "Incense route") and the [Roman-India routes](/wiki/Indo-Roman_trade_relations "Indo-Roman trade relations").[[136]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELaw1978164-137) During the 2nd century BCE Greek and Indian ships met to trade at [Arabian](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula "Arabian Peninsula") ports such as [Aden](/wiki/Aden "Aden").[[137]](#cite_note-138) During the first millennium, the sea routes to India were controlled by the Indians and [Ethiopians](/wiki/Ethiopian "Ethiopian") that became the maritime trading power of the [Red Sea](/wiki/Red_Sea "Red Sea").

Indian merchants involved in spice trade took [Indian cuisine](/wiki/Indian_cuisine "Indian cuisine") to Southeast Asia, where spice mixtures and [curries](/wiki/Curry "Curry") became popular with the native inhabitants.[[138]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollingham2006245-139) Buddhism entered China through the [Silk Road](/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism "Silk Road transmission of Buddhism") in the 1st or 2nd century CE.[[139]](#cite_note-140) Hindu and Buddhist religious establishments of South and Southeast Asia came to be centres of production and commerce as they accumulated capital donated by patrons. They engaged in estate management, craftsmanship, and trade. Buddhism in particular travelled alongside the maritime trade, promoting literacy, art, and the use of coinage.[[140]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonkin200367,_60–70-141)

#### Kushan Empire

Main article: [Kushan Empire](/wiki/Kushan_Empire "Kushan Empire")

Kushan Empire

Kushan territories (full line) and maximum extent of Kushan dominions under Kanishka (dotted line), according to the Rabatak inscription

Depiction of the [Buddha](/wiki/Buddha "Buddha") in Kanishka's coinage, [Mathura art](/wiki/Mathura_art "Mathura art"), 2nd century CE

The Kushan Empire expanded out of what is now Afghanistan into the northwest of the Indian subcontinent under the leadership of their first emperor, [Kujula Kadphises](/wiki/Kujula_Kadphises "Kujula Kadphises"), about the middle of the 1st century CE. The Kushans were possibly a [Tocharian speaking](/wiki/Tocharian_languages "Tocharian languages") tribe,[[141]](#cite_note-142) one of five branches of the [Yuezhi](/wiki/Yuezhi "Yuezhi") confederation.[[142]](#cite_note-143)[[143]](#cite_note-144) By the time of his grandson, [Kanishka the Great](/wiki/Kanishka_the_Great "Kanishka the Great"), the empire spread to encompass much of [Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan "Afghanistan"),[[144]](#cite_note-145) and then the northern parts of the Indian subcontinent.[[145]](#cite_note-146)

Emperor Kanishka was a great patron of Buddhism; however, as Kushans expanded southward, the deities of their later coinage came to reflect its new [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu") majority.[[146]](#cite_note-147)[[147]](#cite_note-148) Historian [Vincent Smith](/wiki/Vincent_Arthur_Smith "Vincent Arthur Smith") said about Kanishka:

> He played the part of a second Ashoka in the history of Buddhism.[[148]](#cite_note-149)

The empire linked the Indian Ocean maritime trade with the commerce of the [Silk Road](/wiki/Silk_Road "Silk Road") through the Indus valley, encouraging long-distance trade, particularly between China and [Rome](/wiki/Roman_empire "Roman empire"). The Kushans brought new trends to the budding and blossoming [Gandhara art](/wiki/Gandhara_art "Gandhara art") and [Mathura art](/wiki/Mathura_art "Mathura art"), which reached its peak during Kushan rule.[[149]](#cite_note-150) The period of peace under Kushan rule is known as *[Pax Kushana](/wiki/Pax_Kushana "Pax Kushana")*. By the 3rd century, their empire in India was disintegrating and their last known great emperor was [Vasudeva I](/wiki/Vasudeva_I "Vasudeva I").[[150]](#cite_note-151)[[151]](#cite_note-152)

### Classical period (c. 320 – 650 CE)

#### Gupta Empire

Main article: [Gupta Empire](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire")

Further information: [Meghadūta](/wiki/Meghad%C5%ABta "Meghadūta"), [Abhijñānaśākuntala](/wiki/Abhij%C3%B1%C4%81na%C5%9B%C4%81kuntala "Abhijñānaśākuntala"), [Kumārasambhava](/wiki/Kum%C4%81rasambhava "Kumārasambhava"), [Panchatantra](/wiki/Panchatantra "Panchatantra"), [Aryabhatiya](/wiki/Aryabhatiya "Aryabhatiya"), [Indian numerals](/wiki/Indian_numerals "Indian numerals"), and [Kama Sutra](/wiki/Kama_Sutra "Kama Sutra")

Gupta Empire

[Gupta Empire](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") around 420 CE at its peak territorial extent under Kumaragupta I.

Current structure of the [Mahabodhi Temple](/wiki/Mahabodhi_Temple "Mahabodhi Temple") built during the Gupta era, 5th century CE. The location are marked where the Buddha is said to have attained enlightenment.

The Gupta period was noted for cultural creativity, especially in literature, architecture, sculpture, and painting.[[152]](#cite_note-153) The Gupta period produced scholars such as [Kalidasa](/wiki/Kalidasa "Kalidasa"), [Aryabhata](/wiki/Aryabhata "Aryabhata"), [Varahamihira](/wiki/Varahamihira "Varahamihira"), [Vishnu Sharma](/wiki/Vishnu_Sharma "Vishnu Sharma"), and [Vatsyayana](/wiki/Vatsyayana "Vatsyayana"). The Gupta period marked a watershed of Indian culture: the Guptas performed Vedic sacrifices to legitimise their rule, but they also patronised Buddhism, an alternative to Brahmanical orthodoxy. The military exploits of the first three rulers – [Chandragupta I](/wiki/Chandragupta_I "Chandragupta I"), [Samudragupta](/wiki/Samudragupta "Samudragupta"), and [Chandragupta II](/wiki/Chandragupta_II "Chandragupta II") – brought much of India under their leadership.[[153]](#cite_note-154) Science and political administration reached new heights during the Gupta era. Strong trade ties also made the region an important cultural centre and established it as a base that would influence nearby kingdoms and regions.[[154]](#cite_note-155)[[155]](#cite_note-156) The period of peace under Gupta rule is known as *[Pax Gupta](/wiki/Pax_Gupta "Pax Gupta")*.

The latter Guptas successfully resisted the northwestern kingdoms until the arrival of the [Alchon Huns](/wiki/Alchon_Huns "Alchon Huns"), who established themselves in Afghanistan by the first half of the 5th century CE, with their capital at [Bamiyan](/wiki/Bamyan,_Afghanistan "Bamyan, Afghanistan").[[156]](#cite_note-157) However, much of the southern India including [Deccan](/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau") were largely unaffected by these events.[[157]](#cite_note-158)[[158]](#cite_note-159)

#### Vakataka Empire

Main article: [Vakataka Empire](/wiki/Vakataka_Empire "Vakataka Empire")

The Vākāṭaka Empire originated from the [Deccan](/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau") in the mid-third century CE. Their state is believed to have extended from the southern edges of [Malwa](/wiki/Malwa "Malwa") and [Gujarat](/wiki/Gujarat "Gujarat") in the north to the [Tungabhadra River](/wiki/Tungabhadra_River "Tungabhadra River") in the south as well as from the [Arabian Sea](/wiki/Arabian_Sea "Arabian Sea") in the western to the edges of [Chhattisgarh](/wiki/Chhattisgarh "Chhattisgarh") in the east. They were the most important successors of the [Satavahanas](/wiki/Satavahanas "Satavahanas") in the [Deccan](/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau"), contemporaneous with the [Guptas](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") in northern India and succeeded by the [Vishnukundina dynasty](/wiki/Vishnukundina_dynasty "Vishnukundina dynasty").

The Vakatakas are noted for having been patrons of the arts, architecture and literature. The rock-cut Buddhist viharas and chaityas of [Ajanta Caves](/wiki/Ajanta_Caves "Ajanta Caves") (a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site")) were built under the patronage of Vakataka emperor, [Harishena](/wiki/Harishena "Harishena").[[159]](#cite_note-160)[[160]](#cite_note-161)

* [Ajanta Caves](/wiki/Ajanta_Caves "Ajanta Caves"), 30 [rock-cut](/wiki/Rock_cut_architecture "Rock cut architecture") Buddhist cave monument built under the [Vakatakas](/wiki/Vakatakas "Vakatakas").
* Buddhist monks praying in front of the Dagoba of Chaitya Cave 26 of the Ajanta Caves.
* Buddhist "Chaitya Griha" or prayer hall, with a seated Buddha, Cave 26 of the Ajanta Caves.
* Many foreign ambassadors, representatives, and travelers are included as devotees attending the Buddha's descent from Trayastrimsa Heaven; painting from Cave 17 of the Ajanta Caves.

#### Kamarupa Kingdom

Main article: [Kamarupa Kingdom](/wiki/Kamarupa_Kingdom "Kamarupa Kingdom")

[Samudragupta](/wiki/Samudragupta "Samudragupta")'s 4th-century [Allahabad pillar inscription](/wiki/Allahabad_Pillar#Samudragupta_inscription "Allahabad Pillar") mentions Kamarupa ([Western Assam](/wiki/Western_Assam "Western Assam"))[[161]](#cite_note-162) and [Davaka](/wiki/Davaka "Davaka") (Central Assam)[[162]](#cite_note-163) as frontier kingdoms of the Gupta Empire. Davaka was later absorbed by Kamarupa, which grew into a large kingdom that spanned from Karatoya river to near present [Sadiya](/wiki/Sadiya "Sadiya") and covered the entire Brahmaputra valley, [North Bengal](/wiki/North_Bengal "North Bengal"), parts of [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") and, at times [Purnea](/wiki/Purnea "Purnea") and parts of [West Bengal](/wiki/West_Bengal "West Bengal").[[163]](#cite_note-164)

Ruled by three dynasties [Varmanas](/wiki/Varman_dynasty "Varman dynasty") (c. 350–650 CE), [Mlechchha dynasty](/wiki/Mlechchha_dynasty "Mlechchha dynasty") (c. 655–900 CE) and [Kamarupa-Palas](/wiki/Pala_dynasty_(Kamarupa) "Pala dynasty (Kamarupa)") (c. 900–1100 CE), from their capitals in present-day [Guwahati](/wiki/Guwahati "Guwahati") ([Pragjyotishpura](/wiki/Pragjyotishpura "Pragjyotishpura")), Tezpur ([Haruppeswara](/wiki/Haruppeswara "Haruppeswara")) and [North Gauhati](/wiki/North_Gauhati "North Gauhati") ([Durjaya](/wiki/Durjaya "Durjaya")) respectively. All three dynasties claimed their descent from [Narakasura](/wiki/Narakasura "Narakasura").[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*] In the reign of the Varman king, [Bhaskar Varman](/wiki/Bhaskar_Varman "Bhaskar Varman") (c. 600–650 CE), the Chinese traveller [Xuanzang](/wiki/Xuanzang "Xuanzang") visited the [region](/wiki/Kamrup_region "Kamrup region") and recorded his travels. Later, after weakening and disintegration (after the Kamarupa-Palas), the Kamarupa tradition was somewhat extended until c. 1255 CE by the Lunar I (c. 1120–1185 CE) and Lunar II (c. 1155–1255 CE) dynasties.[[164]](#cite_note-165) The Kamarupa kingdom came to an end in the middle of the 13th century when the [Khen dynasty](/wiki/Khen_dynasty "Khen dynasty") under [Sandhya](/wiki/Sandhya_(ruler_of_Kamarupa) "Sandhya (ruler of Kamarupa)") of Kamarupanagara (North Guwahati), moved his capital to Kamatapur (North Bengal) after the invasion of Muslim Turks, and established the [Kamata kingdom](/wiki/Kamata_kingdom "Kamata kingdom").[[165]](#cite_note-166)

#### Pallava Empire

Main article: [Pallava Empire](/wiki/Pallava_Empire "Pallava Empire")

The [Pallavas](/wiki/Pallava "Pallava"), during the 4th to 9th centuries were, alongside the [Guptas](/wiki/Gupta "Gupta") of the [North](/wiki/North_India "North India"), great patronisers of Sanskrit development in the [South](/wiki/South_India "South India") of the Indian subcontinent. The Pallava reign saw the first Sanskrit inscriptions in a script called [Grantha](/wiki/Grantha_script "Grantha script").[[166]](#cite_note-167) Early Pallavas had different connexions to [Southeast Asian](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia") countries. The Pallavas used Dravidian architecture to build some very important Hindu temples and academies in [Mamallapuram](/wiki/Mamallapuram "Mamallapuram"), [Kanchipuram](/wiki/Kanchipuram "Kanchipuram") and other places; their rule saw the rise of great poets. The practice of dedicating temples to different deities came into vogue followed by fine artistic [temple architecture](/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture "Hindu temple architecture") and sculpture style of [Vastu Shastra](/wiki/Vastu_Shastra "Vastu Shastra").[[167]](#cite_note-168)

Pallavas reached the height of power during the reign of [Mahendravarman I](/wiki/Mahendravarman_I "Mahendravarman I") (571–630 CE) and [Narasimhavarman I](/wiki/Narasimhavarman_I "Narasimhavarman I") (630–668 CE) and dominated the [Telugu](/wiki/Telugu_people "Telugu people") and northern parts of the [Tamil](/wiki/Ancient_Tamil_country "Ancient Tamil country") region until the end of the 9th century.[[168]](#cite_note-169)

#### Kadamba Empire

Main article: [Kadamba Empire](/wiki/Kadamba_Empire "Kadamba Empire")

Kadambas originated from [Karnataka](/wiki/Karnataka "Karnataka"), was founded by [Mayurasharma](/wiki/Mayurasharma "Mayurasharma") in 345 CE which at later times showed the potential of developing into imperial proportions. King Mayurasharma defeated the armies of [Pallavas of Kanchi](/wiki/Pallavas_of_Kanchi "Pallavas of Kanchi") possibly with help of some native tribes. The Kadamba fame reached its peak during the rule of [Kakusthavarma](/wiki/Kakusthavarma "Kakusthavarma"), a notable ruler with whom the kings of [Gupta Dynasty](/wiki/Gupta_Dynasty "Gupta Dynasty") of northern India cultivated marital alliances. The Kadambas were contemporaries of the [Western Ganga Dynasty](/wiki/Western_Ganga_Dynasty "Western Ganga Dynasty") and together they formed the earliest native kingdoms to rule the land with absolute autonomy. The dynasty later continued to rule as a feudatory of larger Kannada empires, the [Chalukya](/wiki/Chalukya "Chalukya") and the [Rashtrakuta](/wiki/Rashtrakuta "Rashtrakuta") empires, for over five hundred years during which time they branched into minor dynasties ([Kadambas of Goa](/wiki/Kadambas_of_Goa "Kadambas of Goa"), [Kadambas of Halasi](/wiki/Kadambas_of_Halasi "Kadambas of Halasi") and [Kadambas of Hangal](/wiki/Kadambas_of_Hangal "Kadambas of Hangal")).

#### Empire of Harsha

Main articles: [Harsha](/wiki/Harsha "Harsha") and [Pushyabhuti dynasty](/wiki/Pushyabhuti_dynasty "Pushyabhuti dynasty")

[Harsha](/wiki/Harsha "Harsha") ruled northern India from 606 to 647 CE. He was the son of [Prabhakarvardhana](/wiki/Prabhakarvardhana "Prabhakarvardhana") and the younger brother of [Rajyavardhana](/wiki/Rajyavardhana "Rajyavardhana"), who were members of the [Vardhana dynasty](/wiki/Vardhana_dynasty "Vardhana dynasty") and ruled [Thanesar](/wiki/Thanesar "Thanesar"), in present-day [Haryana](/wiki/Haryana "Haryana").

After the downfall of the prior [Gupta Empire](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") in the middle of the 6th century, [North India](/wiki/North_India "North India") reverted to smaller republics and monarchical states. The power vacuum resulted in the rise of the Vardhanas of Thanesar, who began uniting the republics and monarchies from the Punjab to central India. After the death of Harsha's father and brother, representatives of the empire crowned Harsha emperor in April 606 CE, giving him the title of Maharaja.[[170]](#cite_note-171) At the peak, his Empire covered much of North and Northwestern India, extended East until [Kamarupa](/wiki/Kamarupa "Kamarupa"), and South until [Narmada River](/wiki/Narmada_River "Narmada River"); and eventually made [Kannauj](/wiki/Kannauj "Kannauj") (in present [Uttar Pradesh](/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh "Uttar Pradesh")) his capital, and ruled until 647 CE.[[171]](#cite_note-Historic_Places_p.507-172)

The peace and prosperity that prevailed made his court a centre of cosmopolitanism, attracting scholars, artists and religious visitors.[[171]](#cite_note-Historic_Places_p.507-172) During this time, Harsha converted to Buddhism from [Surya](/wiki/Surya "Surya") worship.[[172]](#cite_note-173) The Chinese traveller [Xuanzang](/wiki/Xuanzang "Xuanzang") visited the court of Harsha and wrote a very favourable account of him, praising his justice and generosity.[[171]](#cite_note-Historic_Places_p.507-172) His biography *[Harshacharita](/wiki/Harshacharita "Harshacharita")* ("Deeds of Harsha") written by Sanskrit poet [Banabhatta](/wiki/Banabhatta "Banabhatta"), describes his association with Thanesar and the palace with a two-storied *Dhavalagriha* (White Mansion).[[173]](#cite_note-174)[[174]](#cite_note-175)

## Early medieval period (c. 650 – 1200)

Main articles: [Medieval India](/wiki/Medieval_India "Medieval India"), [Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent "Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent"), and [Tripartite Struggle](/wiki/Tripartite_Struggle "Tripartite Struggle")

Early [medieval India](/wiki/Medieval_India "Medieval India") began after the end of the [Gupta Empire](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") in the 6th century CE.[[127]](#cite_note-stein-128) This period also covers the "Late Classical Age" of Hinduism, which began after the collapse of the [Empire of Harsha](/wiki/Empire_of_Harsha "Empire of Harsha") in the 7th century,[[175]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200441-176) and ended in the 13th century with the rise of the [Delhi Sultanate](/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate "Delhi Sultanate") in Northern India;[[176]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200443-177) the beginning of Imperial [Kannauj](/wiki/Kannauj "Kannauj"), leading to the [Tripartite struggle](/wiki/Tripartite_struggle "Tripartite struggle"); and the end of the [Later Cholas](/wiki/Later_Cholas "Later Cholas") with the death of [Rajendra Chola III](/wiki/Rajendra_Chola_III "Rajendra Chola III") in 1279 in Southern India; however some aspects of the Classical period continued until the fall of the [Vijayanagara Empire](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire") in the south around the 17th century.

From the fifth century to the thirteenth, [Śrauta](/wiki/%C5%9Arauta "Śrauta") sacrifices declined, and support for [Shaivism](/wiki/Shaivism "Shaivism"), [Vaishnavism](/wiki/Vaishnavism "Vaishnavism") and [Shaktism](/wiki/Shaktism "Shaktism") expanded in royal courts, while the support for Buddhism declined.[[177]](#cite_note-178) Lack of appeal among the rural masses, who instead embraced Brahmanical [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") formed in the [Hindu synthesis](/wiki/Hindu_synthesis "Hindu synthesis"), and dwindling financial support from trading communities and royal elites, were major factors in the decline of Buddhism.[[178]](#cite_note-179)

In the 7th century, [Kumārila Bhaṭṭa](/wiki/Kum%C4%81rila_Bha%E1%B9%AD%E1%B9%ADa "Kumārila Bhaṭṭa") formulated his school of [Mimamsa](/wiki/Mimamsa "Mimamsa") philosophy and defended the position on Vedic rituals.[[179]](#cite_note-180)

From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties contested for control of northern India: the [Gurjara Pratiharas](/wiki/Gurjara_Pratihara "Gurjara Pratihara") of Malwa, the [Palas](/wiki/Pala_Empire "Pala Empire") of Bengal, and the [Rashtrakutas](/wiki/Rashtrakuta_dynasty "Rashtrakuta dynasty") of the Deccan. The [Sena dynasty](/wiki/Sena_dynasty "Sena dynasty") would later assume control of the Pala Empire; the Gurjara Pratiharas fragmented into various states, notably the Kingdom of Malwa, the [Kingdom of Bundelkhand](/w/index.php?title=Chandelas_of_Bundelkhand&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chandelas of Bundelkhand (page does not exist)"), the [Kingdom of Dahala](/wiki/Kalachuris_of_Tripuri "Kalachuris of Tripuri"), the [Tomaras](/wiki/Tomaras "Tomaras") of [Haryana](/wiki/Haryana "Haryana"), and the [Kingdom of Sambhar](/wiki/Chahamanas_of_Shakambhari "Chahamanas of Shakambhari"), these states were some of the earliest [Rajput kingdoms](/wiki/List_of_Rajput_dynasties_and_states "List of Rajput dynasties and states");[[180]](#cite_note-181) while the Rashtrakutas were annexed by the [Western Chalukyas](/wiki/Western_Chalukyas "Western Chalukyas").[[181]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath198093-182) During this period, the [Chaulukya dynasty](/wiki/Chaulukya_dynasty "Chaulukya dynasty") emerged; the Chaulukyas constructed the [Dilwara Temples](/wiki/Dilwara_Temples "Dilwara Temples"), [Modhera Sun Temple](/wiki/Sun_Temple,_Modhera "Sun Temple, Modhera"), [Rani ki vav](/wiki/Rani_ki_vav "Rani ki vav")[[182]](#cite_note-183) in the style of [Māru-Gurjara architecture](/wiki/M%C4%81ru-Gurjara_architecture "Māru-Gurjara architecture"), and their capital Anhilwara (modern [Patan, Gujarat](/wiki/Patan,_Gujarat "Patan, Gujarat")) was one of the largest cities in the Indian subcontinent, with the population estimated at 100,000 in c. 1000. Patan's rise also marked the revival of Jainism in Gujarat during the times of [Hemchandracharya](/wiki/Hemchandracharya "Hemchandracharya"). It became renowned for its collection of ancient Jain manuscripts and an important centre of Jain learning,[[183]](#cite_note-184) which drew the admiration of many scholars. [British](/wiki/British_people "British people") [Indologist](/wiki/Indologist "Indologist") and [Sanskritist](/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit") Peter Peterson described the collection as follows:

> *I know of no town in India and only a few in the world which can boast of so great a store documents of venerable antiquity. They would be the pride and jealously guarded treasure of any University Library in Europe.*[[184]](#cite_note-185)

The [Chola Empire](/wiki/Chola_Empire "Chola Empire") emerged as a major power during the reign of [Raja Raja Chola I](/wiki/Raja_Raja_Chola_I "Raja Raja Chola I") and [Rajendra Chola I](/wiki/Rajendra_Chola_I "Rajendra Chola I") who successfully [invaded parts of Southeast Asia](/wiki/South-East_Asia_campaign_of_Rajendra_Chola_I "South-East Asia campaign of Rajendra Chola I") and [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Chola_occupation_of_Sri_Lanka_(993-1077) "Chola occupation of Sri Lanka (993-1077)") in the 11th century.[[185]](#cite_note-The_Dancing_Girl_p._129-186) [Lalitaditya Muktapida](/wiki/Lalitaditya_Muktapida "Lalitaditya Muktapida") (r. 724–760) was an emperor of the Kashmiri [Karkoṭa dynasty](/wiki/Karko%E1%B9%ADa_dynasty "Karkoṭa dynasty"), which exercised influence in northwestern India from 625 until 1003, and was followed by [Lohara dynasty](/wiki/Lohara_dynasty "Lohara dynasty"). [Kalhana](/wiki/Kalhana "Kalhana") in his [Rajatarangini](/wiki/Rajatarangini "Rajatarangini") credits king Lalitaditya with leading an aggressive military campaign in Northern India and Central Asia.[[186]](#cite_note-187)[[187]](#cite_note-188)[[188]](#cite_note-189)

The [Hindu Shahi](/wiki/Hindu_Shahi "Hindu Shahi") dynasty ruled portions of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and Kashmir from the mid-7th century to the early 11th century. While in Odisha, the [Eastern Ganga Empire](/wiki/Eastern_Ganga_dynasty "Eastern Ganga dynasty") rose to power; noted for the advancement of [Hindu architecture](/wiki/Hindu_architecture "Hindu architecture"), most notable being [Jagannath Temple](/wiki/Jagannath_Temple,_Puri "Jagannath Temple, Puri") and [Konark Sun Temple](/wiki/Konark_Sun_Temple "Konark Sun Temple"), as well as being patrons of art and literature.

* [Martand Sun Temple](/wiki/Martand_Sun_Temple "Martand Sun Temple") Central shrine, dedicated to the deity [Surya](/wiki/Surya "Surya"), and built by the third ruler of the [Karkota dynasty](/wiki/Karko%E1%B9%ADa_Empire "Karkoṭa Empire"), [Lalitaditya Muktapida](/wiki/Lalitaditya_Muktapida "Lalitaditya Muktapida"), in the 8th century
* [Konark Sun Temple](/wiki/Konark_Sun_Temple "Konark Sun Temple") at [Konark](/wiki/Konark "Konark"), [Orissa](/wiki/Orissa,_India "Orissa, India"), built by [Narasimhadeva I](/wiki/Narasimhadeva_I "Narasimhadeva I") (1238–1264) of the Eastern Ganga dynasty
* [Kandariya Mahadeva Temple](/wiki/Kandariya_Mahadeva_Temple "Kandariya Mahadeva Temple") in the [Khajuraho complex](/wiki/Khajuraho_Group_of_Monuments "Khajuraho Group of Monuments") was built by the [Chandelas](/wiki/Chandela "Chandela")
* [Jagannath Temple](/wiki/Jagannath_Temple,_Puri "Jagannath Temple, Puri") at [Puri](/wiki/Puri "Puri"), built by [Anantavarman Chodaganga Deva](/wiki/Anantavarman_Chodaganga_Deva "Anantavarman Chodaganga Deva") of the Eastern Ganga dynasty

### Later Gupta dynasty

Main article: [Later Gupta dynasty](/wiki/Later_Gupta_dynasty "Later Gupta dynasty")

The Later Gupta dynasty ruled the [Magadha](/wiki/Magadha_(Mahajanapada) "Magadha (Mahajanapada)") region in eastern India between the 6th and 7th centuries AD. The Later Guptas succeeded the [imperial Guptas](/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") as the rulers of Magadha, but there is no evidence connecting the two dynasties; these appear to be two distinct families.[[189]](#cite_note-190) The Later Guptas are so-called because the names of their rulers ended with the suffix "-gupta", which they might have adopted to portray themselves as the legitimate successors of the imperial Guptas.[[190]](#cite_note-191)

### Chalukya Empire

Main article: [Chalukya dynasty](/wiki/Chalukya_dynasty "Chalukya dynasty")

The [Chalukya Empire](/wiki/Chalukya_dynasty "Chalukya dynasty") ruled large parts of southern and [central India](/wiki/Central_India "Central India") between the 6th and the 12th centuries, as three related yet individual dynasties. The earliest dynasty, known as the "Badami Chalukyas", ruled from Vatapi (modern [Badami](/wiki/Badami "Badami")) from the middle of the 6th century. The Badami Chalukyas began to assert their independence at the decline of the [Kadamba](/wiki/Kadamba_Dynasty "Kadamba Dynasty") kingdom of [Banavasi](/wiki/Banavasi "Banavasi") and rapidly rose to prominence during the reign of [Pulakeshin II](/wiki/Pulakeshin_II "Pulakeshin II"). The rule of the Chalukyas marks an important milestone in the history of South India and a golden age in the history of [Karnataka](/wiki/Karnataka "Karnataka"). The political atmosphere in South India shifted from smaller kingdoms to large empires with the ascendancy of Badami Chalukyas. A Southern India-based kingdom took control and consolidated the entire region between the [Kaveri](/wiki/Kaveri "Kaveri") and the [Narmada Rivers](/wiki/Narmada_River "Narmada River"). The rise of this empire saw the birth of efficient administration, overseas trade and commerce and the development of new style of architecture called "Chalukyan architecture". The Chalukya dynasty ruled parts of southern and central India from Badami in Karnataka between 550 and 750, and then again from [Kalyani](/wiki/Basavakalyan "Basavakalyan") between 970 and 1190.

* Galaganatha Temple at [Pattadakal complex](/wiki/Pattadakal "Pattadakal") ([UNESCO World Heritage](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage "UNESCO World Heritage")) is an example of [Badami Chalukya architecture](/wiki/Badami_Chalukya_architecture "Badami Chalukya architecture")
* [Bhutanatha temple complex](/wiki/Bhutanatha_group_of_temples,_Badami "Bhutanatha group of temples, Badami") at [Badami](/wiki/Badami "Badami"), next to a [waterfall](/wiki/Waterfall "Waterfall"), during the monsoon.
* [Vishnu](/wiki/Vishnu "Vishnu") image inside the [Badami Cave Temple Complex](/wiki/Badami_cave_temples "Badami cave temples"). Example of [Indian rock-cut architecture](/wiki/Indian_rock-cut_architecture "Indian rock-cut architecture")
* 8th century Durga temple exterior view at [Aihole complex](/wiki/Aihole "Aihole"). It includes Hindu, Buddhist and Jain temples and monuments

### Rashtrakuta Empire

Main article: [Rashtrakuta Empire](/wiki/Rashtrakuta_Empire "Rashtrakuta Empire")

Founded by [Dantidurga](/wiki/Dantidurga "Dantidurga") around 753,[[191]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar2003334-192) the Rashtrakuta Empire ruled from its capital at [Manyakheta](/wiki/Manyakheta "Manyakheta") for almost two centuries.[[192]](#cite_note-Chandra-193) At its peak, the Rashtrakutas ruled from the [Ganges-Yamuna Doab](/wiki/Ganges-Yamuna_Doab "Ganges-Yamuna Doab") in the north to [Cape Comorin](/wiki/Cape_Comorin "Cape Comorin") in the south, a fruitful time of architectural and literary achievements.[[193]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath198083,_85,_97-194)[[194]](#cite_note-195)

The early rulers of this dynasty were Hindu, but the later rulers were strongly influenced by Jainism.[[195]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999380-196) [Govinda III](/wiki/Govinda_III "Govinda III") and [Amoghavarsha](/wiki/Amoghavarsha "Amoghavarsha") were the most famous of the long line of able administrators produced by the dynasty. Amoghavarsha was also an author and wrote [Kavirajamarga](/wiki/Kavirajamarga "Kavirajamarga"), the earliest known Kannada work on poetics.[[192]](#cite_note-Chandra-193)[[196]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999380–381-197) Architecture reached a milestone in the Dravidian style, the finest example of which is seen in the Kailasanath Temple at Ellora. Other important contributions are the Kashivishvanatha temple and the Jain Narayana temple at [Pattadakal](/wiki/Pattadakal "Pattadakal") in Karnataka.

The Arab traveller Suleiman described the Rashtrakuta Empire as one of the four great Empires of the world.[[197]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaniélou2003170-198) The Rashtrakuta period marked the beginning of the golden age of southern Indian mathematics. The great south Indian mathematician [Mahāvīra](/wiki/Mah%C4%81v%C4%ABra_(mathematician) "Mahāvīra (mathematician)") had a huge impact on medieval south Indian mathematicians.[[198]](#cite_note-199) The Rashtrakuta rulers also patronised men of letters in a variety of languages.[[192]](#cite_note-Chandra-193)

* [Kailasa temple](/wiki/Kailasa_Temple,_Ellora "Kailasa Temple, Ellora"), is one of the largest [rock-cut](/wiki/Indian_rock-cut_architecture "Indian rock-cut architecture") ancient [Hindu temples](/wiki/Hindu_temple "Hindu temple") located in [Ellora](/wiki/Ellora_Caves "Ellora Caves")
* [Shikhara](/wiki/Shikhara "Shikhara") of Indra Sabha at Ellora Caves
* Statue of the [Buddha](/wiki/Buddha "Buddha") seated. A part of the Carpenter's cave (Buddhist Cave 10).
* [Jain](/wiki/Jain "Jain") [Tirthankara](/wiki/Tirthankara "Tirthankara") [Mahavira](/wiki/Mahavira "Mahavira") with [Yaksha](/wiki/Yaksha "Yaksha") Matanga and [Yakshi](/wiki/Yakshi "Yakshi") Siddhaiki at Ellora Caves

### Gurjara-Pratihara Empire

Main article: [Gurjara-Pratihara Empire](/wiki/Gurjara-Pratihara_Empire "Gurjara-Pratihara Empire")

The Gurjara-Pratiharas were instrumental in containing Arab armies moving east of the [Indus River](/wiki/Indus_River "Indus River"). [Nagabhata I](/wiki/Nagabhata_I "Nagabhata I") defeated the Arab army under Junaid and Tamin during the [Umayyad campaigns in India](/wiki/Umayyad_campaigns_in_India "Umayyad campaigns in India").[[199]](#cite_note-200) Under [Nagabhata II](/wiki/Nagabhata_II "Nagabhata II"), the Gurjara-Pratiharas became the most powerful dynasty in northern India. He was succeeded by his son [Ramabhadra](/wiki/Ramabhadra "Ramabhadra"), who ruled briefly before being succeeded by his son, [Mihira Bhoja](/wiki/Mihira_Bhoja "Mihira Bhoja"). Under Bhoja and his successor [Mahendrapala I](/wiki/Mahendrapala_I "Mahendrapala I"), the Pratihara Empire reached its peak of prosperity and power. By the time of Mahendrapala, its territory stretched from the border of [Sindh](/wiki/Sindh "Sindh") in the west to Bihar in the east and from the Himalayas in the north to around the [Narmada River](/wiki/Narmada_River "Narmada River") in the south.[[200]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari2007204-201) The expansion triggered a [tripartite power struggle](/wiki/Tripartite_Struggle "Tripartite Struggle") with the [Rashtrakuta](/wiki/Rashtrakuta "Rashtrakuta") and [Pala](/wiki/Pala_Empire "Pala Empire") empires for control of the Indian subcontinent.

By the end of the 10th century, several feudatories of the empire took advantage of the temporary weakness of the Gurjara-Pratiharas to declare their independence, notably the Kingdom of Malwa, the [Kingdom of Bundelkhand](/w/index.php?title=Chandelas_of_Bundelkhand&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chandelas of Bundelkhand (page does not exist)"), the [Tomaras](/wiki/Tomaras "Tomaras") of [Haryana](/wiki/Haryana "Haryana"), and the [Kingdom of Sambhar](/wiki/Chahamanas_of_Shakambhari "Chahamanas of Shakambhari")[[201]](#cite_note-202) and the [Kingdom of Dahala](/wiki/Kalachuris_of_Tripuri "Kalachuris of Tripuri").[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

* One of the four entrances of the [Teli ka Mandir](/wiki/Teli_ka_Mandir "Teli ka Mandir"), built by the Pratihara emperor [Mihira Bhoja](/wiki/Mihira_Bhoja "Mihira Bhoja").[[202]](#cite_note-203)
* Sculptures near Teli ka Mandir, [Gwalior Fort](/wiki/Gwalior_Fort "Gwalior Fort")
* Jainism-related cave monuments and statues carved into the rock face inside [Siddhachal Caves](/wiki/Siddhachal_Caves "Siddhachal Caves"), Gwalior Fort
* Ghateshwara Mahadeva temple at [Baroli Temples complex](/wiki/Baroli_Temples "Baroli Temples"). Complex of eight temples, built by the Gurjara-Pratiharas, within a walled enclosure

### Gahadavala dynasty

Main article: [Gahadavala dynasty](/wiki/Gahadavala_dynasty "Gahadavala dynasty")

Gahadavala dynasty ruled parts of the present-day [Indian states](/wiki/Indian_states "Indian states") of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, during 11th and 12th centuries. Their capital was located at [Varanasi](/wiki/Varanasi "Varanasi").[[203]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENiyogi195938-204)

### Karnat dynasty

Main article: [Karnat dynasty](/wiki/Karnat_dynasty "Karnat dynasty")

In 1097 AD, the Karnat dynasty of Mithila emerged on the Bihar/Nepal border area and maintained capitals in [Darbhanga](/wiki/Darbhanga "Darbhanga") and [Simraongadh](/wiki/Simraungadh "Simraungadh"). The dynasty was established by [Nanyadeva](/wiki/Nanyadeva "Nanyadeva"), a military commander of Karnataka origin. Under this dynasty, the [Maithili](/wiki/Maithili_language "Maithili language") language started to develop with the first piece of Maithili literature, the [Varna Ratnakara](/wiki/Varna_Ratnakara "Varna Ratnakara") being produced in the 14th century by Jyotirishwar Thakur. The Karnats also carried out raids into [Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal"). They fell in 1324 following the invasion of [Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq](/wiki/Ghiyasuddin_Tughlaq "Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq").[[204]](#cite_note-205)[[205]](#cite_note-206)

### Pala Empire

Main article: [Pala Empire](/wiki/Pala_Empire "Pala Empire")

The Pala Empire was founded by [Gopala I](/wiki/Gopala_I "Gopala I").[[206]](#cite_note-207)[[207]](#cite_note-208)[[208]](#cite_note-209) It was ruled by a Buddhist dynasty from Bengal. The Palas reunified Bengal after the fall of [Shashanka](/wiki/Shashanka "Shashanka")'s [Gauda Kingdom](/wiki/Gauda_Kingdom "Gauda Kingdom").[[209]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004112,_119-210)

The Palas were followers of the [Mahayana](/wiki/Mahayana "Mahayana") and [Tantric](/wiki/Tantric_Buddhism "Tantric Buddhism") schools of Buddhism,[[210]](#cite_note-211) they also patronised [Shaivism](/wiki/Shaivism "Shaivism") and [Vaishnavism](/wiki/Vaishnavism "Vaishnavism").[[211]](#cite_note-ChandraPala-212) The empire reached its peak under [Dharmapala](/wiki/Dharmapala_(emperor) "Dharmapala (emperor)") and [Devapala](/wiki/Devapala_(Pala_dynasty) "Devapala (Pala dynasty)"). Dharmapala is believed to have conquered Kanauj and extended his sway up to the farthest limits of India in the north-west.[[211]](#cite_note-ChandraPala-212)

The Pala Empire can be considered as the golden era of Bengal.[[212]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999278-213) Dharmapala founded the [Vikramashila](/wiki/Vikramashila "Vikramashila") and revived Nalanda,[[211]](#cite_note-ChandraPala-212) considered one of the first great universities in recorded history. Nalanda reached its height under the patronage of the Pala Empire.[[212]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen1999278-213)[[213]](#cite_note-214) The Palas also built many [viharas](/wiki/Vihara "Vihara"). They maintained close cultural and commercial ties with countries of Southeast Asia and [Tibet](/wiki/Tibet "Tibet"). Sea trade added greatly to the prosperity of the Pala Empire.

### Cholas

Main articles: [Chola dynasty](/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty") and [Chola Empire](/wiki/Chola_Empire "Chola Empire")

Medieval Cholas rose to prominence during the middle of the 9th century and established the greatest empire South India had seen.[[214]](#cite_note-215) They successfully united the South India under their rule and through their naval strength extended their influence in the Southeast Asian countries such as Srivijaya.[[185]](#cite_note-The_Dancing_Girl_p._129-186) Under [Rajaraja Chola I](/wiki/Rajaraja_Chola_I "Rajaraja Chola I") and his successors [Rajendra Chola I](/wiki/Rajendra_Chola_I "Rajendra Chola I"), [Rajadhiraja Chola](/wiki/Rajadhiraja_Chola "Rajadhiraja Chola"), [Virarajendra Chola](/wiki/Virarajendra_Chola "Virarajendra Chola") and [Kulothunga Chola I](/wiki/Kulothunga_Chola_I "Kulothunga Chola I") the dynasty became a military, economic and cultural power in South Asia and South-East Asia.[[215]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004116-216)[[216]](#cite_note-217) Rajendra Chola I's navies occupied the sea coasts from Burma to Vietnam,[[217]](#cite_note-218) the [Andaman and Nicobar Islands](/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands "Andaman and Nicobar Islands"), the [Lakshadweep](/wiki/Lakshadweep "Lakshadweep") (Laccadive) islands, [Sumatra](/wiki/Sumatra "Sumatra"), and the [Malay Peninsula](/wiki/Malay_Peninsula "Malay Peninsula"). The power of the new empire was proclaimed to the eastern world by the expedition to the [Ganges](/wiki/Ganges "Ganges") which Rajendra Chola I undertook and by the occupation of cities of the maritime empire of [Srivijaya](/wiki/Srivijaya "Srivijaya") in Southeast Asia, as well as by the repeated embassies to China.[[218]](#cite_note-219)

They dominated the political affairs of Sri Lanka for over two centuries through repeated invasions and occupation. They also had continuing trade contacts with the Arabs and the Chinese empire.[[219]](#cite_note-220) Rajaraja Chola I and his son Rajendra Chola I gave political unity to the whole of Southern India and established the Chola Empire as a respected sea power.[[220]](#cite_note-221) Under the Cholas, the South India reached new heights of excellence in art, religion and literature. In all of these spheres, the Chola period marked the culmination of movements that had begun in an earlier age under the Pallavas. Monumental architecture in the form of majestic temples and sculpture in stone and bronze reached a finesse never before achieved in India.[[221]](#cite_note-222)

### Western Chalukya Empire

Main article: [Western Chalukya Empire](/wiki/Western_Chalukya_Empire "Western Chalukya Empire")

The Western Chalukya Empire ruled most of the [western Deccan](/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau"), South India, between the 10th and 12th centuries.[[223]](#cite_note-Medieval_India_p.24-224) Vast areas between the [Narmada River](/wiki/Narmada_River "Narmada River") in the north and [Kaveri River](/wiki/Kaveri_River "Kaveri River") in the south came under Chalukya control.[[223]](#cite_note-Medieval_India_p.24-224) During this period the other major ruling families of the Deccan, the [Hoysalas](/wiki/Hoysalas "Hoysalas"), the [Seuna Yadavas of Devagiri](/wiki/Seuna_Yadavas_of_Devagiri "Seuna Yadavas of Devagiri"), the [Kakatiya dynasty](/wiki/Kakatiya_dynasty "Kakatiya dynasty") and the [Southern Kalachuris](/wiki/Kalachuris_of_Kalyani "Kalachuris of Kalyani"), were subordinates of the Western Chalukyas and gained their independence only when the power of the Chalukya waned during the latter half of the 12th century.[[224]](#cite_note-225)

The Western Chalukyas developed an architectural style known today as a transitional style, an architectural link between the style of the early Chalukya dynasty and that of the later Hoysala empire. Most of its monuments are in the districts bordering the Tungabhadra River in central Karnataka. Well known examples are the [Kasivisvesvara Temple](/wiki/Kasivisvesvara_Temple "Kasivisvesvara Temple") at [Lakkundi](/wiki/Lakkundi "Lakkundi"), the [Mallikarjuna Temple](/wiki/Mallikarjuna_Temple,_Kuruvatti "Mallikarjuna Temple, Kuruvatti") at Kuruvatti, the [Kallesvara Temple](/wiki/Kalleshvara_Temple,_Bagali "Kalleshvara Temple, Bagali") at Bagali, [Siddhesvara Temple](/wiki/Siddhesvara_Temple "Siddhesvara Temple") at Haveri, and the [Mahadeva Temple](/wiki/Mahadeva_Temple_(Itagi) "Mahadeva Temple (Itagi)") at Itagi.[[225]](#cite_note-226) This was an important period in the development of fine arts in Southern India, especially in literature as the Western Chalukya kings encouraged writers in the native language of [Kannada](/wiki/Kannada_language "Kannada language"), and Sanskrit like the philosopher and statesman [Basava](/wiki/Basava "Basava") and the great mathematician [Bhāskara II](/wiki/Bh%C4%81skara_II "Bhāskara II").[[226]](#cite_note-227)[[227]](#cite_note-228)
