## Late medieval period (c. 1200 – 1526)

Main article: [Medieval India](/wiki/Medieval_India "Medieval India")

See also: [Muslim kingdoms in the Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Muslim_kingdoms_in_the_Indian_subcontinent "Muslim kingdoms in the Indian subcontinent")

The late medieval period is marked by repeated invasions by Muslim Central Asian nomadic clans,[[228]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200647-229)[[229]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf20066-230) the rule of the Delhi Sultanate, and by the growth of other states, built upon military technology of the sultanate.[[230]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200653-231)

### Delhi Sultanate

Main article: [Delhi Sultanate](/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate "Delhi Sultanate")

The Delhi Sultanate was a series of successive Islamic states based in Delhi, ruled by several dynasties of varying origins. The polity ruled over large parts of the Indian subcontinent from the 13th to early 16th centuries.[[231]](#cite_note-delhi-232) The sultanate was founded in the 12th and 13th centuries by Central Asian Turks, who invaded parts of northern India and established the state atop former Hindu holdings.[[232]](#cite_note-233) The subsequent [Mamluk dynasty](/wiki/Mamluk_dynasty_(Delhi) "Mamluk dynasty (Delhi)") of Delhi managed to conquer large areas of northern India. The [Khalji dynasty](/wiki/Khalji_dynasty "Khalji dynasty") conquered much of central India while forcing the principal Hindu kingdoms of South India to become [vassal states](/wiki/Vassal_state "Vassal state").[[231]](#cite_note-delhi-232)

The sultanate ushered in a period of Indian cultural renaissance. The resulting "Indo-Muslim" fusion of cultures left lasting syncretic monuments in architecture, music, literature, religion, and clothing. It is surmised that the language of [Urdu](/wiki/Urdu "Urdu") was born during the period of the Delhi Sultanate. The sultanate was the only Indo-Islamic state to enthrone one of the few female rulers in India, [Razia Sultana](/wiki/Razia_Sultana "Razia Sultana") (r. 1236–1240).

While initially disruptive due to the passing of power from native Indian elites to Turkic Muslim elites, the Delhi Sultanate was responsible for integrating the Indian subcontinent into a growing world system, drawing India into a wider international network, which had a significant impact on Indian culture and society.[[233]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200650–52-234) However, the Delhi Sultanate also caused large-scale destruction and desecration of temples in the Indian subcontinent.[[234]](#cite_note-235)

The [Mongol invasions of India](/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_India "Mongol invasions of India") were successfully repelled by the Delhi Sultanate during the rule of [Alauddin Khalji](/wiki/Alauddin_Khalji "Alauddin Khalji"). A major factor in their success was their Turkic [Mamluk](/wiki/Mamluk "Mamluk") slave army, who were highly skilled in the same style of nomadic cavalry warfare as the Mongols. It is possible that the Mongol Empire may have expanded into India were it not for the Delhi Sultanate's role in repelling them.[[235]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200650–51-236) By repeatedly repulsing the Mongol raiders,[[236]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden200267-237) the sultanate saved India from the devastation waged on West and Central Asia. Soldiers from that region and learned men and administrators fleeing Mongol invasions of Iran migrated into the subcontinent, thereby creating a syncretic Indo-Islamic culture in the north.[[235]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200650–51-236)

A [Turco-Mongol](/wiki/Turco-Mongol "Turco-Mongol") conqueror from Central Asia, [Timur](/wiki/Timur "Timur") (Tamerlane), attacked the reigning sultan [Nasir-u Din Mehmud](/wiki/Mahmud_Shah_II "Mahmud Shah II") of the [Tughlaq dynasty](/wiki/Tughlaq_dynasty "Tughlaq dynasty") in Delhi.[[237]](#cite_note-238) The sultan's army was defeated on 17 December 1398. Timur entered Delhi and the city was sacked, destroyed, and left in ruins after Timur's army had killed and plundered for three days and nights. He ordered the whole city to be sacked except for the [sayyids](/wiki/Sayyid "Sayyid"), scholars, and the "other Muslims" (artists); 100,000 war prisoners were said to have been put to death in one day.[[238]](#cite_note-239) The sultanate suffered significantly from the sacking of Delhi. Though revived briefly under the [Sayyid](/wiki/Sayyid_dynasty "Sayyid dynasty") and [Lodi](/wiki/Lodi_dynasty "Lodi dynasty") dynasties, it was but a shadow of the former. Lodi rule lasted in Delhi until the defeat of the last sultan, [Ibrahim Khan Lodi](/wiki/Ibrahim_Khan_Lodi "Ibrahim Khan Lodi"), [in 1526](/wiki/First_Battle_of_Panipat "First Battle of Panipat") to the forces of [Babur](/wiki/Babur "Babur").[[239]](#cite_note-240)

* [Qutb Minar](/wiki/Qutb_Minar "Qutb Minar"), a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site"), whose construction was begun by [Qutb ud-Din Aibak](/wiki/Qutb_ud-Din_Aibak "Qutb ud-Din Aibak"), the first Sultan of Delhi.
* [Dargahs](/wiki/Dargah "Dargah") of [Sufi](/wiki/Suffism "Suffism")-saint [Nizamuddin Auliya](/wiki/Nizamuddin_Auliya "Nizamuddin Auliya"), and poet and musician [Amir Khusro](/wiki/Amir_Khusro "Amir Khusro") in Delhi.

### Vijayanagara Empire

Main article: [Vijayanagara Empire](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire")

The Vijayanagara Empire was established in 1336 by [Harihara I](/wiki/Harihara_I "Harihara I") and his brother [Bukka Raya I](/wiki/Bukka_Raya_I "Bukka Raya I") of [Sangama Dynasty](/wiki/Sangama_Dynasty "Sangama Dynasty"),[[240]](#cite_note-241) which originated as a political heir of the [Hoysala Empire](/wiki/Hoysala_Empire "Hoysala Empire"), [Kakatiya Empire](/wiki/Kakatiya_dynasty "Kakatiya dynasty"),[[241]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200528–29-242) and the [Pandyan Empire](/wiki/Pandyan_Empire "Pandyan Empire").[[242]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESastri2002239-243) The empire rose to prominence as a culmination of attempts by the south Indian powers to ward off [Islamic invasions](/wiki/Islamic_invasions_of_India "Islamic invasions of India") by the end of the 13th century. It lasted until 1646, although its power declined after a major military defeat in 1565 by the combined armies of the [Deccan sultanates](/wiki/Deccan_sultanates "Deccan sultanates"). The empire is named after its capital city of [Vijayanagara](/wiki/Vijayanagara "Vijayanagara"), whose ruins surround present day [Hampi](/wiki/Hampi "Hampi"), now a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in Karnataka, India.[[243]](#cite_note-244)

In the first two decades after the founding of the empire, Harihara I gained control over most of the area south of the Tungabhadra river and earned the title of *Purvapaschima Samudradhishavara* ("master of the eastern and western seas"). By 1374 Bukka Raya I, successor to Harihara I, had defeated the chiefdom of [Arcot](/wiki/Arcot "Arcot"), the [Reddys](/wiki/Reddy "Reddy") of Kondavidu, and the [Sultan of Madurai](/wiki/Madurai_Sultanate "Madurai Sultanate") and had gained control over [Goa](/wiki/Goa "Goa") in the west and the Tungabhadra-Krishna [doab](/wiki/Doab "Doab") in the north.[[244]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath1980170–171-245)[[245]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESastri1955317-246)

[Harihara II](/wiki/Harihara_II "Harihara II"), the second son of Bukka Raya I, further consolidated the kingdom beyond the [Krishna River](/wiki/Krishna_River "Krishna River") and brought the whole of South India under the Vijayanagara umbrella.[[246]](#cite_note-247) The next ruler, [Deva Raya I](/wiki/Deva_Raya_I "Deva Raya I"), emerged successful against the [Gajapatis](/wiki/Gajapatis "Gajapatis") of Odisha and undertook important works of fortification and irrigation.[[247]](#cite_note-248) Italian traveller Niccolo de Conti wrote of him as the most powerful ruler of India.[[248]](#cite_note-249) [Deva Raya II](/wiki/Deva_Raya_II "Deva Raya II") succeeded to the throne in 1424 and was possibly the most capable of the Sangama Dynasty rulers.[[249]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESastri1955244-250) He quelled rebelling feudal lords as well as the [Zamorin](/wiki/Zamorin "Zamorin") of [Calicut](/wiki/History_of_Kozhikode "History of Kozhikode") and [Quilon](/wiki/Quilon "Quilon") in the south. He invaded the island of Sri Lanka and became overlord of the kings of [Burma](/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar") at [Pegu](/wiki/Pegu "Pegu") and [Tanasserim](/wiki/Tanintharyi_Division "Tanintharyi Division").[[250]](#cite_note-251)[[251]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath1980173-252)[[252]](#cite_note-253)

The Vijayanagara Emperors were tolerant of all religions and sects, as writings by foreign visitors show.[[253]](#cite_note-254) The kings used titles such as *Gobrahamana Pratipalanacharya* (*literally*, "protector of cows and Brahmins") and *Hindurayasuratrana* (*lit*, "upholder of Hindu faith") that testified to their intention of protecting Hinduism and yet were at the same time staunchly Islamicate in their court ceremonials and dress.[[254]](#cite_note-255) The empire's founders, Harihara I and Bukka Raya I, were devout [Shaivas](/wiki/Shaiva "Shaiva") (worshippers of [Shiva](/wiki/Shiva "Shiva")), but made grants to the [Vaishnava](/wiki/Vaishnava "Vaishnava") order of [Sringeri](/wiki/Sringeri "Sringeri") with [Vidyaranya](/wiki/Vidyaranya "Vidyaranya") as their patron saint, and designated *[Varaha](/wiki/Varaha "Varaha")* (an [avatar](/wiki/Avatar "Avatar") of Vishnu) as their emblem.[[255]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath1980188–189-256) Nobles from Central Asia's Timurid kingdoms also came to Vijayanagara.[[256]](#cite_note-257) The later [Saluva](/wiki/Saluva "Saluva") and [Tuluva](/wiki/Tuluva "Tuluva") kings were Vaishnava by faith, but worshipped at the feet of Lord Virupaksha (Shiva) at Hampi as well as Lord [Venkateshwara](/wiki/Venkateshwara "Venkateshwara") (Vishnu) at [Tirupati](/wiki/Tirumala_Venkateswara_Temple "Tirumala Venkateswara Temple").[[257]](#cite_note-258) A Sanskrit work, *Jambavati Kalyanam* by King Krishnadevaraya, called Lord Virupaksha *Karnata Rajya Raksha Mani* ("protective jewel of Karnata Empire").[[258]](#cite_note-259) The kings patronised the saints of the [dvaita](/wiki/Dvaita "Dvaita") order (philosophy of dualism) of [Madhvacharya](/wiki/Madhvacharya "Madhvacharya") at [Udupi](/wiki/Udupi "Udupi").[[259]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath1980189-260)

* Photograph of the ruins of the [Vijayanagara Empire](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire") at [Hampi](/wiki/Hampi "Hampi"), now a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1868[[260]](#cite_note-261)
* Gajashaala, or elephant's stable, was built by the Vijayanagar rulers for their [war elephants](/wiki/War_elephants "War elephants").[[261]](#cite_note-262)
* Vijayanagara marketplace at [Hampi](/wiki/Hampi "Hampi"), along with the sacred tank located on the side of Krishna temple.
* Stone temple car in Vitthala Temple at Hampi

The empire's legacy includes many monuments spread over South India, the best known of which is the group at Hampi. The previous temple building traditions in South India came together in the Vijayanagara Architecture style. The mingling of all faiths and vernaculars inspired architectural innovation of Hindu temple construction. South Indian mathematics flourished under the protection of the Vijayanagara Empire in Kerala. The south Indian mathematician [Madhava of Sangamagrama](/wiki/Madhava_of_Sangamagrama "Madhava of Sangamagrama") founded the famous [Kerala School of Astronomy and Mathematics](/wiki/Kerala_School_of_Astronomy_and_Mathematics "Kerala School of Astronomy and Mathematics") in the 14th century which produced a lot of great south Indian mathematicians like [Parameshvara](/wiki/Parameshvara "Parameshvara"), [Nilakantha Somayaji](/wiki/Nilakantha_Somayaji "Nilakantha Somayaji") and [Jyeṣṭhadeva](/wiki/Jye%E1%B9%A3%E1%B9%ADhadeva "Jyeṣṭhadeva").[[262]](#cite_note-263) Efficient administration and vigorous overseas trade brought new technologies such as water management systems for irrigation.[[263]](#cite_note-264) The empire's patronage enabled fine arts and literature to reach new heights in Kannada, Telugu, Tamil, and Sanskrit, while Carnatic music evolved into its current form.[[264]](#cite_note-265)

Vijayanagara went into decline after the defeat in the [Battle of Talikota](/wiki/Battle_of_Talikota "Battle of Talikota") (1565). After the death of [Aliya Rama Raya](/wiki/Aliya_Rama_Raya "Aliya Rama Raya") in the Battle of Talikota, [Tirumala Deva Raya](/wiki/Tirumala_Deva_Raya "Tirumala Deva Raya") started the [Aravidu dynasty](/wiki/Aravidu_dynasty "Aravidu dynasty"), moved and founded a new capital of Penukonda to replace the destroyed Hampi, and attempted to reconstitute the remains of Vijayanagara Empire.[[265]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton2005100–101-266) Tirumala abdicated in 1572, dividing the remains of his kingdom to his three sons, and pursued a religious life until his death in 1578. The Aravidu dynasty successors ruled the region but the empire collapsed in 1614, and the final remains ended in 1646, from continued wars with the Bijapur sultanate and others.[[266]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath1980185-267)[[267]](#cite_note-268)[[268]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton2005101–115-269) During this period, more kingdoms in South India became independent and separate from Vijayanagara. These include the [Mysore Kingdom](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mysore "Kingdom of Mysore"), [Keladi Nayaka](/wiki/Keladi_Nayaka "Keladi Nayaka"), [Nayaks of Madurai](/wiki/Madurai_Nayak_Dynasty "Madurai Nayak Dynasty"), [Nayaks of Tanjore](/wiki/Thanjavur_Nayaks "Thanjavur Nayaks"), [Nayakas of Chitradurga](/wiki/Nayakas_of_Chitradurga "Nayakas of Chitradurga") and [Nayak Kingdom of Gingee](/wiki/Nayaks_of_Gingee "Nayaks of Gingee") – all of which declared independence and went on to have a significant impact on the history of South India in the coming centuries.[[266]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKamath1980185-267)

### Other kingdoms

Main articles: [Guhila dynasty](/wiki/Guhila_dynasty "Guhila dynasty") and [Kingdom of Mewar](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mewar "Kingdom of Mewar")

* [Vijaya Stambha](/wiki/Vijaya_Stambha "Vijaya Stambha") (Tower of Victory).
* Temple inside [Chittorgarh fort](/wiki/Chittorgarh_fort "Chittorgarh fort")
* Man Singh (Manasimha) palace at the [Gwalior fort](/wiki/Gwalior_fort "Gwalior fort")
* Chinese manuscript *Tribute Giraffe with Attendant*, depicting a giraffe presented by Bengali envoys in the name of Sultan [Saifuddin Hamza Shah](/wiki/Saifuddin_Hamza_Shah "Saifuddin Hamza Shah") of Bengal to the [Yongle Emperor](/wiki/Yongle_Emperor "Yongle Emperor") of [Ming China](/wiki/Ming_China "Ming China")
* Mahmud Gawan Madrasa was built by Mahmud Gawan, the Wazir of the Bahmani Sultanate as the centre of religious as well as secular education

For two and a half centuries from the mid-13th century, politics in Northern India was dominated by the [Delhi Sultanate](/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate "Delhi Sultanate"), and in Southern India by the Vijayanagar Empire. However, there were other regional powers present as well. After fall of Pala Empire, the [Chero dynasty](/wiki/Chero_dynasty "Chero dynasty") ruled much of Eastern [Uttar Pradesh](/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh "Uttar Pradesh"), [Bihar](/wiki/Bihar "Bihar") and [Jharkhand](/wiki/Jharkhand "Jharkhand") from the 12th to the 18th centuries.[[269]](#cite_note-270)[[270]](#cite_note-271)[[271]](#cite_note-272) The [Reddy dynasty](/wiki/Reddy_dynasty "Reddy dynasty") successfully defeated the Delhi Sultanate and extended their rule from [Cuttack](/wiki/Cuttack "Cuttack") in the north to [Kanchi](/wiki/Kanchi "Kanchi") in the south, eventually being absorbed into the expanding Vijayanagara Empire.[[272]](#cite_note-273)

In the north, the [Rajput kingdoms](/wiki/Rajput_kingdoms "Rajput kingdoms") remained the dominant force in Western and Central India. The [Mewar dynasty](/wiki/Mewar_dynasty "Mewar dynasty") under [Maharana Hammir](/wiki/Maharana_Hammir "Maharana Hammir") defeated and captured [Muhammad Tughlaq](/wiki/Muhammad_Tughlaq "Muhammad Tughlaq") with the Bargujars as his main allies. Tughlaq had to pay a huge ransom and relinquish all of Mewar's lands. After this event, the Delhi Sultanate did not attack Chittor for a few hundred years. The Rajputs re-established their independence, and Rajput states were established as far east as Bengal and north into the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab"). The [Tomaras](/wiki/Tomaras_of_Gwalior "Tomaras of Gwalior") established themselves at [Gwalior](/wiki/Gwalior "Gwalior"), and [Man Singh Tomar](/wiki/Man_Singh_Tomar "Man Singh Tomar") reconstructed the [Gwalior Fort](/wiki/Gwalior_Fort "Gwalior Fort").[[273]](#cite_note-sen2-274) During this period, Mewar emerged as the leading Rajput state; and [Rana Kumbha](/wiki/Rana_Kumbha "Rana Kumbha") expanded his kingdom at the expense of the [Sultanates](/wiki/Sultan "Sultan") of [Malwa](/wiki/Malwa_Sultanate "Malwa Sultanate") and [Gujarat](/wiki/Sultanate_of_Gujarat "Sultanate of Gujarat").[[273]](#cite_note-sen2-274)[[274]](#cite_note-275) The next great Rajput ruler, [Rana Sanga](/wiki/Rana_Sanga "Rana Sanga") of Mewar, became the principal player in [Northern India](/wiki/Northern_India "Northern India"). His objectives grew in scope – he planned to conquer Delhi. But, his defeat in the [Battle of Khanwa](/wiki/Battle_of_Khanwa "Battle of Khanwa") consolidated the new [Mughal dynasty](/wiki/Mughal_dynasty "Mughal dynasty") in India.[[273]](#cite_note-sen2-274) The Mewar dynasty under Maharana [Udai Singh II](/wiki/Udai_Singh_II "Udai Singh II") faced further defeat by Mughal emperor [Akbar](/wiki/Akbar "Akbar"), with their capital Chittor being captured. Due to this event, Udai Singh II founded [Udaipur](/wiki/Udaipur "Udaipur"), which became the new capital of the [Mewar kingdom](/wiki/Udaipur_State "Udaipur State"). His son, [Maharana Pratap](/wiki/Maharana_Pratap "Maharana Pratap") of Mewar, firmly resisted the Mughals. Akbar sent many missions against him. He survived to ultimately gain control of all of Mewar, excluding the [Chittor Fort](/wiki/Chittor_Fort "Chittor Fort").[[275]](#cite_note-276)

In the south, the [Bahmani Sultanate](/wiki/Bahmani_Sultanate "Bahmani Sultanate") in the Deccan, born from a [rebellion](/wiki/Rebellion_of_Ismail_Mukh "Rebellion of Ismail Mukh") in 1347 against the [Tughlaq dynasty](/wiki/Tughlaq_dynasty "Tughlaq dynasty"),[[276]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200541–42-277) was the chief rival of Vijayanagara, and frequently created difficulties for them.[[277]](#cite_note-278) Starting in 1490, the Bahmani Sultanate's governors revolted, their independent states composing the five [Deccan sultanates](/wiki/Deccan_sultanates "Deccan sultanates"); [Ahmadnagar](/wiki/Ahmadnagar_Sultanate "Ahmadnagar Sultanate") declared independence, followed by [Bijapur](/wiki/Bijapur_Sultanate "Bijapur Sultanate") and [Berar](/wiki/Berar_sultanate "Berar sultanate") in the same year; [Golkonda](/wiki/Golconda_Sultanate "Golconda Sultanate") became independent in 1518 and [Bidar](/wiki/Bidar_Sultanate "Bidar Sultanate") in 1528.[[278]](#cite_note-279) Although generally rivals, they allied against the Vijayanagara Empire in 1565, permanently weakening Vijayanagar in the Battle of Talikota.[[279]](#cite_note-280)[[280]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200598-281)

In the East, the [Gajapati Kingdom](/wiki/Gajapati_Kingdom "Gajapati Kingdom") remained a strong regional power to reckon with, associated with a high point in the growth of regional culture and architecture. Under [Kapilendradeva](/wiki/Kapilendradeva "Kapilendradeva"), Gajapatis became an empire stretching from the lower [Ganga](/wiki/Ganga "Ganga") in the north to the [Kaveri](/wiki/Kaveri "Kaveri") in the south.[[281]](#cite_note-282) In [Northeast India](/wiki/Northeast_India "Northeast India"), the [Ahom Kingdom](/wiki/Ahom_Kingdom "Ahom Kingdom") was a major power for six centuries;[[282]](#cite_note-283)[[283]](#cite_note-284) led by [Lachit Borphukan](/wiki/Lachit_Borphukan "Lachit Borphukan"), the Ahoms decisively defeated the Mughal army at the [Battle of Saraighat](/wiki/Battle_of_Saraighat "Battle of Saraighat") during the [Ahom-Mughal conflicts](/wiki/Ahom-Mughal_conflicts "Ahom-Mughal conflicts").[[284]](#cite_note-285) Further east in Northeastern India was the [Kingdom of Manipur](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Manipur "Kingdom of Manipur"), which ruled from their seat of power at [Kangla Fort](/wiki/Kangla_Fort "Kangla Fort") and developed a sophisticated Hindu [Gaudiya Vaishnavite](/wiki/Gaudiya_Vaishnavite "Gaudiya Vaishnavite") culture.[[285]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200483–84,_the_other_major_classical_Indian_dances_are:_Bharatanatyam,_Kathak,_Odissi,_Kathakali,_Kuchipudi,_Cchau,_Satriya,_Yaksagana_and_Bhagavata_Mela-286)[[286]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMassey2004177-287)[[287]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDevi1990175–180-288)

The [Sultanate of Bengal](/wiki/Sultanate_of_Bengal "Sultanate of Bengal") was the dominant power of the [Ganges–Brahmaputra Delta](/wiki/Ganges%E2%80%93Brahmaputra_Delta "Ganges–Brahmaputra Delta"), with a network of mint towns spread across the region. It was a [Sunni Muslim](/wiki/Sunni_Muslim "Sunni Muslim") monarchy with Indo-Turkic, Arab, Abyssinian and [Bengali Muslim](/wiki/Bengali_Muslim "Bengali Muslim") elites. The sultanate was known for its religious pluralism where non-Muslim communities co-existed peacefully. The Bengal Sultanate had a circle of [vassal states](/wiki/Vassal_states "Vassal states"), including [Odisha](/wiki/Odisha "Odisha") in the southwest, [Arakan](/wiki/Arakan "Arakan") in the southeast, and [Tripura](/wiki/Tripura "Tripura") in the east. In the early 16th century, the Bengal Sultanate reached the peak of its territorial growth with control over [Kamrup](/wiki/Kamarupa "Kamarupa") and [Kamata](/wiki/Kamata_Kingdom "Kamata Kingdom") in the northeast and [Jaunpur](/wiki/Jaunpur_district "Jaunpur district") and [Bihar](/wiki/Bihar "Bihar") in the west. It was reputed as a thriving trading nation and one of Asia's strongest states. The Bengal Sultanate was described by contemporary European and Chinese visitors as a relatively prosperous kingdom and the "richest country to trade with". The Bengal Sultanate left a strong architectural legacy. Buildings from the period show foreign influences merged into a distinct [Bengali style.](/wiki/Architecture_of_Bengal "Architecture of Bengal") The Bengal Sultanate was also the largest and most prestigious authority among the independent medieval Muslim-ruled states in the [history of Bengal](/wiki/History_of_Bengal "History of Bengal"). Its decline began with an [interregnum](/wiki/Interregnum "Interregnum") by the [Suri Empire](/wiki/Suri_Empire "Suri Empire"), followed by [Mughal](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire") [conquest](/wiki/Bengal_Subah "Bengal Subah") and disintegration into petty kingdoms.

### Bhakti movement and Sikhism

Main articles: [Bhakti movement](/wiki/Bhakti_movement "Bhakti movement"), [Buddhism in India](/wiki/Buddhism_in_India "Buddhism in India"), and [Sikhism](/wiki/Sikhism "Sikhism")

See also: [History of Sikhism](/wiki/History_of_Sikhism "History of Sikhism")

The Bhakti movement refers to the [theistic](/wiki/Theism "Theism") devotional trend that emerged in medieval Hinduism[[288]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871-289) and later revolutionised in [Sikhism](/wiki/Sikhism "Sikhism").[[289]](#cite_note-290) It originated in the seventh-century south India (now parts of Tamil Nadu and Kerala), and spread northwards.[[288]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871-289) It swept over east and north India from the 15th century onwards, reaching its zenith between the 15th and 17th century.[[290]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19871–2-291)

* The Bhakti movement regionally developed around different gods and goddesses, such as [Vaishnavism](/wiki/Vaishnavism "Vaishnavism") (Vishnu), [Shaivism](/wiki/Shaivism "Shaivism") (Shiva), [Shaktism](/wiki/Shaktism "Shaktism") (Shakti goddesses), and [Smartism](/wiki/Smartism "Smartism").[[291]](#cite_note-292)[[292]](#cite_note-293)[[293]](#cite_note-294) The movement was inspired by many poet-saints, who championed a wide range of philosophical positions ranging from theistic [dualism](/wiki/Dualism_(Indian_philosophy) "Dualism (Indian philosophy)") of [Dvaita](/wiki/Dvaita "Dvaita") to absolute [monism](/wiki/Monism "Monism") of [Advaita Vedanta](/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta "Advaita Vedanta").[[294]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchomerMcLeod19872-295)[[295]](#cite_note-296)
* Sikhism is a [monotheistic](/wiki/Monotheistic "Monotheistic") and [panentheistic](/wiki/Panentheistic "Panentheistic") religion based on the spiritual teachings of [Guru Nanak](/wiki/Guru_Nanak "Guru Nanak"), the first Guru,[[296]](#cite_note-297) and the ten successive [Sikh gurus](/wiki/Sikh_gurus "Sikh gurus"). After the death of the tenth Guru, [Guru Gobind Singh](/wiki/Guru_Gobind_Singh "Guru Gobind Singh"), the Sikh scripture, [Guru Granth Sahib](/wiki/Guru_Granth_Sahib "Guru Granth Sahib"), became the literal embodiment of the eternal, impersonal Guru, where the scripture's word serves as the spiritual guide for Sikhs.[[297]](#cite_note-298)[[298]](#cite_note-299)[[299]](#cite_note-300)
* [Buddhism in India](/wiki/Buddhism_in_India "Buddhism in India") flourished in the [Himalayan](/wiki/Himalaya "Himalaya") kingdoms of [Namgyal Kingdom](/wiki/Namgyal_dynasty_of_Ladakh "Namgyal dynasty of Ladakh") in [Ladakh](/wiki/Ladakh "Ladakh"), [Sikkim Kingdom](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sikkim "Kingdom of Sikkim") in [Sikkim](/wiki/Sikkim "Sikkim"), and [Chutia Kingdom](/wiki/Chutia_Kingdom "Chutia Kingdom") in [Arunachal Pradesh](/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh "Arunachal Pradesh") of the Late medieval period.

* [Rang Ghar](/wiki/Rang_Ghar "Rang Ghar"), built by [Pramatta Singha](/wiki/Pramatta_Singha "Pramatta Singha") in [Ahom kingdom](/wiki/Ahom_kingdom "Ahom kingdom")'s capital [Rangpur](/wiki/Sibsagar "Sibsagar"), is one of the earliest pavilions of outdoor stadia in the Indian subcontinent
* [Chittor Fort](/wiki/Chittor_Fort "Chittor Fort") is the largest fort on the Indian subcontinent; it is one of the six [Hill Forts of Rajasthan](/wiki/Hill_Forts_of_Rajasthan "Hill Forts of Rajasthan")
* [Ranakpur Jain temple](/wiki/Ranakpur_Jain_temple "Ranakpur Jain temple") was built in the 15th century with the support of the Rajput state of [Mewar](/wiki/Mewar "Mewar")
* [Gol Gumbaz](/wiki/Gol_Gumbaz "Gol Gumbaz") built by the [Bijapur Sultanate](/wiki/Bijapur_Sultanate "Bijapur Sultanate"), has the second largest pre-modern dome in the world after the Byzantine [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia")

## Early modern period (1526–1858)

The [early modern period](/wiki/Early_modern_period "Early modern period") of Indian history is dated from 1526 to 1858, corresponding to the rise and fall of the [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire"), which inherited from the [Timurid Renaissance](/wiki/Timurid_Renaissance "Timurid Renaissance"). During this age India's economy expanded, relative peace was maintained and arts were patronised. This period witnessed the further development of [Indo-Islamic architecture](/wiki/Indo-Islamic_architecture "Indo-Islamic architecture");[[300]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2006115-301)[[301]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200190–91-302) the growth of [Marathas](/wiki/Maratha_Empire "Maratha Empire") and [Sikhs](/wiki/Sikh_Empire "Sikh Empire") enabled them to rule significant regions of India in the waning days of the Mughal empire.[[16]](#cite_note-exeter-16) With the discovery of the [Cape route](/wiki/Cape_route "Cape route") in the 1500s, the first Europeans to arrive by sea and establish themselves, were the [Portuguese in Goa and Bombay](/wiki/Portuguese_in_Goa_and_Bombay "Portuguese in Goa and Bombay").[[302]](#cite_note-303)

### Mughal Empire

Main article: [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire")

See also: [Bengal Subah](/wiki/Bengal_Subah "Bengal Subah"), [Muslin trade in Bengal](/wiki/Muslin_trade_in_Bengal "Muslin trade in Bengal"), [Mughal architecture](/wiki/Mughal_architecture "Mughal architecture"), [Army of the Mughal Empire](/wiki/Army_of_the_Mughal_Empire "Army of the Mughal Empire"), [Mughal clothing](/wiki/Mughal_clothing "Mughal clothing"), and [Mughal painting](/wiki/Mughal_painting "Mughal painting")

Mughal Empire

Map of the [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire") at its peak in year 1700

[Taj Mahal](/wiki/Taj_Mahal "Taj Mahal") is the jewel of Muslim architecture in India [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site") declaration, 1983.[[303]](#cite_note-304)

In 1526, [Babur](/wiki/Babur "Babur") swept across the [Khyber Pass](/wiki/Khyber_Pass "Khyber Pass") and established the Mughal Empire, which at its zenith covered much of South Asia.[[304]](#cite_note-305) However, his son [Humayun](/wiki/Humayun "Humayun") was defeated by the Afghan warrior [Sher Shah Suri](/wiki/Sher_Shah_Suri "Sher Shah Suri") in 1540, and Humayun was forced to retreat to [Kabul](/wiki/Kabul "Kabul"). After Sher Shah's death, his son [Islam Shah Suri](/wiki/Islam_Shah_Suri "Islam Shah Suri") and his Hindu general [Hemu Vikramaditya](/wiki/Hemu_Vikramaditya "Hemu Vikramaditya") established secular rule in North India from [Delhi](/wiki/Delhi "Delhi") until 1556, when [Akbar](/wiki/Akbar "Akbar") (r. 1556–1605), grandson of Babur, defeated Hemu in the [Second Battle of Panipat](/wiki/Battle_of_Panipat_(1556) "Battle of Panipat (1556)") on 6 November 1556 after winning [Battle of Delhi](/wiki/Battle_of_Delhi_(1556) "Battle of Delhi (1556)"). Akbar tried to establish a good relationship with the Hindus. Akbar declared "Amari" or non-killing of animals in the holy days of Jainism. He rolled back the *[jizya](/wiki/Jizya "Jizya")* tax for non-Muslims. The Mughal emperors married local royalty, allied themselves with local *[maharajas](/wiki/Maharajas "Maharajas")*, and attempted to fuse their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, creating a unique [Indo-Persian culture](/wiki/Indo-Persian_culture "Indo-Persian culture") and [Indo-Saracenic architecture](/wiki/Mughal_architecture "Mughal architecture").

Akbar married a [Rajput](/wiki/Rajput "Rajput") princess, [Mariam-uz-Zamani](/wiki/Mariam-uz-Zamani "Mariam-uz-Zamani"), and they had a son, [Jahangir](/wiki/Jahangir "Jahangir") (r. 1605–1627).[[305]](#cite_note-306) Jahangir followed his father's policy. The Mughal dynasty ruled most of the Indian subcontinent by 1600. The reign of [Shah Jahan](/wiki/Shah_Jahan "Shah Jahan") (r. 1628–1658) was the golden age of Mughal architecture. He erected several large monuments, the most famous of which is the [Taj Mahal](/wiki/Taj_Mahal "Taj Mahal") at Agra.

It was one of the largest empires to have existed in the Indian subcontinent,[[306]](#cite_note-307) and surpassed China to become the world's largest economic power, controlling 24.4% of the [world economy](/wiki/World_economy "World economy"),[[307]](#cite_note-308) and the world leader in manufacturing,[[308]](#cite_note-309) producing 25% of global industrial output.[[309]](#cite_note-310) The economic and demographic upsurge was stimulated by Mughal [agrarian reforms](/wiki/Agrarian_reform "Agrarian reform") that intensified agricultural production,[[310]](#cite_note-311) and a relatively high degree of [urbanisation](/wiki/Urbanisation "Urbanisation").[[311]](#cite_note-312)

Other Mughal UNESCO World Heritage Sites

* [Agra Fort](/wiki/Agra_Fort "Agra Fort") showing [Yamuna](/wiki/Yamuna "Yamuna") river and Taj Mahal in the background
* [Fatehpur Sikri](/wiki/Fatehpur_Sikri "Fatehpur Sikri"), near Agra, showing [Buland Darwaza](/wiki/Buland_Darwaza "Buland Darwaza"), the complex built by [Akbar](/wiki/Akbar "Akbar"), the third Mughal emperor
* [Red Fort](/wiki/Red_Fort "Red Fort"), Delhi, constructed in the year 1648

The Mughal Empire reached the zenith of its territorial expanse during the reign of [Aurangzeb](/wiki/Aurangzeb "Aurangzeb") (r. 1658–1707), under whose reign India surpassed Qing China as the world's largest economy.[[312]](#cite_note-313)[[313]](#cite_note-314) Aurangzeb was less tolerant than his predecessors, reintroducing the *jizya* tax and destroying several historical temples, while at the same time building more Hindu temples than he destroyed,[[314]](#cite_note-315) employing significantly more Hindus in his imperial bureaucracy than his predecessors, and advancing administrators based on ability rather than religion.[[315]](#cite_note-316) However, he is often blamed for the erosion of the tolerant syncretic tradition of his predecessors, as well as increasing religious controversy and centralisation. The [English East India Company](/wiki/English_East_India_Company "English East India Company") suffered a defeat in the [Anglo-Mughal War](/wiki/Anglo-Mughal_War_(1686%E2%80%931690) "Anglo-Mughal War (1686–1690)").[[316]](#cite_note-317)[[317]](#cite_note-318)

The Mughals suffered several blows due to invasions from [Marathas](/wiki/Maratha_Empire "Maratha Empire"), [Rajputs](/wiki/Rajput "Rajput"), [Jats](/wiki/Bharatpur_State "Bharatpur State") and [Afghans](/wiki/Durrani_Empire "Durrani Empire"). In 1737, the Maratha general [Bajirao](/wiki/Bajirao "Bajirao") of the Maratha Empire invaded and plundered Delhi. Under the general Amir Khan Umrao Al Udat, the Mughal Emperor sent 8,000 troops to drive away the 5,000 Maratha cavalry soldiers. Baji Rao easily routed the novice Mughal general. In 1737, in the final defeat of Mughal Empire, the commander-in-chief of the Mughal Army, Nizam-ul-mulk, was routed at Bhopal by the Maratha army. This essentially brought an end to the Mughal Empire.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*] While Bharatpur State under Jat ruler [Suraj Mal](/wiki/Suraj_Mal "Suraj Mal"), overran the Mughal garrison at Agra and plundered the city.[[318]](#cite_note-319) In 1739, [Nader Shah](/wiki/Nader_Shah "Nader Shah"), emperor of Iran, defeated the Mughal army at the [Battle of Karnal](/wiki/Battle_of_Karnal "Battle of Karnal").[[319]](#cite_note-320) After this victory, Nader captured and sacked Delhi, carrying away treasures including the [Peacock Throne](/wiki/Peacock_Throne "Peacock Throne").[[320]](#cite_note-321) [Ahmad Shah Durrani](/wiki/Ahmad_Shah_Durrani "Ahmad Shah Durrani") commenced his own invasions as ruler of the [Durrani Empire](/wiki/Durrani_Empire "Durrani Empire"), eventually [sacking Delhi in 1757](/wiki/Sack_of_Delhi_(1757) "Sack of Delhi (1757)").[[321]](#cite_note-322) Mughal rule was further weakened by constant native Indian resistance; [Banda Singh Bahadur](/wiki/Banda_Singh_Bahadur "Banda Singh Bahadur") led the [Sikh](/wiki/Sikh "Sikh") [Khalsa](/wiki/Khalsa "Khalsa") against Mughal religious oppression; Hindu [Rajas](/wiki/Raja "Raja") of Bengal, [Pratapaditya](/wiki/Pratapaditya "Pratapaditya") and [Raja Sitaram Ray](/wiki/Raja_Sitaram_Ray "Raja Sitaram Ray") revolted; and [Maharaja](/wiki/Maharaja "Maharaja") [Chhatrasal](/wiki/Chhatrasal "Chhatrasal"), of [Bundela](/wiki/Bundela "Bundela") Rajputs, fought the Mughals and established the [Panna State](/wiki/Panna_State "Panna State").[[322]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2006265-323) The [Mughal dynasty](/wiki/Mughal_emperors "Mughal emperors") was reduced to puppet rulers by 1757. [Vadda Ghalughara](/wiki/Vadda_Ghalughara "Vadda Ghalughara") took place under the Muslim provincial government based at [Lahore](/wiki/Lahore "Lahore") to wipe out the Sikhs, with 30,000 Sikhs being killed, an offensive that had begun with the Mughals, with the [Chhota Ghallughara](/wiki/Chhota_Ghallughara "Chhota Ghallughara"),[[323]](#cite_note-324) and lasted several decades under its Muslim successor states.[[324]](#cite_note-325)

### Maratha Empire

Main article: [Maratha Empire](/wiki/Maratha_Empire "Maratha Empire")

Further information: [Maratha Army](/wiki/Maratha_Army "Maratha Army"), [Maratha Navy](/wiki/Maratha_Navy "Maratha Navy"), and [Battles involving the Maratha Empire](/wiki/Battles_involving_the_Maratha_Empire "Battles involving the Maratha Empire")

Maratha Empire

Maratha Empire at its peak in 1760 (yellow area), covering much of the Indian subcontinent, stretching from [South India](/wiki/South_India "South India") to present-day [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan")

[Shaniwarwada](/wiki/Shaniwarwada "Shaniwarwada") palace fort in [Pune](/wiki/Pune "Pune"), the seat of the Peshwa rulers of the Maratha Empire until 1818

The Maratha kingdom was founded and consolidated by [Chatrapati Shivaji](/wiki/Chatrapati_Shivaji "Chatrapati Shivaji").[[325]](#cite_note-326) However, the credit for making the Marathas formidable power nationally goes to *[Peshwa](/wiki/Peshwa "Peshwa")* (chief minister) [Bajirao I](/wiki/Bajirao_I "Bajirao I"). Historian K.K. Datta wrote that Bajirao I "may very well be regarded as the second founder of the Maratha Empire".[[326]](#cite_note-327)

In the early 18th century, under the Peshwas, the Marathas consolidated and ruled over much of South Asia. The Marathas are credited to a large extent for ending [Mughal rule](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire") in India.[[327]](#cite_note-328)[[328]](#cite_note-329)[[329]](#cite_note-330) In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, in the Battle of Delhi. The Marathas continued [their military campaigns](/wiki/Battles_involving_the_Maratha_Empire "Battles involving the Maratha Empire") against the Mughals, [Nizam](/wiki/Nizam "Nizam"), [Nawab of Bengal](/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal "Nawab of Bengal") and the Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. At its peak, the domain of the Marathas encompassed most of the Indian subcontinent.[[330]](#cite_note-331) The Marathas even attempted to capture Delhi and discussed putting [Vishwasrao](/wiki/Vishwasrao "Vishwasrao") Peshwa on the throne there in place of the Mughal emperor.[[331]](#cite_note-332)

The Maratha empire at its peak stretched from [Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu "Tamil Nadu") in the south,[[332]](#cite_note-333) to [Peshawar](/wiki/Maratha_conquest_of_North-west_India "Maratha conquest of North-west India") (modern-day [Khyber Pakhtunkhwa](/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa "Khyber Pakhtunkhwa"), [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan")[[333]](#cite_note-334) [[note 2]](#cite_note-336)) in the north, and [Bengal](/wiki/Maratha_expeditions_in_Bengal "Maratha expeditions in Bengal") in the east. The Northwestern expansion of the Marathas was stopped after the [Third Battle of Panipat](/wiki/Third_Battle_of_Panipat "Third Battle of Panipat") (1761). However, the Maratha authority in the north was re-established within a decade under Peshwa [Madhavrao I](/wiki/Madhavrao_I "Madhavrao I").[[335]](#cite_note-337)

Under Madhavrao I, the strongest knights were granted semi-autonomy, creating a confederacy of United Maratha states under the [Gaekwads](/wiki/Gaekwad "Gaekwad") of [Baroda](/wiki/Baroda_State "Baroda State"), the [Holkars](/wiki/House_of_Holkar "House of Holkar") of [Indore](/wiki/Indore_State "Indore State") and [Malwa](/wiki/Malwa "Malwa"), the [Scindias](/wiki/Scindia "Scindia") of [Gwalior](/wiki/Gwalior_State "Gwalior State") and [Ujjain](/wiki/Ujjain "Ujjain"), the [Bhonsales](/wiki/Bhonsle_(clan) "Bhonsle (clan)") of [Nagpur](/wiki/Nagpur_kingdom "Nagpur kingdom") and the [Puars](/wiki/Paramara_dynasty "Paramara dynasty") of [Dhar](/wiki/Dhar_State "Dhar State") and [Dewas](/wiki/Dewas_State_(Maratha_Confederacy) "Dewas State (Maratha Confederacy)"). In 1775, the East India Company intervened in a Peshwa family succession struggle in [Pune](/wiki/Pune "Pune"), which led to the [First Anglo-Maratha War](/wiki/First_Anglo-Maratha_War "First Anglo-Maratha War"), resulting in a Maratha victory.[[336]](#cite_note-338) The Marathas remained a major power in India until their defeat in the [Second](/wiki/Second_Anglo-Maratha_War "Second Anglo-Maratha War") and [Third Anglo-Maratha Wars](/wiki/Third_Anglo-Maratha_War "Third Anglo-Maratha War") (1805–1818).

### Sikh Empire

Main article: [Sikh Empire](/wiki/Sikh_Empire "Sikh Empire")

See also: [Sikh architecture](/wiki/Sikh_architecture "Sikh architecture")

The Sikh Empire was a political entity that governed the Northwestern regions of the Indian subcontinent, based around the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab"), from 1799 to 1849. It was forged, on the foundations of the [Khalsa](/wiki/Khalsa "Khalsa"), under the leadership of [Maharaja Ranjit Singh](/wiki/Ranjit_Singh "Ranjit Singh") (1780–1839).[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

Maharaja Ranjit Singh consolidated much of northern India into an empire using his [Sikh Khalsa Army](/wiki/Sikh_Khalsa_Army "Sikh Khalsa Army"), trained in European military techniques and equipped with modern military technologies. Ranjit Singh proved himself to be a master strategist and selected well-qualified generals for his army. He successfully ended the [Afghan-Sikh Wars](/wiki/Afghan-Sikh_Wars "Afghan-Sikh Wars"). In stages, he added central Punjab, the provinces of Multan and Kashmir, and the Peshawar Valley to his empire.[[337]](#cite_note-339)[[338]](#cite_note-340)

At its peak in the 19th century, the empire extended from the [Khyber Pass](/wiki/Khyber_Pass "Khyber Pass") in the west, to [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir") in the north, to [Sindh](/wiki/Sindh "Sindh") in the south, running along Sutlej river to [Himachal](/wiki/Himachal_Pradesh "Himachal Pradesh") in the east. After the death of Ranjit Singh, the empire weakened, leading to conflict with the British East India Company. The [First Anglo-Sikh War](/wiki/First_Anglo-Sikh_War "First Anglo-Sikh War") and [Second Anglo-Sikh War](/wiki/Second_Anglo-Sikh_War "Second Anglo-Sikh War") marked the downfall of the Sikh Empire, making it among the last areas of the Indian subcontinent to be conquered by the British.

### Other kingdoms

The [Kingdom of Mysore](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mysore "Kingdom of Mysore") in southern India expanded to its greatest extent under [Hyder Ali](/wiki/Hyder_Ali "Hyder Ali") and his son [Tipu Sultan](/wiki/Tipu_Sultan "Tipu Sultan") in the later half of the 18th century. Under their rule, Mysore fought series of wars against the Marathas and British or their combined forces. The [Maratha–Mysore War](/wiki/Maratha%E2%80%93Mysore_War "Maratha–Mysore War") ended in April 1787, following the finalising of *treaty of Gajendragad*, in which Tipu Sultan was obligated to pay tribute to the Marathas. Concurrently, the [Anglo-Mysore Wars](/wiki/Anglo-Mysore_Wars "Anglo-Mysore Wars") took place, where the Mysoreans used the [Mysorean rockets](/wiki/Mysorean_rockets "Mysorean rockets"). The [Fourth Anglo-Mysore War](/wiki/Fourth_Anglo-Mysore_War "Fourth Anglo-Mysore War") (1798–1799) saw the death of Tipu. Mysore's alliance with the French was seen as a threat to the British East India Company, and Mysore was attacked from all four sides. The Nizam of Hyderabad and the Marathas launched an invasion from the north. The British won a decisive victory at the [Siege of Seringapatam (1799)](/wiki/Siege_of_Seringapatam_(1799) "Siege of Seringapatam (1799)").

Hyderabad was founded by the [Qutb Shahi dynasty](/wiki/Qutb_Shahi_dynasty "Qutb Shahi dynasty") of [Golconda](/wiki/Golconda "Golconda") in 1591. Following a brief Mughal rule, Asif Jah, a Mughal official, seized control of Hyderabad and declared himself [Nizam-al-Mulk of Hyderabad](/wiki/Nizam_of_Hyderabad "Nizam of Hyderabad") in 1724. The Nizams lost considerable territory and paid tribute to the Maratha Empire after being routed in multiple battles, such as the [Battle of Palkhed](/wiki/Battle_of_Palkhed "Battle of Palkhed").[[339]](#cite_note-341) However, the Nizams maintained their sovereignty from 1724 until 1948 through paying tributes to the Marathas, and later, being vassals of the British. [Hyderabad State](/wiki/Hyderabad_State "Hyderabad State") became a princely state in British India in 1798.

The [Nawabs of Bengal](/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal "Nawab of Bengal") had become the de facto rulers of Bengal following the decline of Mughal Empire. However, their rule was interrupted by Marathas who carried out [six expeditions in Bengal](/wiki/Expeditions_in_Bengal "Expeditions in Bengal") from 1741 to 1748, as a result of which Bengal became a tributary state of Marathas. On 23 June 1757, [Siraj ud-Daulah](/wiki/Siraj_ud-Daulah "Siraj ud-Daulah"), the last independent Nawab of Bengal was betrayed in the [Battle of Plassey](/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey "Battle of Plassey") by [Mir Jafar](/wiki/Mir_Jafar "Mir Jafar"). He lost to the British, who took over the charge of Bengal in 1757, installed Mir Jafar on the *Masnad* (throne) and established itself to a political power in Bengal.[[340]](#cite_note-342) In 1765 the system of Dual Government was established, in which the Nawabs ruled on behalf of the British and were mere puppets to the British. In 1772 the system was abolished and Bengal was brought under the direct control of the British. In 1793, when the *Nizamat* (governorship) of the Nawab was also taken away, they remained as mere pensioners of the [British East India Company](/wiki/British_East_India_Company "British East India Company").[[341]](#cite_note-343)[[342]](#cite_note-344)

In the 18th century, the whole of Rajputana was virtually subdued by the Marathas. The [Second Anglo-Maratha War](/wiki/Second_Anglo-Maratha_War "Second Anglo-Maratha War") distracted the Marathas from 1807 to 1809, but afterward Maratha domination of Rajputana resumed. In 1817, the British went to war with the [Pindaris](/wiki/Pindari "Pindari"), raiders who were fled in Maratha territory, which quickly became the [Third Anglo-Maratha War](/wiki/Third_Anglo-Maratha_War "Third Anglo-Maratha War"), and the British government offered its protection to the Rajput rulers from the Pindaris and the Marathas. By the end of 1818 similar treaties had been executed between the other Rajput states and Britain. The Maratha [Sindhia](/wiki/Sindhia "Sindhia") ruler of [Gwalior](/wiki/Gwalior "Gwalior") gave up the district of [Ajmer-Merwara](/wiki/Ajmer-Merwara "Ajmer-Merwara") to the British, and Maratha influence in Rajasthan came to an end.[[343]](#cite_note-345) Most of the Rajput princes remained loyal to Britain in the [Revolt of 1857](/wiki/Revolt_of_1857 "Revolt of 1857"), and few political changes were made in Rajputana until Indian independence in 1947. The [Rajputana Agency](/wiki/Rajputana_Agency "Rajputana Agency") contained more than 20 princely states, most notable being [Udaipur State](/wiki/Udaipur_State "Udaipur State"), [Jaipur State](/wiki/Jaipur_State "Jaipur State"), [Bikaner State](/wiki/Bikaner_State "Bikaner State") and [Jodhpur State](/wiki/Jodhpur_State "Jodhpur State").

After the fall of the Maratha Empire, many [Maratha dynasties and states](/wiki/List_of_Maratha_dynasties_and_states "List of Maratha dynasties and states") became vassals in a subsidiary alliance with the British. With the decline of the Sikh Empire, after the [First Anglo-Sikh War](/wiki/First_Anglo-Sikh_War "First Anglo-Sikh War") in 1846, under the terms of the [Treaty of Amritsar](/wiki/Treaty_of_Amritsar,_1846 "Treaty of Amritsar, 1846"), the British government sold Kashmir to Maharaja [Gulab Singh](/wiki/Gulab_Singh "Gulab Singh") and the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir, the second-largest princely state in British India, was created by the [Dogra dynasty](/wiki/Dogra_dynasty "Dogra dynasty").[[344]](#cite_note-346)[[345]](#cite_note-347) While in eastern and north-eastern India, the Hindu and Buddhist states of [Cooch Behar Kingdom](/wiki/Cooch_Behar_Kingdom "Cooch Behar Kingdom"), [Twipra Kingdom](/wiki/Twipra_Kingdom "Twipra Kingdom") and [Kingdom of Sikkim](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sikkim "Kingdom of Sikkim") were annexed by the British and made vassal princely state.

After the fall of the [Vijayanagara Empire](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire"), [Polygar](/wiki/Polygar "Polygar") states emerged in Southern India; and managed to weather invasions and flourished until the [Polygar Wars](/wiki/Polygar_Wars "Polygar Wars"), where they were defeated by the British East India Company forces.[[346]](#cite_note-348) Around the 18th century, the [Kingdom of Nepal](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Nepal "Kingdom of Nepal") was formed by Rajput rulers.[[347]](#cite_note-349)

### European exploration

Main article: [Colonial India](/wiki/Colonial_India "Colonial India")

In 1498, a Portuguese fleet under [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da Gama") discovered a new sea route from Europe to India, which paved the way for direct Indo-European commerce. The Portuguese soon set up trading posts in [Velha Goa](/wiki/Velha_Goa "Velha Goa"), [Damaon](/wiki/Daman,_India "Daman, India"), [Dio island](/wiki/Dio_island "Dio island"), and [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay "Bombay"). The Portuguese instituted the [Goa Inquisition](/wiki/Goa_Inquisition "Goa Inquisition"), where new Indian converts were punished for suspected heresy against Christianity and non-Christians were condemned.[[348]](#cite_note-350) Goa remained the main Portuguese territory until it was [annexed by India in 1961](/wiki/Indian_annexation_of_Goa "Indian annexation of Goa").[[349]](#cite_note-351)

The next to arrive [were the Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_India "Dutch India"), with their main base in [Ceylon](/wiki/Ceylon "Ceylon"). They established ports in [Malabar](/wiki/Dutch_Malabar "Dutch Malabar"). However, their expansion into India was halted after their defeat in the [Battle of Colachel](/wiki/Battle_of_Colachel "Battle of Colachel") by the [Kingdom of Travancore](/wiki/Travancore "Travancore") during the [Travancore-Dutch War](/wiki/Travancore-Dutch_War "Travancore-Dutch War"). The Dutch never recovered from the defeat and no longer posed a large colonial threat to India.[[350]](#cite_note-352)[[351]](#cite_note-353)

The internal conflicts among Indian kingdoms gave opportunities to the European traders to gradually establish political influence and appropriate lands. Following the Dutch, the British — who set up in the west coast port of [Surat](/wiki/Surat "Surat") in 1619 — and the French both established trading outposts in India. Although continental European powers controlled various coastal regions of southern and eastern India during the ensuing century, they eventually lost all their territories in India to the British, with the exception of the French outposts of [Pondichéry](/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory) "Puducherry (union territory)") and [Chandernagore](/wiki/Chandernagore "Chandernagore"), and the Portuguese colonies of [Goa, Daman and Diu](/wiki/Goa,_Daman_and_Diu "Goa, Daman and Diu").[[352]](#cite_note-354)[[353]](#cite_note-355)

### East India Company rule in India

Main articles: [East India Company](/wiki/East_India_Company "East India Company") and [Company rule in India](/wiki/Company_rule_in_India "Company rule in India")

India under East India Company rule

India in 1765 and 1805 showing East India Company Territories in pink

India in 1837 and 1857 showing East India Company (pink) and other territories

The English East India Company was founded in 1600. It gained a foothold in India with the establishment of a [factory](/wiki/Factory_(trading_post) "Factory (trading post)") in [Masulipatnam](/wiki/Masulipatnam "Masulipatnam") on the Eastern coast of India in 1611 and a grant of rights by the Mughal emperor Jahangir to establish a factory in [Surat](/wiki/Surat "Surat") in 1612. In 1640, after receiving similar permission from the [Vijayanagara ruler](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire") farther south, a second factory was established in [Madras](/wiki/Madras "Madras") on the southeastern coast. The islet of *[Bom Bahia](/wiki/Bom_Bahia "Bom Bahia")* in present-day Mumbai (Bombay) was a Portuguese [outpost](/wiki/Outpost_(military) "Outpost (military)") not far from Surat. It was presented to [Charles II of England](/wiki/Charles_II_of_England "Charles II of England") as [dowry](/wiki/Dowry "Dowry") in his marriage to [Catherine of Braganza](/wiki/Catherine_of_Braganza "Catherine of Braganza"). Charles in turn leased Bombay to the Company in 1668. Two decades later, the company established a [trade post](/wiki/Trade_post "Trade post") in the [River Ganges](/wiki/River_Ganges "River Ganges") delta. During this time other companies established by the [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_East_India_Company "Portuguese East India Company"), [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company "Dutch East India Company"), [French](/wiki/French_Indies_Company "French Indies Company"), and [Danish](/wiki/Danish_East_India_Company "Danish East India Company") were similarly expanding in the subcontinent.

The company's victory under [Robert Clive](/wiki/Robert_Clive "Robert Clive") in the 1757 [Battle of Plassey](/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey "Battle of Plassey") and another victory in the 1764 [Battle of Buxar](/wiki/Battle_of_Buxar "Battle of Buxar") (in Bihar), consolidated the company's power, and forced emperor [Shah Alam II](/wiki/Shah_Alam_II "Shah Alam II") to appoint it the *[diwan](/wiki/Diwan_(title) "Diwan (title)")*, or revenue collector, of Bengal, Bihar, and [Orissa](/wiki/Odisha "Odisha"). The company thus became the *de facto* ruler of large areas of the [lower Gangetic plain](/wiki/Lower_Gangetic_Plains_moist_deciduous_forests "Lower Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests") by 1773. It also proceeded by degrees to expand its dominions around Bombay and Madras. The [Anglo-Mysore Wars](/wiki/Anglo-Mysore_Wars "Anglo-Mysore Wars") (1766–99) and the [Anglo-Maratha Wars](/wiki/Anglo-Maratha_Wars_(disambiguation) "Anglo-Maratha Wars (disambiguation)") (1772–1818) left it in control of large areas of India south of the [Sutlej River](/wiki/Sutlej_River "Sutlej River"). With the defeat of the [Marathas](/wiki/Maratha_Empire "Maratha Empire"), no native power represented a threat for the company any longer.[[354]](#cite_note-356)

The expansion of the company's power chiefly took two forms. The first of these was the outright annexation of Indian states and subsequent direct governance of the underlying regions that collectively came to comprise British India. The annexed regions included the [North-Western Provinces](/wiki/North-Western_Provinces "North-Western Provinces") (comprising [Rohilkhand](/wiki/Rohilkhand "Rohilkhand"), [Gorakhpur](/wiki/Gorakhpur,_Uttar_Pradesh "Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh"), and the [Doab](/wiki/Doab "Doab")) (1801), Delhi (1803), Assam ([Ahom Kingdom](/wiki/Ahom_Kingdom "Ahom Kingdom") 1828) and [Sindh](/wiki/Sindh "Sindh") (1843). [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab"), [North-West Frontier Province](/wiki/North-West_Frontier_Province "North-West Frontier Province"), and [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir") were annexed after the [Anglo-Sikh Wars](/wiki/Second_Anglo-Sikh_War "Second Anglo-Sikh War") in 1849–56 (Period of tenure of Marquess of Dalhousie Governor General). However, Kashmir was immediately sold under the [Treaty of Amritsar](/wiki/Treaty_of_Amritsar,_1846 "Treaty of Amritsar, 1846") (1850) to the [Dogra Dynasty](/wiki/Dogra_Dynasty "Dogra Dynasty") of [Jammu](/wiki/Jammu "Jammu") and thereby became a princely state. In 1854, [Berar](/wiki/Berar_Province "Berar Province") was annexed along with the state of [Oudh](/wiki/Oudh_State "Oudh State") two years later.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

* [Warren Hastings](/wiki/Warren_Hastings "Warren Hastings"), the first governor-general of [Fort William (Bengal)](/wiki/Bengal_Presidency "Bengal Presidency") who oversaw the company's territories in India
* Gold coin, minted 1835, with obverse showing the bust of [William IV](/wiki/William_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom "William IV of the United Kingdom"), king of United Kingdom from 26 June 1830 to 20 June 1837, and reverse marked "Two mohurs" in English (do [ashrafi](/wiki/Ashrafi "Ashrafi") in [Urdu](/wiki/Urdu "Urdu")) issued during [Company rule in India](/wiki/Company_rule_in_India "Company rule in India")
* Photograph (1855) showing the construction of the Bhor Ghaut incline bridge, Bombay; the incline was conceived by George Clark, the Chief Engineer in the East India Company's Government of Bombay

The second form of asserting power involved treaties in which Indian rulers acknowledged the company's [hegemony](/wiki/Hegemony "Hegemony") in return for limited internal [autonomy](/wiki/Autonomy "Autonomy"). Since the company operated under financial constraints, it had to set up *political* underpinnings for its rule.[[355]](#cite_note-brown-p67-357) The most important such support came from the *[subsidiary alliances](/wiki/Subsidiary_alliance "Subsidiary alliance")* with Indian princes.[[355]](#cite_note-brown-p67-357) In the early 19th century, the territories of these princes accounted for two-thirds of India.[[355]](#cite_note-brown-p67-357) When an Indian ruler who was able to secure his territory wanted to enter such an alliance, the company welcomed it as an economical method of indirect rule that did not involve the economic costs of direct administration or the political costs of gaining the support of alien subjects.[[356]](#cite_note-brown-68-358)

In return, the company undertook the "defense of these subordinate allies and treated them with traditional respect and marks of honor."[[356]](#cite_note-brown-68-358) Subsidiary alliances created the [Princely States](/wiki/Princely_States "Princely States") of the Hindu [maharajas](/wiki/Maharaja "Maharaja") and the Muslim [nawabs](/wiki/Nawab "Nawab"). Prominent among the princely states were [Cochin](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Cochin "Kingdom of Cochin") (1791), [Jaipur](/wiki/Jaipur_State "Jaipur State") (1794), [Travancore](/wiki/Travancore "Travancore") (1795), [Hyderabad](/wiki/Hyderabad_State "Hyderabad State") (1798), [Mysore](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mysore "Kingdom of Mysore") (1799), [Cis-Sutlej Hill States](/wiki/Cis-Sutlej_states "Cis-Sutlej states") (1815), [Central India Agency](/wiki/Central_India_Agency "Central India Agency") (1819), [Cutch](/wiki/Cutch_State "Cutch State") and [Gujarat Gaikwad territories](/wiki/Baroda_State "Baroda State") (1819), [Rajputana](/wiki/Rajputana "Rajputana") (1818),[[357]](#cite_note-359) and [Bahawalpur](/wiki/Bahawalpur_(princely_state) "Bahawalpur (princely state)") (1833).

#### Indian indenture system

Main article: [Indian indenture system](/wiki/Indian_indenture_system "Indian indenture system")

The Indian indenture system was an ongoing system of indenture, a form of debt bondage, by which 3.5 million Indians were transported to colonies of European powers to provide labour for the (mainly sugar) plantations. It started from the end of slavery in 1833 and continued until 1920. This resulted in the development of a large [Indian diaspora](/wiki/Indian_diaspora "Indian diaspora") that spread from the Caribbean to the Pacific Ocean and the growth of large [Indo-Caribbean](/wiki/Indo-Caribbean "Indo-Caribbean") and [Indo-African](/wiki/Non-resident_Indian_and_person_of_Indian_origin "Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin") populations.

## Late modern period and contemporary history (1857–1947)

### Rebellion of 1857 and its consequences

Main article: [Indian Rebellion of 1857](/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857 "Indian Rebellion of 1857")

* [Lakshmibai, the Rani of Jhansi](/wiki/Rani_of_Jhansi "Rani of Jhansi"), one of the principal leaders of the rebellion who earlier had lost her kingdom as a result of the [Doctrine of lapse](/wiki/Doctrine_of_lapse "Doctrine of lapse").
* [Bahadur Shah Zafar](/wiki/Bahadur_Shah_Zafar "Bahadur Shah Zafar"), the last Mughal Emperor. Crowned Emperor of India by the rebels, he was deposed by the British and died in exile in Burma.
* [Charles Canning](/wiki/Charles_Canning,_1st_Earl_Canning "Charles Canning, 1st Earl Canning"), the [Governor-General of India](/wiki/Governor-General_of_India "Governor-General of India") during the rebellion.
* [Lord Dalhousie](/wiki/James_Broun-Ramsay,_1st_Marquess_of_Dalhousie "James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie"), the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856, who devised the [Doctrine of Lapse](/wiki/Doctrine_of_Lapse "Doctrine of Lapse").

The Indian rebellion of 1857 was a large-scale rebellion by soldiers employed by the British East India Company in northern and central India against the company's rule. The spark that led to the mutiny was the issue of new gunpowder cartridges for the Enfield rifle, which was insensitive to local religious prohibition. The key mutineer was [Mangal Pandey](/wiki/Mangal_Pandey "Mangal Pandey").[[358]](#cite_note-360) In addition, the underlying grievances over British taxation, the ethnic gulf between the British officers and their Indian troops and land annexations played a significant role in the rebellion. Within weeks after Pandey's mutiny, dozens of units of the Indian army joined peasant armies in widespread rebellion. The rebel soldiers were later joined by Indian nobility, many of whom had lost titles and domains under the [Doctrine of Lapse](/wiki/Doctrine_of_Lapse "Doctrine of Lapse") and felt that the company had interfered with a traditional system of inheritance. Rebel leaders such as [Nana Sahib](/wiki/Nana_Sahib "Nana Sahib") and the [Rani of Jhansi](/wiki/Rani_of_Jhansi "Rani of Jhansi") belonged to this group.[[359]](#cite_note-361)

After the outbreak of the mutiny in [Meerut](/wiki/Meerut "Meerut"), the rebels very quickly reached Delhi. The rebels had also captured large tracts of the [North-Western Provinces](/wiki/North-Western_Provinces "North-Western Provinces") and [Awadh](/wiki/Awadh "Awadh") (Oudh). Most notably, in Awadh, the rebellion took on the attributes of a patriotic revolt against British presence.[[360]](#cite_note-362) However, the British East India Company mobilised rapidly with the assistance of friendly [Princely states](/wiki/Princely_states "Princely states"), but it took the British the better part of 1858 to suppress the rebellion. Due to the rebels being poorly equipped and having no outside support or funding, they were brutally subdued.[[361]](#cite_note-363)

In the aftermath, all power was transferred from the British East India Company to the [British Crown](/wiki/British_Crown "British Crown"), which began to administer most of India as provinces. The Crown controlled the company's lands directly and had considerable indirect influence over the rest of India, which consisted of the Princely states ruled by local royal families. There were officially 565 princely states in 1947, but only 21 had actual state governments, and only three were large (Mysore, Hyderabad, and Kashmir). They were absorbed into the independent nation in 1947–48.[[362]](#cite_note-364)

### British Raj (1858–1947)

Main article: [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj")

British Raj

The British Indian Empire in 1909. [British India](/wiki/British_India "British India") is shown in pink; the [princely states](/wiki/Princely_state "Princely state") in yellow.

A 1903 stereographic image of [Victoria Terminus](/wiki/Victoria_Terminus "Victoria Terminus") a [terminal train station](/wiki/Terminal_train_station "Terminal train station"), in Mumbai, completed in 1887, and now a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site").

After 1857, the colonial government strengthened and expanded its infrastructure via the court system, legal procedures, and statutes. The [Indian Penal Code](/wiki/Indian_Penal_Code "Indian Penal Code") came into being.[[363]](#cite_note-365) In education, [Thomas Babington Macaulay](/wiki/Thomas_Babington_Macaulay,_1st_Baron_Macaulay "Thomas Babington Macaulay, 1st Baron Macaulay") had made schooling a priority for the Raj in 1835 and succeeded in implementing the use of English for instruction. By 1890 some 60,000 Indians had matriculated.[[364]](#cite_note-366) The Indian economy grew at about 1% per year from 1880 to 1920, and the population also grew at 1%. However, from 1910s Indian private industry began to grow significantly. India built a modern railway system in the late 19th century which was the fourth largest in the world.[[365]](#cite_note-367) Historians have been divided on issues of economic history, with the Nationalist school arguing that India was poorer due to British rule.[[366]](#cite_note-368)

In 1905, [Lord Curzon](/wiki/George_Curzon,_1st_Marquess_Curzon_of_Kedleston "George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston") [split the large province of Bengal](/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1905) "Partition of Bengal (1905)") into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half. The British goal was said to be efficient administration but the people of Bengal were outraged at the apparent "divide and rule" strategy. It also marked the beginning of the organised anti-colonial movement. When the Liberal party in Britain came to power in 1906, he was removed. Bengal was reunified in 1911. The new Viceroy Gilbert Minto and the new Secretary of State for India [John Morley](/wiki/John_Morley "John Morley") consulted with Congress leaders on political reforms. The [Morley-Minto reforms of 1909](/wiki/Indian_Councils_Act_1909 "Indian Councils Act 1909") provided for Indian membership of the provincial executive councils as well as the Viceroy's executive council. The Imperial Legislative Council was enlarged from 25 to 60 members and separate communal representation for Muslims was established in a dramatic step towards representative and responsible government.[[367]](#cite_note-369) Several socio-religious organisations came into being at that time. Muslims set up the [All India Muslim League](/wiki/All_India_Muslim_League "All India Muslim League") in 1906 to protect the interests of the aristocratic Muslims. The [Hindu Mahasabha](/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha "Hindu Mahasabha") sought to represent Hindu interests.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*] The Hindu nationalist [Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh](/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh "Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh") (RSS) was formed in 1925–1926.[[368]](#cite_note-370) Sikhs founded the [Shiromani Akali Dal](/wiki/Shiromani_Akali_Dal "Shiromani Akali Dal") in 1920.[[369]](#cite_note-371) However, the largest and oldest political party [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress"), founded in 1885, attempted to keep a distance from the socio-religious movements and identity politics.[[370]](#cite_note-372)
