#### Indian Renaissance

Main articles: [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") and [Bengali Renaissance](/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance "Bengali Renaissance")

* Sir [Syed Ahmad Khan](/wiki/Syed_Ahmad_Khan "Syed Ahmad Khan") (1817–1898), the author of *Causes of the Indian Mutiny*, was the founder of [Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College](/wiki/Muhammadan_Anglo-Oriental_College "Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College"), later the [Aligarh Muslim University](/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University "Aligarh Muslim University")
* [Pandita Ramabai](/wiki/Pandita_Ramabai "Pandita Ramabai") (1858–1922) was a [social reformer](/wiki/Reform_movement "Reform movement"), and a pioneer in the education and emancipation of women in India
* [Rabindranath Tagore](/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore "Rabindranath Tagore") (1861–1941) was a [Bengali language](/wiki/Bengali_language "Bengali language") poet, short-story writer, and playwright, and in addition a music composer and painter, who won the Nobel prize for Literature in 1913
* [Srinivasa Ramanujan](/wiki/Srinivasa_Ramanujan "Srinivasa Ramanujan") (1887–1920) was an Indian mathematician who made seminal contributions to [number theory](/wiki/Number_theory "Number theory")

The Bengali Renaissance refers to a social reform movement, dominated by [Bengali Hindus](/wiki/Bengali_Hindus "Bengali Hindus"), in the [Bengal region](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal") of the Indian subcontinent during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, a period of British rule. Historian [Nitish Sengupta](/wiki/Nitish_Sengupta "Nitish Sengupta") describes the renaissance as having started with reformer and humanitarian [Raja Ram Mohan Roy](/wiki/Raja_Ram_Mohan_Roy "Raja Ram Mohan Roy") (1775–1833), and ended with Asia's first Nobel laureate [Rabindranath Tagore](/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore "Rabindranath Tagore") (1861–1941).[[371]](#cite_note-373) This flowering of religious and social reformers, scholars, and writers is described by historian [David Kopf](/wiki/David_Kopf "David Kopf") as "one of the most creative periods in Indian history."[[372]](#cite_note-374)

During this period, Bengal witnessed an [intellectual](/wiki/Intellectual "Intellectual") awakening that is in some way similar to the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance"). This movement questioned existing orthodoxies, particularly with respect to women, marriage, the [dowry](/wiki/Dowry "Dowry") system, the [caste system](/wiki/Caste_system "Caste system"), and religion. One of the earliest [social movements](/wiki/Social_movement "Social movement") that emerged during this time was the [Young Bengal](/wiki/Young_Bengal "Young Bengal") movement, which espoused [rationalism](/wiki/Rationalism "Rationalism") and [atheism](/wiki/Atheism "Atheism") as the common denominators of civil conduct among upper caste educated Hindus.[[373]](#cite_note-375) It played an important role in reawakening Indian minds and intellect across the Indian subcontinent.

#### Famines

Main articles: [Famine in India](/wiki/Famine_in_India "Famine in India") and [Timeline of major famines in India during British rule](/wiki/Timeline_of_major_famines_in_India_during_British_rule "Timeline of major famines in India during British rule")

See also: [Demographics of India](/wiki/Demographics_of_India "Demographics of India")

* Map of famines in India during [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") in year 1800–1885.
* Engraving from *[The Graphic](/wiki/The_Graphic "The Graphic")*, October 1877, showing the plight of animals as well as humans in [Bellary district](/wiki/Bellary_district "Bellary district"), [Madras Presidency](/wiki/Madras_Presidency "Madras Presidency"), British India during the [Great Famine of 1876–1878](/wiki/Great_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%931878 "Great Famine of 1876–1878")
* Government famine relief, Ahmedabad, India, during the [Indian famine of 1899–1900](/wiki/Indian_famine_of_1899%E2%80%931900 "Indian famine of 1899–1900")
* A picture of orphans who survived the [Bengal famine of 1943](/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943 "Bengal famine of 1943"), a man-made disaster by the British government

During British East India Company and [British Crown](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") rule, India experienced some of deadliest ever recorded [famines](/wiki/Famines_in_India "Famines in India"). These famines, usually resulting from crop failures and often exacerbated by policies of the colonial government,[[374]](#cite_note-davis-376) included the [Great Famine of 1876–1878](/wiki/Great_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%931878 "Great Famine of 1876–1878") in which 6.1 million to 10.3 million people died,[[375]](#cite_note-377) the [Great Bengal famine of 1770](/wiki/Great_Bengal_famine_of_1770 "Great Bengal famine of 1770") where between 1 and 10 million people died,[[376]](#cite_note-378)[[377]](#cite_note-379) the [Indian famine of 1899–1900](/wiki/Indian_famine_of_1899%E2%80%931900 "Indian famine of 1899–1900") in which 1.25 to 10 million people died,[[374]](#cite_note-davis-376) and the [Bengal famine of 1943](/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943 "Bengal famine of 1943") where between 2.1 and 3.8 million people died.[[378]](#cite_note-380) The [Third plague pandemic](/wiki/Third_plague_pandemic "Third plague pandemic") in the mid-19th century killed 10 million people in India.[[379]](#cite_note-381) Despite persistent diseases and famines, the population of the Indian subcontinent, which stood at up to 200 million in 1750,[[380]](#cite_note-382) had reached 389 million by 1941.[[381]](#cite_note-383)

#### World War I

Main article: [Indian Army during World War I](/wiki/Indian_Army_during_World_War_I "Indian Army during World War I")

* Indian Cavalry on the Western front 1914
* Indian cavalry from the [Deccan Horse](/wiki/Deccan_Horse "Deccan Horse") during the [Battle of Bazentin Ridge](/wiki/Battle_of_Bazentin_Ridge "Battle of Bazentin Ridge") in 1916.
* Indian Army gunners (probably 39th Battery) with [3.7-inch mountain howitzers](/wiki/3.7-inch_mountain_howitzer "3.7-inch mountain howitzer"), Jerusalem 1917
* India Gate is a memorial to 70,000 soldiers of the [British Indian Army](/wiki/British_Indian_Army "British Indian Army") who died in the period 1914–21 in the First World War

During [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), over 800,000 volunteered for the army, and more than 400,000 volunteered for non-combat roles, compared with the pre-war annual recruitment of about 15,000 men.[[382]](#cite_note-384) The Army saw early action on the [Western Front](/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I) "Western Front (World War I)") at the [First Battle of Ypres](/wiki/First_Battle_of_Ypres "First Battle of Ypres"). After a year of front-line duty, sickness and casualties had reduced the Indian Corps to the point where it had to be withdrawn. Nearly 700,000 Indians fought the Turks in the Mesopotamian campaign. Indian formations were also sent to East Africa, Egypt, and Gallipoli.[[383]](#cite_note-385)

Indian Army and [Imperial Service Troops](/wiki/Imperial_Service_Troops "Imperial Service Troops") fought during the [Sinai and Palestine Campaign](/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign "Sinai and Palestine Campaign")'s [defence of the Suez Canal](/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign#Suez_Canal_Campaign_(1915–1916) "Sinai and Palestine Campaign") in 1915, at [Romani](/wiki/Battle_of_Romani "Battle of Romani") in 1916 and to [Jerusalem](/wiki/Battle_of_Jerusalem_(1917) "Battle of Jerusalem (1917)") in 1917. India units [occupied the Jordan Valley](/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Jordan_Valley_(1918) "Occupation of the Jordan Valley (1918)") and after the [German spring offensive](/wiki/German_spring_offensive "German spring offensive") they became the major force in the [Egyptian Expeditionary Force](/wiki/Egyptian_Expeditionary_Force "Egyptian Expeditionary Force") during the [Battle of Megiddo](/wiki/Battle_of_Megiddo_(1918) "Battle of Megiddo (1918)") and in the [Desert Mounted Corps](/wiki/Desert_Mounted_Corps "Desert Mounted Corps")' advance to [Damascus](/wiki/Damascus "Damascus") and on to [Aleppo](/wiki/Aleppo "Aleppo"). Other divisions remained in India guarding the [North-West Frontier](/wiki/North-West_Frontier_(military_history) "North-West Frontier (military history)") and fulfilling internal security obligations.

One million Indian troops served abroad during the war. In total, 74,187 died,[[384]](#cite_note-386) and another 67,000 were wounded.[[385]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESumner20017-387) The roughly 90,000 soldiers who died fighting in World War I and the [Afghan Wars](/wiki/Third_Anglo-Afghan_War "Third Anglo-Afghan War") are commemorated by the [India Gate](/wiki/India_Gate "India Gate").

#### World War II

Main article: [India in World War II](/wiki/India_in_World_War_II "India in World War II")

* General [Claude Auchinleck](/wiki/Claude_Auchinleck "Claude Auchinleck") (right), Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army, with the then [Viceroy](/wiki/Governor-General_of_India "Governor-General of India") [Wavell](/wiki/Archibald_Wavell,_1st_Earl_Wavell "Archibald Wavell, 1st Earl Wavell") (centre) and [General Montgomery](/wiki/Bernard_Law_Montgomery,_1st_Viscount_Montgomery_of_Alamein "Bernard Law Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein") (left)
* Indian women training for [Air Raid Precautions](/wiki/Air_Raid_Precautions "Air Raid Precautions") (ARP) duties in Bombay in 1942
* Indian infantrymen of the [7th Rajput Regiment](/wiki/7th_Rajput_Regiment "7th Rajput Regiment") about to go on patrol on the [Arakan front](/wiki/Arakan_Campaign_1942%E2%80%9343 "Arakan Campaign 1942–43") in Burma, 1944
* The stamp series "Victory" issued by the Government of British India to commemorate allied victory in World War II

British India officially declared war on [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") in September 1939.[[386]](#cite_note-388) The British Raj, as part of the [Allied Nations](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II"), sent over two and a half million volunteer soldiers to fight under British command against the [Axis powers](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers"). Additionally, several Princely States provided large donations to support the Allied campaign. India also provided the base for American operations in support of China in the [China Burma India Theatre](/wiki/China_Burma_India_Theater "China Burma India Theater").

Indians fought throughout the world, including in the [European theatre against Germany](/wiki/European_theatre_of_World_War_II "European theatre of World War II"), [in North Africa against Germany and Italy](/wiki/North_African_Campaign "North African Campaign"), against the Italians in [East Africa](/wiki/East_African_Campaign_(World_War_II) "East African Campaign (World War II)"), in [the Middle East](/wiki/Syria-Lebanon_Campaign "Syria-Lebanon Campaign") against the [Vichy French](/wiki/Vichy_French "Vichy French"), in the [South Asian region defending India against the Japanese and fighting the Japanese in Burma](/wiki/South-East_Asian_theatre_of_World_War_II "South-East Asian theatre of World War II"). Indians also aided in liberating British colonies such as Singapore and Hong Kong after the Japanese surrender in August 1945. Over 87,000 soldiers from the subcontinent died in World War II.

The [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") denounced Nazi Germany but would not fight it or anyone else until India was independent. Congress launched the [Quit India Movement](/wiki/Quit_India_Movement "Quit India Movement") in August 1942, refusing to co-operate in any way with the government until independence was granted. The government immediately arrested over 60,000 national and local Congress leaders. The [Muslim League](/wiki/All-India_Muslim_League "All-India Muslim League") rejected the Quit India movement and worked closely with the Raj authorities.

[Subhas Chandra Bose](/wiki/Subhas_Chandra_Bose "Subhas Chandra Bose") (also called *Netaji*) broke with Congress and tried to form a military alliance with Germany or Japan to gain independence. The Germans assisted Bose in the formation of the [Indian Legion](/wiki/Indian_Legion "Indian Legion");[[387]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMüller200955-389) however, it was Japan that helped him revamp the [Indian National Army](/wiki/Indian_National_Army "Indian National Army") (INA), after the [First Indian National Army](/wiki/First_Indian_National_Army "First Indian National Army") under [Mohan Singh](/wiki/Mohan_Singh_(general) "Mohan Singh (general)") was dissolved. The INA fought under Japanese direction, mostly in Burma.[[388]](#cite_note-390) Bose also headed the [Provisional Government of Free India](/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Free_India "Provisional Government of Free India") (or [Azad Hind](/wiki/Azad_Hind "Azad Hind")), a government-in-exile based in Singapore.[[389]](#cite_note-391)[[390]](#cite_note-392)

By 1942, neighbouring [Burma](/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar") was invaded by Japan, which by then had already captured the Indian territory of [Andaman and Nicobar Islands](/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands "Andaman and Nicobar Islands"). Japan gave nominal control of the islands to the [Provisional Government of Free India](/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Free_India "Provisional Government of Free India") on 21 October 1943, and in the following March, the Indian National Army with the help of Japan crossed into India and advanced as far as [Kohima](/wiki/Kohima "Kohima") in [Nagaland](/wiki/Nagaland "Nagaland"). This advance on the mainland of the Indian subcontinent reached its farthest point on Indian territory, retreating from the [Battle of Kohima](/wiki/Battle_of_Kohima "Battle of Kohima") in June and from [that of Imphal](/wiki/Battle_of_Imphal "Battle of Imphal") on 3 July 1944.

The region of Bengal in British India [suffered a devastating famine during 1940–1943](/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1943 "Bengal famine of 1943"). An estimated 2.1–3 million died from the famine, frequently characterised as "man-made",[[391]](#cite_note-393) with most sources asserting that wartime [colonial](/wiki/Colonization "Colonization") policies exacerbated the crisis.[[392]](#cite_note-394)

### Indian independence movement (1885–1947)

Main article: [Indian independence movement](/wiki/Indian_independence_movement "Indian independence movement")

See also: [Indian independence activists](/wiki/Indian_independence_activists "Indian independence activists") and [Pakistan Movement](/wiki/Pakistan_Movement "Pakistan Movement")

* The first session of the [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") in 1885. [A. O. Hume](/wiki/A._O._Hume "A. O. Hume"), the founder, is shown in the middle (third row from the front). The Congress was the first modern nationalist movement to emerge in the British Empire in Asia and Africa.[[393]](#cite_note-395)
* Front page of the *Tribune* (25 March 1931), reporting the execution of [Bhagat Singh](/wiki/Bhagat_Singh "Bhagat Singh"), [Rajguru](/wiki/Shivaram_Rajguru "Shivaram Rajguru") and [Sukhdev](/wiki/Sukhdev_Thapar "Sukhdev Thapar") by the British for the murder of 21-year-old police officer J. P. Saunders. Bhagat Singh quickly became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
* From the late 19th century, and especially after 1920, under the leadership of [Mahatma Gandhi](/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi") (right), the Congress became the principal leader of the [Indian independence movement](/wiki/Indian_independence_movement "Indian independence movement").[[394]](#cite_note-396) Gandhi is shown here with [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru"), later the first prime minister of India.

The numbers of British in India were small,[[395]](#cite_note-397) yet they were able to rule 52% of the Indian subcontinent directly and exercise considerable leverage over the [princely states](/wiki/Princely_states "Princely states") that accounted for 48% of the area.[[396]](#cite_note-398)

One of the most important events of the 19th century was the rise of Indian nationalism,[[397]](#cite_note-Modern_India,_Bipin_Chandra,_p.76-399) leading Indians to seek first "self-rule" and later "complete independence". However, historians are divided over the causes of its rise. Probable reasons include a "clash of interests of the Indian people with British interests",[[397]](#cite_note-Modern_India,_Bipin_Chandra,_p.76-399) "racial discriminations",[[398]](#cite_note-400) and "the revelation of India's past".[[399]](#cite_note-401)

The first step toward Indian self-rule was the appointment of [councillors](/wiki/Councillor "Councillor") to advise the British [viceroy](/wiki/Viceroy "Viceroy") in 1861 and the first Indian was appointed in 1909. Provincial Councils with Indian members were also set up. The councillors' participation was subsequently widened into legislative councils. The British built a large [British Indian Army](/wiki/British_Indian_Army "British Indian Army"), with the senior officers all British and many of the troops from small minority groups such as [Gurkhas](/wiki/Gurkha "Gurkha") from Nepal and [Sikhs](/wiki/Sikhs "Sikhs").[[400]](#cite_note-402) The civil service was increasingly filled with natives at the lower levels, with the British holding the more senior positions.[[401]](#cite_note-403)

[Bal Gangadhar Tilak](/wiki/Bal_Gangadhar_Tilak "Bal Gangadhar Tilak"), an Indian nationalist leader, declared [Swaraj](/wiki/Swaraj "Swaraj") (home rule) as the destiny of the nation. His popular sentence "Swaraj is my birthright, and I shall have it"[[402]](#cite_note-404) became the source of inspiration. Tilak was backed by rising public leaders like [Bipin Chandra Pal](/wiki/Bipin_Chandra_Pal "Bipin Chandra Pal") and [Lala Lajpat Rai](/wiki/Lala_Lajpat_Rai "Lala Lajpat Rai"), who held the same point of view, notably they advocated the [Swadeshi movement](/wiki/Swadeshi_movement "Swadeshi movement") involving the boycott of imported items and the use of Indian-made goods;[[403]](#cite_note-Chandra2016p128-405) the triumvirate were popularly known as [Lal Bal Pal](/wiki/Lal_Bal_Pal "Lal Bal Pal"). In 1907, the Congress was split into two factions: The radicals, led by Tilak, advocated civil agitation and direct revolution to overthrow the British Empire and the abandonment of all things British. The moderates, led by leaders like [Dadabhai Naoroji](/wiki/Dadabhai_Naoroji "Dadabhai Naoroji") and [Gopal Krishna Gokhale](/wiki/Gopal_Krishna_Gokhale "Gopal Krishna Gokhale"), on the other hand, wanted reform within the framework of British rule.[[403]](#cite_note-Chandra2016p128-405)

The [partition of Bengal in 1905](/wiki/Partition_of_Bengal_(1905) "Partition of Bengal (1905)") further increased the [revolutionary movement for Indian independence](/wiki/Revolutionary_movement_for_Indian_independence "Revolutionary movement for Indian independence"). The disenfranchisement lead some to take violent action.

The British themselves adopted a "carrot and stick" approach in response to renewed nationalist demands. The means of achieving the proposed measure were later enshrined in the [Government of India Act 1919](/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1919 "Government of India Act 1919"), which introduced the principle of a dual mode of administration, or diarchy, in which elected Indian legislators and appointed British officials shared power.[[404]](#cite_note-406) In 1919, Colonel [Reginald Dyer](/wiki/Reginald_Dyer "Reginald Dyer") ordered his troops to fire their weapons on peaceful protestors, including unarmed women and children, resulting in the [Jallianwala Bagh massacre](/wiki/Jallianwala_Bagh_massacre "Jallianwala Bagh massacre"); which led to the [Non-cooperation Movement](/wiki/Non-cooperation_movement_(1909%E2%80%9322) "Non-cooperation movement (1909–22)") of 1920–1922. The massacre was a decisive episode towards the end of British rule in India.[[405]](#cite_note-407)

From 1920 leaders such as [Mahatma Gandhi](/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi") began highly popular mass movements to campaign against the British Raj using largely peaceful methods. The Gandhi-led independence movement opposed the British rule using non-violent methods like [non-co-operation](/wiki/Non-cooperation_movement_(1909%E2%80%9322) "Non-cooperation movement (1909–22)"), [civil disobedience](/wiki/Dandi_March "Dandi March") and [economic resistance](/wiki/Swadeshi_movement "Swadeshi movement"). However, [revolutionary activities](/wiki/Revolutionary_movement_for_Indian_independence "Revolutionary movement for Indian independence") against the British rule took place throughout the Indian subcontinent and some others adopted a militant approach like the [Hindustan Republican Association](/wiki/Hindustan_Republican_Association "Hindustan Republican Association"), that sought to overthrow British rule by armed struggle.

The [All India Azad Muslim Conference](/wiki/All_India_Azad_Muslim_Conference "All India Azad Muslim Conference") gathered in Delhi in April 1940 to voice its support for an [independent and united India](/wiki/Opposition_to_the_partition_of_India "Opposition to the partition of India").[[406]](#cite_note-408) Its members included several Islamic organisations in India, as well as 1,400 nationalist Muslim delegates.[[407]](#cite_note-409)[[408]](#cite_note-Ahmed2016-410)[[409]](#cite_note-Ali2017-411) The pro-separatist All-India Muslim League worked to try to silence those nationalist Muslims who stood against the partition of India, often using "intimidation and coercion".[[408]](#cite_note-Ahmed2016-410)[[409]](#cite_note-Ali2017-411) The murder of the All India Azad Muslim Conference leader [Allah Bakhsh Soomro](/wiki/Allah_Bakhsh_Soomro "Allah Bakhsh Soomro") also made it easier for the pro-separatist All-India Muslim League to demand the creation of a Pakistan.[[409]](#cite_note-Ali2017-411)

#### After World War II (c. 1946–1947)

> "A moment comes, which comes but rarely in history, when we step out from the old to the new; when an age ends; and when the soul of a nation long suppressed finds utterance."

— From, [Tryst with destiny](/wiki/Tryst_with_destiny "Tryst with destiny"), a speech given by [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") to the [Constituent Assembly of India](/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_India "Constituent Assembly of India") on the eve of independence, 14 August 1947.[[410]](#cite_note-412)

In January 1946, several mutinies broke out in the armed services, starting with that of RAF servicemen frustrated with their slow repatriation. The mutinies came to a head with [mutiny of the Royal Indian Navy](/wiki/Royal_Indian_Navy_mutiny "Royal Indian Navy mutiny") in [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay "Bombay") in February 1946, followed by others in [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta "Calcutta"), [Madras](/wiki/Madras "Madras"), and [Karachi](/wiki/Karachi "Karachi"). The mutinies were rapidly suppressed. In early 1946, new elections were called and [Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") candidates won in eight of the eleven provinces. [*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

Late in 1946, the Labour government decided to end British rule of India, and in early 1947 it announced its intention of transferring power no later than June 1948 and participating in the formation of an [interim government](/wiki/Interim_Government_of_India "Interim Government of India"). [*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

Along with the desire for independence, tensions between Hindus and Muslims had also been developing over the years. Muslim League leader [Muhammad Ali Jinnah](/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah "Muhammad Ali Jinnah") proclaimed 16 August 1946 as [Direct Action Day](/wiki/Direct_Action_Day "Direct Action Day"), with the stated goal of highlighting, peacefully, the demand for a Muslim homeland in British India, which resulted in the outbreak of the cycle of violence that would be later called the "[Great Calcutta Killing of August 1946](/wiki/Direct_Action_Day "Direct Action Day")". The communal violence spread to [Bihar](/wiki/1946_Bihar_riots "1946 Bihar riots"), [Noakhali](/wiki/Noakhali_riots "Noakhali riots") in Bengal, [Garhmukteshwar](/wiki/Garhmukteshwar "Garhmukteshwar") in the [United Provinces](/wiki/United_Provinces_(1937-1950) "United Provinces (1937-1950)"), and on to [Rawalpindi](/wiki/Rawalpindi "Rawalpindi") in March 1947 in which Sikhs and Hindus were [attacked or driven out](/wiki/1947_Rawalpindi_massacres "1947 Rawalpindi massacres") by Muslims. [*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

## Independence and partition (1947–present)

Main article: [History of India (1947–present)](/wiki/History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present) "History of India (1947–present)")

Further information: [South Asia § Contemporary era](/wiki/South_Asia#Contemporary_era "South Asia"), [Partition of India](/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India"), [History of Pakistan (1947–present)](/wiki/History_of_Pakistan_(1947%E2%80%93present) "History of Pakistan (1947–present)"), and [History of Bangladesh](/wiki/History_of_Bangladesh "History of Bangladesh")

* A map of the prevailing religions of the British Indian empire based on district-wise majorities based on the Indian census of 1909, and published in the [Imperial Gazetteer of India](/wiki/Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India "Imperial Gazetteer of India"). The partition of the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab "Punjab") and Bengal was based on such majorities.
* Gandhi touring [Bela, Bihar](/wiki/Bela,_Bihar "Bela, Bihar"), a village struck by religious rioting in March 1947. On the right is [Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan](/wiki/Khan_Abdul_Gaffar_Khan "Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan").
* [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") being sworn in as the first prime minister of independent India by viceroy [Lord Louis Mountbatten](/wiki/Lord_Louis_Mountbatten "Lord Louis Mountbatten") at 8:30 AM 15 August 1947.

In August 1947, the British Indian Empire was partitioned into the [Union of India](/wiki/Dominion_of_India "Dominion of India") and [Dominion of Pakistan](/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan "Dominion of Pakistan"). In particular, the partition of the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab_(British_India) "Punjab (British India)") and Bengal led to rioting between Hindus, Muslims, and Sikhs in these provinces and spread to other nearby regions, leaving some 500,000 dead. The police and army units were largely ineffective. The British officers were gone, and the units were beginning to tolerate if not actually indulge in violence against their religious enemies.[[411]](#cite_note-413)[[412]](#cite_note-symonds-414)[[413]](#cite_note-415) Also, this period saw one of the largest mass migrations anywhere in modern history, with a total of 12 million Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims moving between the newly created nations of India and Pakistan (which gained independence on 15 and 14 August 1947 respectively).[[412]](#cite_note-symonds-414) In 1971, [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"), formerly [East Pakistan](/wiki/East_Pakistan "East Pakistan") and [East Bengal](/wiki/East_Bengal "East Bengal"), seceded from Pakistan.[[414]](#cite_note-416)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

This article is about the history of the [post-independence India](/wiki/India "India") established in 1947. For the history of the region prior to 1947, see [History of India](/wiki/History_of_India "History of India").

The **history of independent India** or **history of Republic of India** began when the country became an independent sovereign state within the [British Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") on 15 August 1947. Direct administration by the British, which began in 1858, affected a political and economic unification of the [subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent"). When British rule came to an end in 1947, the subcontinent was partitioned along religious lines into two separate countries—India, with a majority of [Hindus](/wiki/Hindus "Hindus"), and [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), with a majority of [Muslims](/wiki/Muslims "Muslims").[[1]](#cite_note-1) Concurrently the Muslim-majority northwest and east of [British India](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") was separated into the [Dominion of Pakistan](/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan "Dominion of Pakistan"), by the [Partition of India](/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India"). The partition led to a [population transfer](/wiki/Population_transfer "Population transfer") of more than 10 million people between India and Pakistan and the death of about one million people. [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") leader [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") became the first [Prime Minister of India](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India"), but the leader most associated with the [independence struggle](/wiki/Indian_independence_movement "Indian independence movement"), [Mahatma Gandhi](/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi"), accepted no office. The [constitution adopted in 1950](/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India") made [India](/wiki/India "India") a democratic republic with [Westminster style parliamentary system of government](/wiki/Westminster_system "Westminster system"), both at federal and state level respectively. The democracy has been sustained since then. India's sustained democratic freedoms are unique among the world's newly independent states,[[2]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304-2) despite its history being perforated by several crises and recent worries of [democratic backsliding](/wiki/Democratic_backsliding "Democratic backsliding") under the premiership of [Narendra Modi](/wiki/Narendra_Modi "Narendra Modi").[[3]](#cite_note-3)

The country has faced [religious violence](/wiki/Religious_violence_in_India "Religious violence in India"), [corruption](/wiki/Corruption_in_India "Corruption in India"), [poverty](/wiki/Poverty_in_India "Poverty in India"), [unemployment](/wiki/Unemployment_in_India "Unemployment in India"), [language conflicts](/wiki/Language_conflicts_in_India "Language conflicts in India"), [naxalism](/wiki/Naxalite "Naxalite"), [terrorism](/wiki/Terrorism_in_India "Terrorism in India"), [separatist insurgencies in North East India](/wiki/Insurgency_in_Northeast_India "Insurgency in Northeast India") and [gender-based violence](/wiki/Gender-based_violence_in_India "Gender-based violence in India"). India has unresolved [territorial disputes](/wiki/Territorial_disputes_of_India "Territorial disputes of India") over [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir_conflict "Kashmir conflict") and [Arunachal Pradesh](/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh "Arunachal Pradesh") with [China](/wiki/China "China") which escalated into a war in [1962](/wiki/1962_Sino-Indian_War "1962 Sino-Indian War") and [1967](/wiki/Nathu_La_and_Cho_La_clashes "Nathu La and Cho La clashes"), [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir_conflict "Kashmir conflict") with Pakistan which resulted in wars in [1947–1948](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1947%E2%80%931948 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1947–1948"), [1965](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1965"), [1971](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1971") and [1999](/wiki/Kargil_War "Kargil War") and [Kalapani](/wiki/Kalapani_territory "Kalapani territory") with [Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal"). India was neutral in the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War_in_Asia "Cold War in Asia"), and was a leader in the [Non-Aligned Movement](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned Movement"). However, it [made a loose alliance](/wiki/Indo-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship_and_Cooperation "Indo-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation") with the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") from 1971, when Pakistan was allied with the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") and the [People's Republic of China](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's Republic of China").

India is [a nuclear-weapon state](/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons "List of states with nuclear weapons"), having conducted its first [nuclear test](/wiki/Operation_Smiling_Buddha "Operation Smiling Buddha") in 1974, followed by [another five tests](/wiki/Pokhran-II "Pokhran-II") in 1998. From the 1950s to the 1980s, India followed [socialist](/wiki/Socialist_economics "Socialist economics")-inspired policies. The economy was influenced by [extensive regulation](/wiki/Licence_Raj "Licence Raj"), [protectionism](/wiki/Protectionism "Protectionism") and public ownership, leading to pervasive [corruption](/wiki/Corruption_in_India "Corruption in India") and slow economic growth. Since 1991, [India has pursued more economic liberalisation](/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India "Economic liberalisation in India"). Today, India is the [third largest](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP) "List of countries by GDP (PPP)") and one of the [fastest-growing economies](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate "List of countries by real GDP growth rate") in the world.

From being a relatively struggling country in its formative years,[[4]](#cite_note-Fisher2018-8-4) the Republic of India has emerged as a fast growing [G20](/wiki/G20 "G20") major economy.[[5]](#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2012-265-5)[[6]](#cite_note-6) India has sometimes been referred to as a [great power](/wiki/Great_power "Great power") and a [potential superpower](/wiki/Potential_superpower "Potential superpower") given its large and growing economy, military and population.[[7]](#cite_note-7)[[8]](#cite_note-8)[[9]](#cite_note-9)[[10]](#cite_note-10)

## 1947–1950: Dominion of India

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: 1947–1950: Dominion of India")]

Main article: [Dominion of India](/wiki/Dominion_of_India "Dominion of India")

Independent India's first years were marked with turbulent events—a massive exchange of population with Pakistan, the [Indo-Pakistani War of 1947](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1947 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1947") and the integration of over 500 [princely states](/wiki/Princely_state "Princely state") to form a united nation.[[11]](#cite_note-11) [Vallabhbhai Patel](/wiki/Vallabhbhai_Patel "Vallabhbhai Patel"), [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") and [Mahatma Gandhi](/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi") also ensured that the constitution of independent India would be secular.[[12]](#cite_note-12)

### Partition of India

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Partition of India")]

Main article: [Partition of India](/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India")

The partition of India was outlined in the [Indian Independence Act 1947](/wiki/Indian_Independence_Act_1947 "Indian Independence Act 1947"). It led to the dissolution of the [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") in [South Asia](/wiki/South_Asia "South Asia") and the creation of two independent [dominions](/wiki/Dominion "Dominion"): [India](/wiki/Dominion_of_India "Dominion of India") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan "Dominion of Pakistan").[[13]](#cite_note-fisher-partition-13)[[14]](#cite_note-khan-great-partition-14) The change of political borders notably included the division of two provinces of [British India](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj"),[[a]](#cite_note-15) [Bengal](/wiki/Bengal_Presidency "Bengal Presidency") and [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab_Province_(British_India) "Punjab Province (British India)").[[*[[Wikipedia:Citing\_sources|page needed]]*]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETalbotSingh2009[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_November_2022]]<sup_class=)-16">[15] The majority [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") districts in these provinces were awarded to Pakistan and the majority non-Muslim to India. The other assets that were divided included the [British Indian Army](/wiki/British_Indian_Army "British Indian Army"), the [Royal Indian Navy](/wiki/Royal_Indian_Navy "Royal Indian Navy"), the [Royal Indian Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Indian_Air_Force "Royal Indian Air Force"), the [Indian Civil Service](/wiki/Indian_Civil_Service "Indian Civil Service"), the [railways](/wiki/Rail_transport_in_India#History "Rail transport in India"), and the central treasury. Self-governing independent Pakistan and India legally came into existence at midnight on 14 and 15 August 1947 respectively.

The partition caused large-scale loss of life and an unprecedented migration between the two dominions.[[16]](#cite_note-chaterjee-washbrook-18) Among refugees who survived, it solidified the belief that safety lay among co-religionists. In the instance of Pakistan, it made palpable a hitherto only-imagined refuge for the Muslims of British India.[[17]](#cite_note-metcalf&metcalt-partition-19) The migrations took place hastily and with little warning. It is thought that between 14 million and 18 million people moved, and perhaps more. [Excess mortality](/wiki/Excess_mortality "Excess mortality") during the period of the partition is usually estimated to have been around one million.[[18]](#cite_note-dyson-partition-demographics-20) The violent nature of the partition created an atmosphere of hostility and suspicion between India and Pakistan that affects [their relationship](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_relations "Indo-Pakistani relations") to this day.

An estimated 3.5 million[[19]](#cite_note-Encarta-21) Hindus and [Sikhs](/wiki/Sikhs "Sikhs") living in [West Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan "Punjab, Pakistan"), [North-West Frontier Province](/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa "Khyber Pakhtunkhwa"), [Baluchistan](/wiki/Baluchistan_(Chief_Commissioner%27s_Province) "Baluchistan (Chief Commissioner's Province)"), [East Bengal](/wiki/East_Bengal "East Bengal") and [Sind](/wiki/History_of_Sindh "History of Sindh") migrated to India in fear of domination and suppression in Muslim Pakistan. Communal violence killed an estimated one million Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs, and gravely destabilised both dominions along their [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_India "Punjab, India") and [Bengal](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal") boundaries, and the cities of [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta "Calcutta"), Delhi and [Lahore](/wiki/Lahore "Lahore"). The violence was stopped by early September owing to the co-operative efforts of both Indian and Pakistani leaders, and especially due to the efforts of [Mohandas Gandhi](/wiki/Mohandas_Gandhi "Mohandas Gandhi"), the leader of the Indian freedom struggle, who undertook a *fast-unto-death* in Calcutta and later in Delhi to calm people and emphasise peace despite the threat to his life. Both governments constructed large relief camps for incoming and leaving refugees, and the [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army") was mobilised to provide humanitarian assistance on a massive scale.

> I find no parallel in history for a body of converts and their descendants claiming to be a nation apart from the parent stock.

— [Mahatma Gandhi](/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi"), [opposing the division of India](/wiki/Opposition_to_the_partition_of_India "Opposition to the partition of India") on the basis of religion in 1945.[[20]](#cite_note-Prasoon2010-22)

The [assassination of Mohandas Gandhi](/wiki/Assassination_of_Mahatma_Gandhi "Assassination of Mahatma Gandhi") on 30 January 1948 was carried out by [Nathuram Godse](/wiki/Nathuram_Godse "Nathuram Godse"), who held him responsible for partition and charged that Mohandas Gandhi was appeasing Muslims. More than one million people flooded the streets of Delhi to follow the procession to cremation grounds and pay their last respects.

In 1949, India recorded almost 1 million Hindu refugees into [West Bengal](/wiki/West_Bengal "West Bengal") and other states from [East Pakistan](/wiki/East_Pakistan "East Pakistan"), owing to communal violence, intimidation, and repression from Muslim authorities. The plight of the refugees outraged Hindus and Indian nationalists, and the refugee population drained the resources of Indian states, who were unable to absorb them. While not ruling out war, Prime Minister Nehru and Sardar Patel invited [Liaquat Ali Khan](/wiki/Liaquat_Ali_Khan "Liaquat Ali Khan") for talks in Delhi. Although many Indians termed this [appeasement](/wiki/Appeasement "Appeasement"), Nehru signed a pact with Liaquat Ali Khan that pledged both nations to the protection of minorities and creation of minority commissions. Although opposed to the principle, Patel decided to back this pact for the sake of peace, and played a critical role in garnering support from West Bengal and across India, and enforcing the provisions of the pact. Khan and Nehru also signed a trade agreement, and committed to resolving bilateral disputes through peaceful means. Steadily, hundreds of thousands of Hindus returned to East Pakistan, but the thaw in relations did not last long, primarily owing to the Kashmir dispute.
