### Integration of princely states

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Integration of princely states")]

Main article: [Political integration of India](/wiki/Political_integration_of_India "Political integration of India")

In July 1946, [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") pointedly observed that no princely state could prevail militarily against the army of independent India.[[21]](#cite_note-books.google.co.in-23) In January 1947, Nehru said that independent India would not accept the [divine right of kings](/wiki/Divine_right_of_kings "Divine right of kings").[[22]](#cite_note-24) In May 1947, he declared that any princely state which refused to join the [Constituent Assembly](/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_India "Constituent Assembly of India") would be treated as an enemy state.[[23]](#cite_note-25) [British India](/wiki/British_India "British India") consisted of 17 provinces, which existed alongside 565 [princely states](/wiki/Princely_state "Princely state"). The provinces were given to India or Pakistan, in two particular cases—[Punjab](/wiki/Punjab_Province_(British_India) "Punjab Province (British India)") and [Bengal](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal")—after being partitioned. The princes of the princely states, however, were given the right to either remain independent or accede to either dominion. Thus India's leaders were faced with the prospect of inheriting a fragmented country with independent states and kingdoms dispersed across the mainland. Under the leadership of [Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel](/wiki/Sardar_Vallabhbhai_Patel "Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel"), the new Government of India employed political negotiations backed with the option (and, on several occasions, the use) of military action to ensure the primacy of the central government and of the Constitution then being drafted. Sardar Patel and [V. P. Menon](/wiki/V._P._Menon "V. P. Menon") convinced the rulers of princely states contiguous to India to accede to India. Many rights and privileges of the rulers of the princely states, especially their personal estates and privy purses, were guaranteed to convince them to accede. Some of them were made [Rajpramukh](/wiki/Rajpramukh "Rajpramukh") (governor) and Uprajpramukh (deputy governor) of the merged states. Many small princely states were merged to form viable administrative states such as [Saurashra](/wiki/Saurashtra_(region) "Saurashtra (region)"), [PEPSU](/wiki/Patiala_and_East_Punjab_States_Union "Patiala and East Punjab States Union"), [Vindhya Pradesh](/wiki/Vindhya_Pradesh "Vindhya Pradesh") and [Madhya Bharat](/wiki/Madhya_Bharat "Madhya Bharat"). Some princely states such as [Tripura](/wiki/Tripura_(princely_state) "Tripura (princely state)") and [Manipur](/wiki/Manipur_(princely_state) "Manipur (princely state)") acceded later in 1949.

There were three states that proved more difficult to integrate than others:

1. [Junagadh](/wiki/Junagadh "Junagadh") (Hindu-majority state with a Muslim Nawab)—a December 1947 [plebiscite](/wiki/Plebiscite "Plebiscite") resulted in a 99% vote[[24]](#cite_note-RJ-26) to merge with India, annulling the controversial accession to Pakistan, which was made by the [Nawab](/wiki/Nawab "Nawab") against the wishes of the people of the state who were overwhelmingly [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu") and despite Junagadh not being contiguous with Pakistan.
2. [Hyderabad](/wiki/Hyderabad_State "Hyderabad State") (Hindu-majority state with a Muslim nizam)—Patel ordered the Indian army to depose the government of the [Nizam](/wiki/Nizam "Nizam"), code-named [Operation Polo](/wiki/Operation_Polo "Operation Polo"), after the failure of negotiations, which was done between 13 and 29 September 1948. It was incorporated as a state of India the next year.
3. The state of [Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(princely_state) "Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)") (a Muslim-majority state with a Hindu king) in the far north of the subcontinent quickly became a source of controversy that erupted into the [First Indo-Pakistani War](/wiki/First_Indo-Pakistani_War "First Indo-Pakistani War") which lasted from 1947 to 1949. Eventually, a United Nations-overseen ceasefire was agreed that left India in control of two-thirds of the contested region. [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") initially agreed to [Mountbatten's](/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma "Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma") proposal that a plebiscite be held in the entire state as soon as hostilities ceased, and a UN-sponsored cease-fire was agreed to by both parties on 1 January 1949. No statewide plebiscite was held, however, for in 1954, after Pakistan began to receive arms from the United States, Nehru withdrew his support. The Indian Constitution came into force in Kashmir on 26 January 1950 with special clauses for the state.

### Constitution

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Constitution")]

Main article: [Constitution of India](/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India")

The Constitution of India was adopted by the [Constituent Assembly](/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_India "Constituent Assembly of India") on 26 November 1949 and became effective on 26 January 1950.[[25]](#cite_note-law_min_intro-27) The constitution replaced the [Government of India Act 1935](/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1935 "Government of India Act 1935") as the country's fundamental governing document, and the [Dominion of India](/wiki/Dominion_of_India "Dominion of India") became the [Republic of India](/wiki/India "India"). To ensure [constitutional autochthony](/wiki/Constitutional_autochthony "Constitutional autochthony"), its framers repealed prior acts of the [British parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United Kingdom") in Article 395.[[26]](#cite_note-28) The constitution declares India a [sovereign](/wiki/Sovereignty "Sovereignty"), [socialist](/wiki/Democratic_socialism "Democratic socialism"), secular,[[27]](#cite_note-29) and democratic republic, assures its citizens [justice](/wiki/Justice "Justice"), [equality](/wiki/Equality_before_the_law "Equality before the law"), and [liberty](/wiki/Liberty "Liberty"), and endeavours to promote [fraternity](/wiki/Fraternity "Fraternity").[[28]](#cite_note-30) Key features of the constitution were [Universal suffrage](/wiki/Universal_suffrage "Universal suffrage") for all adults,[Westminster style parliamentary system of government](/wiki/Westminster_system "Westminster system") at the federal and state level, and independent judiciary.[[29]](#cite_note-Atul_Kohli-31) [Indian judiciary](/wiki/Indian_judiciary "Indian judiciary") continues to suffer [pendency of court cases](/wiki/Pendency_of_court_cases_in_India "Pendency of court cases in India"). The constitution also required the [Union Government](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of India") and the [States and Territories of India](/wiki/States_and_Territories_of_India "States and Territories of India") to set *reserved quotas or seats*, at particular percentage in Education Admissions, Employments, Political Bodies, Promotions, etc., for "socially and educationally backward citizens."[[30]](#cite_note-32)[[31]](#cite_note-33) The constitution has had [more than 100 amendments](/wiki/List_of_amendments_of_the_Constitution_of_India "List of amendments of the Constitution of India") since it was enacted.[[32]](#cite_note-amendments-34) India celebrates its constitution on 26 January as [Republic Day](/wiki/Republic_Day_(India) "Republic Day (India)").[[33]](#cite_note-Hari_Das-35)

### Indo-Pakistani War of 1947–1948

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Indo-Pakistani War of 1947–1948")]

Main article: [Indo-Pakistani War of 1947–1948](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1947%E2%80%931948 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1947–1948")

The Indo-Pakistani War of 1947–1948 was fought between [India](/wiki/Dominion_of_India "Dominion of India") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan "Dominion of Pakistan") over the [princely state](/wiki/Princely_state "Princely state") of [Kashmir and Jammu](/wiki/Kashmir_and_Jammu_(princely_state) "Kashmir and Jammu (princely state)") from 1947 to 1948. It was the first of four [Indo-Pakistan Wars](/wiki/Indo-Pakistan_Wars "Indo-Pakistan Wars") fought between the two [newly independent nations](/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India"). Pakistan precipitated the war a few weeks after independence by launching tribal *lashkar* (militia) from [Waziristan](/wiki/Waziristan "Waziristan"),[[34]](#cite_note-36) in an effort to secure Kashmir, the future of which hung in the balance. A United Nations-mediated ceasefire took place on 5 January 1949.

Indian losses in the war totalled 1,104 killed and 3,154 wounded;[[35]](#cite_note-Kargil_from_Surprise_to_Victory-37) Pakistani, about 6,000 killed and 14,000 wounded.[[36]](#cite_note-Honor_and_Glory-38) Neutral assessments state India emerged victorious as it successfully defended the majority of the contested territory.[[37]](#cite_note-Kulke-39)[[38]](#cite_note-Wilcox-40)[[39]](#cite_note-New_Zealand_Defence_Quarterly-41)[[40]](#cite_note-War_bellies:_the_critical_relationship_between_resolve_and_domestic_audiences-42)[[41]](#cite_note-The_Global_Rise_of_Asian_Transformation:_Trends_and_Developments_in_Economic_Growth_Dynamics-43)

## Governance and politics

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Governance and politics")]

India held its first national elections under the Constitution in [1952](/wiki/1951%E2%80%9352_Indian_general_election "1951–52 Indian general election"), where a turnout of over 60% was recorded. The [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") won an overwhelming majority, and [Jawaharlal Nehru](/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") began a second term as prime minister. President Prasad was also elected to a second term by the electoral college of the first [Parliament of India](/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of India").[[42]](#cite_note-44)

### Nehru administration (1952–1964)

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Nehru administration (1952–1964)")]

Nehru can be regarded as the founder of the modern Indian state. Parekh attributes this to the national philosophy Nehru formulated for India. For him, modernisation was the national philosophy, with seven goals: national unity, parliamentary democracy, industrialisation, socialism, development of the scientific temper, and non-alignment in the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"). In Parekh's opinion, the philosophy and the policies that resulted from this benefited a large section of society such as public sector workers, industrial houses, and middle and upper peasantry. However, it failed to benefit or satisfy the urban and rural poor, the unemployed and the [Hindu nationalists and fundamentalists](/wiki/Hindutva "Hindutva").[[43]](#cite_note-45)

The death of Vallabhbhai Patel in 1950 left Nehru as the sole remaining iconic national leader, and soon the situation became such that Nehru could implement his vision for India without hindrance.[[44]](#cite_note-46)

Nehru implemented economic policies based on [import substitution industrialisation](/wiki/Import_substitution_industrialization "Import substitution industrialization") and advocated a [mixed economy](/wiki/Mixed_economy "Mixed economy") where the government-controlled [public sector](/wiki/Public_sector "Public sector") would co-exist with the [private sector](/wiki/Private_sector "Private sector").[[45]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGhose1993243-47) He believed the establishment of basic and heavy industry was fundamental to the development and modernisation of the Indian economy. The government, therefore, directed investment primarily into key [public sector](/wiki/Public_sector_undertakings_in_India "Public sector undertakings in India") industries—steel, iron, coal, and power—promoting their development with subsidies and protectionist policies.[[46]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKopstein2005364-48)

Nehru led the Congress to further election victories in 1957 and 1962. During his tenure, the Indian Parliament passed extensive reforms that increased the legal rights of women in Hindu society,[[47]](#cite_note-49)[[48]](#cite_note-50)[[49]](#cite_note-51)[[50]](#cite_note-52) and further legislated against caste discrimination and [untouchability](/wiki/Dalit "Dalit").[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*] Nehru advocated a strong initiative to enroll India's children to complete primary education, and thousands of schools, colleges and institutions of advanced learning, such as the [Indian Institutes of Technology](/wiki/Indian_Institutes_of_Technology "Indian Institutes of Technology"), were founded across the nation.[[51]](#cite_note-53) Nehru advocated a socialist model for the [economy of India](/wiki/Economy_of_India "Economy of India"). After India achieved independence, a formal model of planning was adopted, and accordingly the [Planning Commission](/wiki/Planning_Commission_(India) "Planning Commission (India)"), reporting directly to the Prime Minister, was established in 1950, with Nehru as the chairman. The commission was tasked with formulating [Five-Year Plans](/wiki/Five-Year_Plans_of_India "Five-Year Plans of India") for economic development which were shaped by the [Soviet model](/wiki/Five-year_plans_of_the_Soviet_Union "Five-year plans of the Soviet Union") based on centralised and integrated national economic programs[[52]](#cite_note-54)—no taxation for Indian farmers, minimum wage and benefits for blue-collar workers, and the [nationalisation](/wiki/Nationalisation "Nationalisation") of heavy industries such as steel, aviation, shipping, electricity, and mining. Village [common lands](/wiki/Commons "Commons") were seized, and an extensive public works and industrialisation campaign resulted in the construction of major dams, irrigation canals, roads, thermal and hydroelectric power stations, and many more.[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

### States reorganisation

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: States reorganisation")]

Main article: [States Reorganisation Act, 1956](/wiki/States_Reorganisation_Act,_1956 "States Reorganisation Act, 1956")

[Potti Sreeramulu](/wiki/Potti_Sreeramulu "Potti Sreeramulu")'s *fast-unto-death*, and consequent death for the demand of an [Andhra State](/wiki/Andhra_State "Andhra State") in 1952 sparked a major re-shaping of the Indian Union. Nehru appointed the States Re-organisation Commission, upon whose recommendations the [States Reorganisation Act](/wiki/States_Reorganisation_Act,_1956 "States Reorganisation Act, 1956") was passed in 1956. Old states were dissolved and new states created on the lines of shared linguistic and ethnic demographics. The separation of [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala "Kerala") and the [Telugu](/wiki/Telugu_language "Telugu language")-speaking regions of [Madras State](/wiki/Madras_State "Madras State") enabled the creation of an exclusively [Tamil](/wiki/Tamil_language "Tamil language")-speaking state of [Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu "Tamil Nadu"). On 1 May 1960, the states of [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra") and [Gujarat](/wiki/Gujarat "Gujarat") were created out of the bilingual [Bombay State](/wiki/Bombay_State "Bombay State"), and on 1 November 1966, the larger [Punjab](/wiki/East_Punjab "East Punjab") state was divided into the smaller, [Punjabi](/wiki/Punjabi_language "Punjabi language")-speaking [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_India "Punjab, India") and [Haryanvi](/wiki/Haryanvi_language "Haryanvi language")-speaking [Haryana](/wiki/Haryana "Haryana") states.[[53]](#cite_note-55)

### Development of a multi-party system

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Development of a multi-party system")]

In pre-independence India, the main parties were the Congress and the Muslim league. There were also many other parties such as the [Hindu mahasabha](/wiki/Hindu_mahasabha "Hindu mahasabha"), [Justice party](/wiki/Justice_Party_(India) "Justice Party (India)"), the [Akali dal](/wiki/Shiromani_Akali_Dal "Shiromani Akali Dal"), the [Communist party](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India "Communist Party of India") etc. during this period with limited or regional appeal. With the eclipse of the Muslim league due to partition, the Congress party was able to dominate Indian politics during the 1950s. This started breaking down during the 60s and 70s.This period saw formation of many new parties. These included those founded by former congress leaders such as the Swatantra party, many Socialist leaning parties, and the [Bharatiya Jan Sangh](/wiki/Bharatiya_Jan_Sangh "Bharatiya Jan Sangh"), the political arm of the Hindu nationalist [RSS](/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh "Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh").[[54]](#cite_note-56)

#### Swatantra Party

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Swatantra Party")]

Main articles: [C. Rajagopalachari](/wiki/C._Rajagopalachari "C. Rajagopalachari") and [Swatantra Party](/wiki/Swatantra_Party "Swatantra Party")

On 4 June 1959, shortly after the Nagpur session of the Indian National Congress, [C. Rajagopalachari](/wiki/C._Rajagopalachari "C. Rajagopalachari"),[[55]](#cite_note-Guha2011-57) along with Murari Vaidya of the newly established Forum of Free Enterprise (FFE)[[56]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp66-58) and [Minoo Masani](/wiki/Minoo_Masani "Minoo Masani"), a [classical liberal](/wiki/Classical_liberal "Classical liberal") and critic of socialist leaning Nehru, announced the formation of the new [Swatantra Party](/wiki/Swatantra_Party "Swatantra Party") at a meeting in Madras.[[57]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp65-59) Conceived by disgruntled heads of former princely states such as the Raja of Ramgarh, the Maharaja of Kalahandi and the Maharajadhiraja of Darbhanga, the party was conservative in character.[[58]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp74-60)[[59]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp72-61) Later, [N. G. Ranga](/wiki/N._G._Ranga "N. G. Ranga"), [K. M. Munshi](/wiki/K._M._Munshi "K. M. Munshi"), [Field Marshal](/wiki/Field_marshal_(India) "Field marshal (India)") [K. M. Cariappa](/wiki/K._M._Cariappa "K. M. Cariappa") and the Maharaja of Patiala joined the effort.[[59]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp72-61) Rajagopalachari, Masani and Ranga also tried but failed to involve [Jayaprakash Narayan](/wiki/Jayaprakash_Narayan "Jayaprakash Narayan") in the initiative.[[60]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp78-62)

In his short essay "Our Democracy", Rajagopalachari argued the necessity of a right-wing alternative to the Congress: "since ... the Congress Party has swung to the Left, what is wanted is not an ultra or outer-Left [viz. the CPI or the Praja Socialist Party, PSP], but a strong and articulate Right."[[58]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp74-60) Rajagopalachari also said the opposition must: "operate not privately and behind the closed doors of the party meeting, but openly and periodically through the electorate."[[58]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp74-60) He outlined the goals of the Swatantra Party through twenty-one "fundamental principles" in the foundation document.[[61]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp188-63) The party stood for equality and opposed government control over the private sector.[[62]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp189-64)[[63]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp190-65) Rajagopalachari sharply criticised the bureaucracy and coined the term "[licence-permit Raj](/wiki/Licence_Raj "Licence Raj")" to describe Nehru's elaborate system of permissions and licences required for an individual to set up a private enterprise. Rajagopalachari's personality became a rallying point for the party.[[58]](#cite_note-swatantraconservatismp74-60)

Rajagopalachari's efforts to build an anti-Congress front led to a patch-up with his former adversary [C. N. Annadurai](/wiki/C._N._Annadurai "C. N. Annadurai") of the [Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam](/wiki/Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam "Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam").[[64]](#cite_note-wisestman_thehindu-66) During the late 1950s and early 1960s, Annadurai grew close to Rajagopalachari and sought an alliance with the Swatantra Party for the [1962 Madras Legislative Assembly elections](/wiki/1962_Madras_Legislative_Assembly_election "1962 Madras Legislative Assembly election"). Although there were occasional electoral pacts between the Swatantra Party and the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK), Rajagopalachari remained non-committal on a formal tie-up with the DMK due to its existing alliance with Communists whom he dreaded.[[65]](#cite_note-socialchangep111-67) The Swatantra Party contested 94 seats in the Madras state assembly elections and won six[[66]](#cite_note-1962electionresults-68) as well as won 18 parliamentary seats in the [1962 Lok Sabha elections](/wiki/1962_Indian_general_election "1962 Indian general election").[[67]](#cite_note-1962elections-69)

### Foreign policy and military conflicts

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Foreign policy and military conflicts")]

See also: [India and the Non-Aligned Movement](/wiki/India_and_the_Non-Aligned_Movement "India and the Non-Aligned Movement"), [List of conflicts in Asia § Republic of India](/wiki/List_of_conflicts_in_Asia#Republic_of_India "List of conflicts in Asia"), and [Indo-Pakistani War of 1965](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1965")

Nehru's foreign policy was the inspiration of the [Non-Aligned Movement](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned Movement"), of which India was a co-founder. Nehru maintained friendly relations with both the United States and the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), and encouraged the People's Republic of China to join the global community of nations. In 1956, when the [Suez Canal Company](/wiki/Suez_Canal_Company "Suez Canal Company") was seized by the Egyptian government, an international conference voted 18–4 to take action against Egypt. India was one of the four backers of Egypt, along with [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"), and the USSR. India had opposed the [partition of Palestine](/wiki/Partition_of_Palestine "Partition of Palestine") and the 1956 invasion of the [Sinai](/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula "Sinai Peninsula") by Israel, the United Kingdom and France, but did not oppose the Chinese direct control over [Tibet](/wiki/Tibet_Autonomous_Region "Tibet Autonomous Region"),[[68]](#cite_note-Joes2006-70) and the suppression of a pro-democracy movement in [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") by the Soviet Union. Although Nehru disavowed nuclear ambitions for India, Canada and France aided India in the development of nuclear power stations for electricity. India also negotiated an agreement in 1960 with Pakistan on the just use of the waters of seven rivers shared by the countries. Nehru had visited Pakistan in 1953, but owing to political turmoil in Pakistan, no headway was made on the Kashmir dispute.[[69]](#cite_note-71)

India has fought a total of four [wars/military conflicts](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_wars_and_conflicts "Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts") with its neighbouring rival state Pakistan, two in this period. In the [Indo-Pakistani War of 1947](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1947 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1947"), fought over the disputed territory of [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir"), Pakistan captured one-third of Kashmir (which India claims as its territory), and India captured three-fifths (which Pakistan claims as its territory). In the [Indo-Pakistani War of 1965](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1965"), India attacked Pakistan on all fronts by crossing the international border after attempts by Pakistani troops to infiltrate Indian-controlled Kashmir by crossing the de facto border between India and Pakistan in Kashmir.

In 1961, after continual petitions for a peaceful handover, India [invaded and annexed](/wiki/Annexation_of_Goa "Annexation of Goa") the Portuguese colony of [Goa](/wiki/Goa "Goa") on the west coast of India.[[70]](#cite_note-Major_K_C_Praval-72)

In 1962 China and India engaged in the brief [Sino-Indian War](/wiki/Sino-Indian_War "Sino-Indian War") over the border in the [Himalayas](/wiki/Himalayas "Himalayas"). The war was a complete rout for the Indians and led to a refocusing on arms build-up and an improvement in relations with the United States. China withdrew from disputed territory in the contested Chinese [South Tibet](/wiki/South_Tibet "South Tibet") and Indian [North-East Frontier Agency](/wiki/North-East_Frontier_Agency "North-East Frontier Agency") that it crossed during the war. India disputes China's sovereignty over the smaller [Aksai Chin](/wiki/Aksai_Chin "Aksai Chin") territory that it controls on the western part of the Sino-Indian border.[[71]](#cite_note-Indo-China_War_of_1962-73)

* Indian Army officers of the 4th Sikh Regiment captured a Police Station in [Lahore, Pakistan](/wiki/Lahore,_Pakistan "Lahore, Pakistan"), after winning the [Battle of Burki](/wiki/Battle_of_Burki "Battle of Burki"), during the [Indo-Pakistani War of 1965](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1965").
* The Indian Air Force used 20 small and lightweight Canberra bombers against the [Portuguese forces](/wiki/Portuguese_Armed_Forces "Portuguese Armed Forces") during [Operation Vijay](/wiki/Operation_Vijay_(1961) "Operation Vijay (1961)"), which led to the Annexation of Goa.
* Disputed areas in the western sector of the Sino-Indian border including [Aksai Chin](/wiki/Aksai_Chin "Aksai Chin"), 1988 [CIA](/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency "Central Intelligence Agency") map

## 1960s after Nehru

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: 1960s after Nehru")]

Jawaharlal Nehru died on 27 May 1964, and [Lal Bahadur Shastri](/wiki/Lal_Bahadur_Shastri "Lal Bahadur Shastri") succeeded him as prime minister. In 1965, India and Pakistan again [went to war over Kashmir](/wiki/Second_Kashmir_War "Second Kashmir War"), but without any definitive outcome or alteration of the Kashmir boundary. The [Tashkent Agreement](/wiki/Tashkent_Agreement "Tashkent Agreement") was signed under the mediation of the Soviet government, but Shastri died on the night after the signing ceremony. A leadership election resulted in the elevation of [Indira Gandhi](/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi"), Nehru's daughter who had been serving as Minister for Information and Broadcasting, as the third prime minister. She defeated right-wing leader [Morarji Desai](/wiki/Morarji_Desai "Morarji Desai"). The Congress Party won a reduced majority in the 1967 elections owing to widespread disenchantment over rising prices of commodities, unemployment, economic stagnation, and food crisis. Indira Gandhi had started on a rocky note after agreeing to a [devaluation](/wiki/Devaluation "Devaluation") of the [rupee](/wiki/Indian_rupee "Indian rupee"), which created much hardship for Indian businesses and consumers, and the import of wheat from the United States fell through due to political disputes.[[72]](#cite_note-Kapila1-74)

In 1967, India and China again engaged with each other in [Sino-Indian War of 1967](/wiki/Nathu_La_and_Cho_La_clashes "Nathu La and Cho La clashes") after the PLA soldiers opened fire on the Indian soldiers who were making a fence on the border in Nathu La. The Indian forces successfully repelled Chinese forces and the outcome saw Chinese defeat with their withdrawal from Sikkim.

Morarji Desai entered Gandhi's government as deputy prime minister and finance minister, and with senior Congress politicians attempted to constrain Gandhi's authority. But following the counsel of her political advisor [P. N. Haksar](/wiki/P._N._Haksar "P. N. Haksar"), Gandhi resuscitated her popular appeal by a major shift towards socialist policies. She successfully ended the [Privy Purse](/wiki/Privy_Purse_in_India "Privy Purse in India") guarantee for former Indian royalty, and waged a major offensive against party hierarchy over the nationalisation of India's banks. Although resisted by Desai and India's business community, the policy was popular with the masses. When Congress politicians attempted to oust Gandhi by suspending her Congress membership, Gandhi was empowered with a large exodus of members of parliament to her own Congress (R). The bastion of the Indian freedom struggle, the [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress"), had split in 1969. Gandhi continued to govern with a slim majority.[[73]](#cite_note-Rosser-75)

## 1970s

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: 1970s")]

In 1971, Indira Gandhi and her Congress (R) were returned to power with a massively increased majority. The nationalisation of banks was carried out, and many other socialist economic and industrial policies enacted. India [intervened](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1971") in the [Bangladesh War of Independence](/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Bangladesh Liberation War"), a civil war taking place in Pakistan's [Bengali](/wiki/East_Bengal "East Bengal") half, after millions of refugees had fled the persecution of the Pakistani army. The clash resulted in the independence of East Pakistan, which became known as [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"), and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's elevation to immense popularity. Relations with the United States grew strained, and India signed a 20-year treaty of friendship with the Soviet Union—breaking explicitly for the first time from non-alignment. In 1974, India tested [its first nuclear weapon](/wiki/India_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "India and weapons of mass destruction") in the desert of [Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan "Rajasthan"), near [Pokhran](/wiki/Pokhran "Pokhran").

### Merger of Sikkim

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Merger of Sikkim")]

In 1973, anti-royalist riots took place in the [Kingdom of Sikkim](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sikkim "Kingdom of Sikkim"). In 1975, the Prime Minister of [Sikkim](/wiki/Sikkim "Sikkim") appealed to the [Indian Parliament](/wiki/Indian_Parliament "Indian Parliament") for Sikkim to become a state of India. In April of that year, the [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army") took over the city of [Gangtok](/wiki/Gangtok "Gangtok") and disarmed the Chogyal's palace guards. Thereafter, [a referendum](/wiki/1975_Sikkimese_monarchy_referendum "1975 Sikkimese monarchy referendum") was held in which 97.5 percent of voters supported abolishing the monarchy, effectively approving union with India.

India is said to have stationed 20,000–40,000 troops in a country of only 200,000 during the referendum.[[74]](#cite_note-76) On 16 May 1975, Sikkim became the 22nd state of the Indian Union, and the monarchy was abolished.[[75]](#cite_note-77) To enable the incorporation of the new state, the [Indian Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of India") amended the [Indian Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India"). First, the [35th Amendment](/wiki/List_of_amendments_of_the_Constitution_of_India "List of amendments of the Constitution of India") laid down a set of conditions that made Sikkim an "associate state", a special designation not used by any other state. A month later, the [36th Amendment](/wiki/List_of_amendments_of_the_Constitution_of_India "List of amendments of the Constitution of India") repealed the 35th Amendment, and made Sikkim a full state, adding its name to the [First Schedule](/wiki/Constitution_of_India#First_Schedule "Constitution of India") of the Constitution.[[76]](#cite_note-78)

### Formation of Northeastern states

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Formation of Northeastern states")]

In the [Northeast India](/wiki/Northeast_India "Northeast India"), the state of [Assam](/wiki/Assam "Assam") was divided into several states beginning in 1970 within the borders of what was then Assam. In 1963, the Naga Hills district became the 16th state of India under the name of [Nagaland](/wiki/Nagaland "Nagaland"). Part of [Tuensang](/wiki/Tuensang "Tuensang") was added to Nagaland. In 1970, in response to the demands of the [Khasi](/wiki/Khasi_people "Khasi people"), [Jaintia](/wiki/Jaintia_people "Jaintia people") and [Garo people](/wiki/Garo_people "Garo people") of the [Meghalaya Plateau](/wiki/Karbi-Meghalaya_Plateau "Karbi-Meghalaya Plateau"), the districts embracing the [Khasi Hills](/wiki/Khasi_Hills "Khasi Hills"), [Jaintia Hills](/wiki/Jaintia_Hills "Jaintia Hills"), and [Garo Hills](/wiki/Garo_Hills "Garo Hills") were formed into an autonomous state within Assam; in 1972 this became a separate state under the name of [Meghalaya](/wiki/Meghalaya "Meghalaya"). In 1972, [Arunachal Pradesh](/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh "Arunachal Pradesh") (the [North-East Frontier Agency](/wiki/North-East_Frontier_Agency "North-East Frontier Agency")) and [Mizoram](/wiki/Mizoram "Mizoram") (from the [Mizo Hills](/wiki/Mizo_Hills "Mizo Hills") in the south) were separated from Assam as union territories; both became states in 1986.[[77]](#cite_note-Bhattacharyya1995-79)

* Assam till the 1950s: The new states of [Nagaland](/wiki/Nagaland "Nagaland"), Meghalaya and [Mizoram](/wiki/Mizoram "Mizoram") formed in the 1960-70s. From [Shillong](/wiki/Shillong "Shillong"), the capital of Assam was shifted to [Dispur](/wiki/Dispur "Dispur"), now a part of [Guwahati](/wiki/Guwahati "Guwahati"). After the [Sino-Indian War](/wiki/Sino-Indian_War "Sino-Indian War") in 1962, [Arunachal Pradesh](/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh "Arunachal Pradesh") was also separated.
* [Hornbill Festival](/wiki/Hornbill_Festival "Hornbill Festival"), [Kohima](/wiki/Kohima "Kohima"), Nagaland. [Nagaland](/wiki/Nagaland "Nagaland") became a state on 1 December 1963.
* *[Pakhangba](/wiki/Pakhangba "Pakhangba")*, a [heraldic](/wiki/Heraldry "Heraldry") dragon of the Meithei tradition and an important emblem among Manipur state symbols. [Manipur](/wiki/Manipur "Manipur") became a state on 21 January 1972.
* Meghalaya is mountainous, the most rain-soaked state of India. [Meghalaya](/wiki/Meghalaya "Meghalaya") became a state on 21 January 1972.
* [Ujjayanta Palace](/wiki/Ujjayanta_Palace "Ujjayanta Palace"), which houses the Tripura State Museum. [Tripura](/wiki/Tripura "Tripura") became a state on 21 January 1972.
* [Golden Pagoda, Namsai](/wiki/Golden_Pagoda,_Namsai "Golden Pagoda, Namsai"), Arunachal Pradesh, is one of the notable [Buddhist temples](/wiki/Buddhist_temple "Buddhist temple") in India. [Arunachal Pradesh](/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh "Arunachal Pradesh") became a state on 20 February 1987.
* A school campus in Mizoram, which has one of the highest literacy rates in India. [Mizoram](/wiki/Mizoram "Mizoram") became a state on 20 February 1987.

The state of [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_India "Punjab, India") led India's [Green Revolution](/wiki/Green_Revolution "Green Revolution") and earned the distinction of being the country's bread basket.[[78]](#cite_note-80)

[Amul](/wiki/Amul "Amul") Dairy Plant at [Anand, Gujarat](/wiki/Anand,_Gujarat "Anand, Gujarat"), was a highly successful co-operative started during [Operation Flood](/wiki/Operation_Flood "Operation Flood") in the 1970s.

### Green revolution and Operation Flood

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Green revolution and Operation Flood")]

Main articles: [Green Revolution in India](/wiki/Green_Revolution_in_India "Green Revolution in India") and [Operation Flood](/wiki/Operation_Flood "Operation Flood")

India's population passed the 500 million mark in the early 1970s, but its long-standing food crisis was resolved with greatly improved agricultural productivity due to the [Green Revolution](/wiki/Green_Revolution_in_India "Green Revolution in India"). The government sponsored modern agricultural implements, new varieties of generic seeds, and increased financial assistance to farmers that increased the yield of food crops such as wheat, rice and corn, as well as commercial crops like cotton, tea, tobacco and coffee.[[79]](#cite_note-81) Increased agricultural productivity expanded across the states of the [Indo-Gangetic Plain](/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain "Indo-Gangetic Plain") and the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_India "Punjab, India").

Under [Operation Flood](/wiki/Operation_Flood "Operation Flood"), the government encouraged the production of milk, which increased greatly, and improved rearing of livestock across India. This enabled India to become self-sufficient in feeding its own population, ending two decades of food imports.[[80]](#cite_note-Katar-82)

### Bangladesh Liberation War

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Bangladesh Liberation War")]

Main article: [Indo-Pakistani War of 1971](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1971")

The [Indo-Pakistani War of 1971](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1971") was the third in four wars fought between the two nations. The war was fought in December 1971 over the issue of Bangladesh. India decisively defeated Pakistan, resulting in the creation of [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh").

The crisis started with Punjabi dominated Pakistani army refusing to surrender power to the newly elected but mainly Bengali [Awami League](/wiki/Awami_League "Awami League") led by Shaikh Mujibur Rehman. [Proclamation of Bangladeshi Independence](/wiki/Proclamation_of_Bangladeshi_Independence "Proclamation of Bangladeshi Independence") in march of 1971 by Rehman led to widespread atrocities being committed by the Pakistani army against select groups. It is estimated that starting in March 1971, members of the Pakistani military and supporting pro-Pakistani Islamist militias [killed between 300,000 and 3,000,000](/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide "1971 Bangladesh genocide") civilians in Bangladesh.[[81]](#cite_note-Women_and_Climate_Change_in_Bangladesh-83)[[82]](#cite_note-Plight_and_Fate_of_Women_During_and_Following_Genocide-84)[[83]](#cite_note-Exploring_Social_Psychology_4E-85)[[84]](#cite_note-86)[[85]](#cite_note-kennedy-87) During the conflict, members of the Pakistani military and supporting pro-Pakistani Islamist militias called the Razakars [raped between 200,000 and 400,000](/wiki/Rape_during_the_Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Rape during the Bangladesh Liberation War") [Bangladeshi](/wiki/Bangladeshis "Bangladeshis") women and girls in a systematic campaign of [genocidal rape](/wiki/Genocidal_rape "Genocidal rape").[[86]](#cite_note-88)[[87]](#cite_note-89)[[88]](#cite_note-90)[[89]](#cite_note-91) The murders and rapes led to an estimated eight to ten million people to flee East Pakistan to seek refuge in India.[[90]](#cite_note-Rummel-8-2-92)[[91]](#cite_note-93)[[92]](#cite_note-94)[[93]](#cite_note-95)[[94]](#cite_note-96)

Official de-jure war began with [Pakistan airforce](/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force "Pakistan Air Force")-affiliated [Operation Chengiz Khan](/wiki/Operation_Chengiz_Khan "Operation Chengiz Khan"), which consisted of preemptive aerial strikes on 11 [Indian air stations](/wiki/List_of_Indian_Air_Force_stations "List of Indian Air Force stations") resulting in minor damages and suspension of counter-air operations for mere few hours.[[95]](#cite_note-:9-97) The strikes led to India declaring war on Pakistan, marking their entry into the war for East Pakistan's independence, on the side of [Bengali nationalist forces](/wiki/Bangladesh_Forces "Bangladesh Forces"). India's entry expanded the existing conflict with Indian and Pakistani forces engaging on both the eastern and western fronts.[[96]](#cite_note-time27Dec1971-98) Thirteen days into the war, India had achieved total superiority into the [East](/wiki/East_Pakistan "East Pakistan") meanwhile it had sufficient superiority in the [West](/wiki/West_Pakistan "West Pakistan"), which resulted later in [Eastern defence](/wiki/Pakistan_Eastern_Command "Pakistan Eastern Command") of [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_Armed_Forces "Pakistan Armed Forces") to sign a joint [instrument of surrender](/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_(1971) "Instrument of Surrender (1971)").[[97]](#cite_note-99)[[98]](#cite_note-100) on 16 December 1971 in Dhaka, ending conflict officially and marking the [formation of East Pakistan](/wiki/Independence_of_Bangladesh "Independence of Bangladesh") as the new nation of [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"). Approximately 93,000 Pakistani servicemen were [taken prisoner](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971_Prisoners_of_War_Investigation "Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 Prisoners of War Investigation") by the [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army"), which included 79,676 to 81,000 uniformed personnel of the Pakistan Armed Forces, including some Bengali soldiers who had remained loyal to Pakistan.[[99]](#cite_note-101)[[100]](#cite_note-:1-102) The remaining 10,324 to 12,500 [prisoners](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war") were civilians, either family members of the military personnel or collaborators ([Razakars](/wiki/Razakar_(Pakistan) "Razakar (Pakistan)")).[[101]](#cite_note-The_Daily_Star-103)[[102]](#cite_note-Haqqani2005p87-104)[[103]](#cite_note-105)

### Indian Emergency

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Indian Emergency")]

Main article: [Indian Emergency](/wiki/Indian_Emergency "Indian Emergency")

#### Prelude to the Emergency

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Prelude to the Emergency")]

India in the first half of the 1970s faced high inflation caused by the [1973 oil crisis](/wiki/1973_oil_crisis "1973 oil crisis") which resulted in cost of oil imports to rise substantially, the cost of the Bangladesh war and the refugee resettlement, and food shortages caused by droughts in parts of the country. The economic and social problems caused by high inflation, as well as allegations of corruption against Indira Gandhi and her government, caused increasing political unrest across India during 1973–74. This included the [Railway Strike in 1974](/wiki/1974_railway_strike_in_India "1974 railway strike in India"), the [Maoist Naxalite movement](/wiki/Naxalite%E2%80%93Maoist_insurgency "Naxalite–Maoist insurgency"), the [Bihar student agitations](/wiki/Bihar_Movement "Bihar Movement"), the United Women's Anti- Price Rise Front in Maharashtra and the [Nav Nirman movement](/wiki/Navnirman_Andolan "Navnirman Andolan") in Gujarat.[[104]](#cite_note-106)[[105]](#cite_note-107)

[Raj Narain](/wiki/Raj_Narain "Raj Narain") was the [Samyukta Socialist Party](/wiki/Samyukta_Socialist_Party "Samyukta Socialist Party") Candidate and Indira's opponent in the 1971 [Lok Sabha](/wiki/Lok_Sabha "Lok Sabha") elections from [Rai Bareli](/wiki/Raebareli_(Lok_Sabha_constituency) "Raebareli (Lok Sabha constituency)"). Although he suffered a defeat from her in 1971 elections, he accused [Indira Gandhi](/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi") of corrupt electoral practices and filed an [election petition](/wiki/State_of_Uttar_Pradesh_v._Raj_Narain "State of Uttar Pradesh v. Raj Narain") against her. Four years later on 12 June 1975, the [Allahabad](/wiki/Allahabad "Allahabad") High Court gave their verdict, and found Indira Gandhi guilty of misusing government machinery for election purposes.[[106]](#cite_note-B-108) Opposition parties conducted nationwide strikes and protests demanding her immediate resignation. Various political parties united under [Jaya Prakash Narayan](/wiki/Jaya_Prakash_Narayan "Jaya Prakash Narayan") to resist what he termed Gandhi's dictatorship. Leading strikes across India that paralysed its economy and administration, Narayan even called for the Army to oust Gandhi.

#### Declaration of the emergency

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Declaration of the emergency")]

On 25 June 1975, Gandhi advised President [Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed](/wiki/Fakhruddin_Ali_Ahmed "Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed") to declare a [state of emergency](/wiki/State_of_emergency "State of emergency") under the constitution, which allowed the central government to assume sweeping powers to defend law and order in the nation. Explaining the breakdown of law and order and threat to national security as her primary reasons, Gandhi suspended many [civil liberties](/wiki/Civil_liberties "Civil liberties") and postponed elections at national and state levels.[[107]](#cite_note-A-109)[[108]](#cite_note-LOC-110) Non-Congress governments in Indian states were dismissed, and nearly 1,000 opposition political leaders and activists were imprisoned.[[109]](#cite_note-111) Her government also introduced a contentious programme of compulsory birth control.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)[[111]](#cite_note-hindustantimes.com-113)[[112]](#cite_note-Tarlo_2000_266-114)[[113]](#cite_note-University_of_California_Press-115)[[114]](#cite_note-Gwatkin,_Davidson_R_1979-116)[[115]](#cite_note-India_:_a_portrait-117) Strikes and public protests were outlawed in all forms.

#### Life during the emergency

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Life during the emergency")]

India's economy benefited from an end to paralysing strikes and political disorder. India announced a 20-point programme which enhanced agricultural and industrial production, increasing national growth, productivity, and job growth. But many organs of government and many Congress politicians were accused of corruption and authoritarian conduct. Police officers were accused of arresting and torturing innocent people. Indira's then twentynine year old son, and unofficial political advisor, [Sanjay Gandhi](/wiki/Sanjay_Gandhi "Sanjay Gandhi"), was accused of committing gross excesses—Sanjay was blamed for the Health Ministry carrying out forced [vasectomies](/wiki/Vasectomies "Vasectomies") of men and [sterilisation](/wiki/Sterilization_(medicine) "Sterilization (medicine)") of women as a part of the initiative to control population growth, and for the demolition of slums in Delhi near the Turkmen Gate, which left hundreds of people dead or injured, and many more displaced.[[111]](#cite_note-hindustantimes.com-113)[[112]](#cite_note-Tarlo_2000_266-114)[[113]](#cite_note-University_of_California_Press-115)[[114]](#cite_note-Gwatkin,_Davidson_R_1979-116)[[115]](#cite_note-India_:_a_portrait-117)[[116]](#cite_note-118)[[117]](#cite_note-119)

### Janata interlude

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Janata interlude")]

Main article: [Janata Party](/wiki/Janata_Party "Janata Party")

Indira Gandhi's Congress Party called for general elections in 1977, only to suffer a humiliating electoral defeat at the hands of the [Janata Party](/wiki/Janata_Party "Janata Party"), an [amalgamation](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/amalgamation "wikt:amalgamation") of opposition parties.[[118]](#cite_note-120) [Morarji Desai](/wiki/Morarji_Desai "Morarji Desai") became the first non-Congress Prime Minister of India. The Desai administration established tribunals to investigate Emergency-era abuses, and Indira and Sanjay Gandhi were arrested after a report from the [Shah Commission](/wiki/Shah_Commission "Shah Commission").[[119]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen2002139-121)

In economic policy the Janata government had lesser success in achieving economic reforms. It launched the Sixth Five-Year Plan, aiming to boost agricultural production and rural industries. Seeking to promote economic self-reliance and indigenous industries, the government required multi-national corporations to go into partnership with Indian corporations. The policy proved controversial, diminishing foreign investment and led to the high-profile exit of corporations such as [Coca-Cola](/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola") and [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") from India.[[120]](#cite_note-IMM-122)

The Janata party government under Morarji Desai Desai restored normal relations with China, for the first time since [the 1962 war](/wiki/Sino-Indian_War "Sino-Indian War").Desai also established friendlier relationship with the military ruler of Pakistan, General [Zia-ul-Haq](/wiki/Muhammad_Zia-ul-Haq "Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq").Despite his pacifist leanings, Desai refused to sign the non-nuclear proliferation treaty despite the threat of stopping supply of uranium for power plants by the USA Congress.[[121]](#cite_note-Alam1988-123)

In 1979, the Janata coalition crumbled and [Charan Singh](/wiki/Charan_Singh "Charan Singh") formed an interim government. The Janata Party had become intensely unpopular due to its internecine warfare, and a perceived lack of leadership on solving India's serious economic and social problems.

## 1980s

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: 1980s")]

Main articles: [Operation Blue Star](/wiki/Operation_Blue_Star "Operation Blue Star"), [Assassination of Indira Gandhi](/wiki/Assassination_of_Indira_Gandhi "Assassination of Indira Gandhi"), [1984 anti-Sikh riots](/wiki/1984_anti-Sikh_riots "1984 anti-Sikh riots"), [Bhopal disaster](/wiki/Bhopal_disaster "Bhopal disaster"), [Indian intervention in the Sri Lankan Civil War](/wiki/Indian_intervention_in_the_Sri_Lankan_Civil_War "Indian intervention in the Sri Lankan Civil War"), and [Siachen conflict](/wiki/Siachen_conflict "Siachen conflict")
