Indira Gandhi and her Congress Party splinter group, the [Indian National Congress](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") or simply "Congress(I)", were swept back into power with a large majority in January 1980.

But the rise of an insurgency in Punjab would jeopardise India's security. In [Assam](/wiki/Assam "Assam"), there were many incidents of communal violence between native villagers and refugees from Bangladesh, as well as settlers from other parts of India. When Indian forces, undertaking [Operation Blue Star](/wiki/Operation_Blue_Star "Operation Blue Star"), raided the hideout of self-rule pressing[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112) [Khalistan](/wiki/Khalistan "Khalistan") militants in the [Golden Temple](/wiki/Golden_Temple "Golden Temple") — Sikhs' most holy shrine – in [Amritsar](/wiki/Amritsar "Amritsar"), the inadvertent deaths of civilians and damage to the temple building inflamed tensions in the Sikh community across India. The Government used intensive police operations to crush militant operations, but it resulted in many claims of abuse of civil liberties. North-east India was paralysed owing to the [ULFA](/wiki/ULFA "ULFA")'s clash with Government forces.

On 31 October 1984, Indira Gandhi was [assassinated by two of her bodyguards](/wiki/Assassination_of_Indira_Gandhi "Assassination of Indira Gandhi"), and [anti-Sikh riots](/wiki/1984_anti-Sikh_riots "1984 anti-Sikh riots") erupted in Delhi and parts of Punjab, causing the deaths of thousands of Sikhs along with pillage, arson, and rape. Senior members of the Congress Party have been implicated in stirring the violence against Sikhs. Government investigation has failed to date to discover the causes and punish the perpetrators, but public opinion blamed Congress leaders for directing attacks on Sikhs in Delhi.

### Rajiv Gandhi administration

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Rajiv Gandhi administration")]

The Congress party chose [Rajiv Gandhi](/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi "Rajiv Gandhi"), Indira's older son, as the next prime minister. Rajiv had been elected to Parliament only in 1982, and at 40, was the youngest national political leader and prime minister ever. But his youth and inexperience were an asset in the eyes of citizens tired of the inefficacy and corruption of career politicians, and looking for newer policies and a fresh start to resolve the country's long-standing problems. The Parliament was dissolved, and Rajiv led the Congress party to its largest majority in history (over 415 seats out of 545 possible), reaping a sympathy vote over his mother's assassination.[[123]](#cite_note-125)

Rajiv Gandhi initiated a series of reforms: the [Licence Raj](/wiki/Licence_Raj "Licence Raj") was loosened, and government restrictions on foreign currency, travel, foreign investment, and imports decreased considerably. This allowed private businesses to use resources and produce commercial goods without government bureaucracy interfering, and the influx of foreign investment increased India's national reserves. As prime minister, Rajiv broke from his mother's precedent to improve relations with the United States, which increased economic aid and scientific co-operation. Rajiv's encouragement of science and technology resulted in a major expansion of the telecommunications industry and [India's space programme](/wiki/Indian_Space_Research_Organisation "Indian Space Research Organisation"), and gave birth to the [software industry](/wiki/Software_industry "Software industry") and information technology sector.[[124]](#cite_note-princeton.edu-126) Rajiv received criticism from some members of the Congress Party for his economic liberalisation policy, which led him to pledge in 1985 (as noted by one journal) ‘not to deviate from the ideals and principles of socialism “under any circumstances.”’[[125]](#cite_note-127)

In December 1984, [gas leaked out](/wiki/Bhopal_disaster "Bhopal disaster") at the [Union Carbide](/wiki/Union_Carbide "Union Carbide") pesticides plant in the central Indian city of [Bhopal](/wiki/Bhopal "Bhopal"). Thousands were killed immediately, while many more subsequently died or were left disabled.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

India in 1987 brokered an agreement with the Government of [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka") and agreed to deploy troops for peacekeeping operation in Sri Lanka's ethnic conflict led by the [LTTE](/wiki/LTTE "LTTE"). Rajiv sent Indian troops to enforce the agreement and disarm the [Tamil](/wiki/Tamils "Tamils") rebels, but the Indian Peace Keeping Force, as it was known, became entangled in outbreaks of violence, ultimately ending up fighting the Tamil rebels itself, and becoming a target of attack from Sri Lankan nationalists.[[126]](#cite_note-128) [V. P. Singh](/wiki/V._P._Singh "V. P. Singh") withdrew the IPKF in 1990, but thousands of Indian soldiers had died. Rajiv's departure from socialist policies did not sit well with the masses, who did not benefit from the innovations. Unemployment was a serious problem, and India's burgeoning population added ever-increasing needs for diminishing resources.

Rajiv Gandhi's image as an honest politician (he was nicknamed "Mr. Clean" by the press) was shattered when the [Bofors scandal](/wiki/Bofors_scandal "Bofors scandal") broke, revealing that senior government officials had taken bribes over defence contracts by a Swedish guns producer.[[127]](#cite_note-129)

### Janata Dal

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Janata Dal")]

General elections in 1989 gave Rajiv's Congress a [plurality](/wiki/Plurality_(voting) "Plurality (voting)"), much less than the majority which propelled him to power.[[128]](#cite_note-130)

Power came instead to his former finance and defence minister, [VP Singh](/wiki/Vishwanath_Pratap_Singh "Vishwanath Pratap Singh") of [Janata Dal](/wiki/Janata_Dal "Janata Dal"). Singh had been moved from the Finance ministry to the Defence ministry after he unearthed some scandals which made the Congress leadership uncomfortable. Singh then unearthed the [Bofors scandal](/wiki/Bofors_scandal "Bofors scandal"), and was sacked from the party and office.[[129]](#cite_note-131) Becoming a popular crusader for reform and clean government, Singh led the Janata Dal coalition to a majority. He was supported by BJP and the leftist parties from outside. Becoming Prime Minister, Singh made an important visit to the Golden Temple shrine, to heal the wounds of the past. He implemented the [Mandal Commission](/wiki/Mandal_Commission "Mandal Commission") report, to increase the quota in reservation for low-caste Hindus.[[130]](#cite_note-132) His government fell after Singh, along with Bihar's Chief Minister [Lalu Prasad Yadav](/wiki/Lalu_Prasad_Yadav "Lalu Prasad Yadav")'s government, had [Advani](/wiki/L._K._Advani "L. K. Advani") arrested in [Samastipur](/wiki/Samastipur "Samastipur") and stopped his [Ram Rath Yatra](/wiki/Ram_Rath_Yatra "Ram Rath Yatra"), which was going to the Babri Masjid site in Ayodhya on 23 October 1990. The [Bharatiya Janata Party](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party") withdrew their support to Singh government, causing them to lose parliamentary vote of confidence on 7 November 1990.[[131]](#cite_note-133) [Chandra Shekhar](/wiki/Chandra_Shekhar "Chandra Shekhar") split to form the Janata Dal (Socialist), supported by Rajiv's Congress. This new government also collapsed in a matter of months, when Congress withdrew its support.

## 1990s

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: 1990s")]

Main articles: [1990s in India](/wiki/1990s_in_India "1990s in India"), [Assassination of Rajiv Gandhi](/wiki/Assassination_of_Rajiv_Gandhi "Assassination of Rajiv Gandhi"), [Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir"), [Bombay riots](/wiki/Bombay_riots "Bombay riots"), and [1993 Mumbai blasts](/wiki/1993_Mumbai_blasts "1993 Mumbai blasts")

The then-Chief Minister of [Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(state) "Jammu and Kashmir (state)") [Farooq Abdullah](/wiki/Farooq_Abdullah "Farooq Abdullah") (son of former Chief Minister [Sheikh Abdullah](/wiki/Sheikh_Abdullah "Sheikh Abdullah")) announced an alliance with the ruling Congress party for the elections of 1987. But, the elections were allegedly rigged in favour of him. This led to the rise of the armed extremist [insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir") composed, in part, of those who unfairly lost elections. India has constantly maintained the position of blaming Pakistan for supplying these groups with logistical support, arms, recruits and training.[[132]](#cite_note-134)

Militants in [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir") reportedly tortured and killed local [Kashmiri Pandits](/wiki/Kashmiri_Pandits "Kashmiri Pandits"), forcing them to leave Kashmir in large numbers.[[133]](#cite_note-135)[*[better source needed](/wiki/Template:Refexample#Self-sourcing "Template:Refexample")*] Around 90% of the Kashmiri Pandits left Kashmir during the 1990s, resulting in the [ethnic cleansing of Kashmiri Hindus](/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing_of_Kashmiri_Hindus "Ethnic cleansing of Kashmiri Hindus").[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

On 21 May 1991, while former prime minister Rajiv Gandhi campaigned in [Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu "Tamil Nadu") on behalf of Congress (Indira), a [Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam](/wiki/Liberation_Tigers_of_Tamil_Eelam "Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam") (LTTE) [female suicide bomber](/wiki/Female_suicide_bomber "Female suicide bomber") assassinated him and many others by setting off the bomb in her belt by leaning forward while garlanding him. In the elections, Congress (Indira) won 244 parliamentary seats and put together a coalition, returning to power under the leadership of [P.V. Narasimha Rao](/wiki/P.V._Narasimha_Rao "P.V. Narasimha Rao"). This Congress-led government, which served a full five-year term, initiated a gradual process of economic liberalisation and reform, which has opened the [Indian economy](/wiki/Economy_of_India "Economy of India") to global trade and investment. India's domestic politics also took new shape, as traditional alignments by caste, creed, and ethnicity gave way to a plethora of small, regionally-based political parties.[[134]](#cite_note-136)

But India was rocked by communal violence (see [Bombay riots](/wiki/Bombay_riots "Bombay riots")) between Hindus and Muslims that killed over 10,000 people, following the [Babri Mosque](/wiki/Babri_Mosque "Babri Mosque") demolition by Hindu extremists in the course of the [Ram Janmabhoomi](/wiki/Ram_Janmabhoomi "Ram Janmabhoomi") dispute in [Ayodhya](/wiki/Ayodhya "Ayodhya") in December 1992.[[135]](#cite_note-137) On 12 March 1993, a series of [blasts](/wiki/1993_Mumbai_blasts "1993 Mumbai blasts") occurred in [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai") which killed 257 people and injured more than 1400 people. The attack was claimed by [Dawood Ibrahim](/wiki/Dawood_Ibrahim "Dawood Ibrahim"), the leader of the Mumbai-based organised crime syndicate, the [D-Company](/wiki/D-Company "D-Company"). The final months of the Rao-led government in the spring of 1996 suffered the effects of several major political corruption scandals, which contributed to the worst electoral performance by the Congress Party in its history till then as the Hindu nationalist [Bharatiya Janata Party](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party") emerged as the largest single party.[[136]](#cite_note-138)

**[P. V. Narasimha Rao](/wiki/P._V._Narasimha_Rao "P. V. Narasimha Rao")**

**[Manmohan Singh](/wiki/Manmohan_Singh "Manmohan Singh")**

[Economic liberalisation in India](/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India "Economic liberalisation in India") was initiated in 1991 by Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao and his then-Finance Minister Dr. Manmohan Singh.[[137]](#cite_note-Reforming-139) Rao was often referred to as *[Chanakya](/wiki/Chanakya "Chanakya")* for his ability to steer tough economic and political legislation through the parliament at a time when he headed a [minority government](/wiki/Minority_government "Minority government").[[138]](#cite_note-frontline-140)[[139]](#cite_note-141)

### Economic reforms

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Economic reforms")]

Main article: [Economic liberalisation in India](/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India "Economic liberalisation in India")

See also: [Indian Century](/wiki/Indian_Century "Indian Century")

Under the [policies](/wiki/P._V._Narasimha_Rao#Economic_reforms "P. V. Narasimha Rao") initiated by the then Prime Minister [P. V. Narasimha Rao](/wiki/P._V._Narasimha_Rao "P. V. Narasimha Rao") and his then-Finance Minister Dr. [Manmohan Singh](/wiki/Manmohan_Singh "Manmohan Singh"), India's economy expanded rapidly. The economic reforms were a reaction to an [impending balance of payment crisis](/wiki/1991_Indian_economic_crisis "1991 Indian economic crisis"). The Rao administration initiated the [privatisation](/wiki/Privatisation "Privatisation") of large, inefficient, and loss-inducing government corporations. The UF government had attempted a progressive budget that encouraged reforms, but the [1997 Asian financial crisis](/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis "1997 Asian financial crisis") and political instability created economic stagnation. The Vajpayee administration continued with privatisation, reduction of taxes, a sound [fiscal policy](/wiki/Fiscal_policy "Fiscal policy") aimed at reducing deficits and debts, and increased initiatives for public works. Cities like [Bangalore](/wiki/Bangalore "Bangalore"), [Hyderabad](/wiki/Hyderabad "Hyderabad"), [Pune](/wiki/Pune "Pune"), and [Ahmedabad](/wiki/Ahmedabad "Ahmedabad") have risen in prominence and economic importance, becoming centres of rising industries and destinations for foreign investment and firms. Strategies like forming Special Economic Zones—tax amenities, good communications infrastructure, low regulation—to encourage industries has paid off in many parts of the country.[[140]](#cite_note-oecdindia2007-142)

A rising generation of well-educated and skilled professionals in scientific sectors of the industry began propelling the Indian economy, as the information technology industry took hold across India with the proliferation of computers. The new technologies increased the efficiency of activity in almost every type of industry, which also benefitted from the availability of skilled labor. Foreign investment and outsourcing of jobs to India's labor markets further enhanced India's economic growth. A large middle class has arisen across India, which has increased the demand, and thus the production of a wide array of [consumer goods](/wiki/Consumer_goods "Consumer goods"). Unemployment is steadily declining, and poverty has fallen to approximately 22%. Gross Domestic Product growth increased to beyond 7%. While serious challenges remain, India is enjoying a period of economic expansion that has propelled it to the forefront of the world economy, and has correspondingly increased its influence in political and diplomatic terms.[[2]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304-2)

### Era of coalitions

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Era of coalitions")]

The [Bharatiya Janata Party](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party") (BJP) emerged from the May 1996 national elections as the single-largest party in the [Lok Sabha](/wiki/Lok_Sabha "Lok Sabha") but without enough strength to prove a majority on the floor of that Parliament. Under Prime Minister [Atal Bihari Vajpayee](/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari Vajpayee"), the BJP coalition lasted in power 13 days. With all political parties wishing to avoid another round of elections, a 14-party coalition led by the [Janata Dal](/wiki/Janata_Dal "Janata Dal") emerged to form a government known as the United Front. A United Front government under then [Chief Minister of Karnataka](/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Karnataka "Chief Minister of Karnataka") [H. D. Deve Gowda](/wiki/H._D._Deve_Gowda "H. D. Deve Gowda") lasted less than a year. The leader of the Congress Party withdrew support in March 1997. [Inder Kumar Gujral](/wiki/Inder_Kumar_Gujral "Inder Kumar Gujral") replaced Deve Gowda as the consensus choice for Prime Minister of a 16-party United Front coalition.[[141]](#cite_note-143)

In November 1997, the Congress Party again withdrew support for the United Front. New elections in February 1998 brought the BJP the largest number of seats in Parliament (182), but this fell far short of a majority. On 20 March 1998, the President inaugurated a BJP-led coalition government, with Vajpayee again serving as prime minister. On 11 and 13 May 1998, this government conducted a series of five underground nuclear weapons tests, known collectively as [Pokhran-II](/wiki/Pokhran-II "Pokhran-II") — which caused Pakistan to conduct its own tests that same year.[[142]](#cite_note-144) India's nuclear tests prompted President of the United States [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") and Japan to impose [economic sanctions](/wiki/Economic_sanctions "Economic sanctions") on India pursuant to the 1994 Nuclear Proliferation Prevention Act and led to widespread international condemnation.

In the early months of 1999, Prime Minister Vajpayee made a historic bus trip to Pakistan and met with Pakistan's prime minister [Nawaz Sharif](/wiki/Nawaz_Sharif "Nawaz Sharif"), signing the bilateral [Lahore peace declaration](/wiki/Lahore_Declaration "Lahore Declaration").[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

In April 1999, the coalition government led by the [Bharatiya Janata Party](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party") (BJP) fell apart, leading to fresh elections in September after AIADMK supremo/ chief Jayalalithaa withdraw her support. In May and June 1999, India discovered an elaborate campaign of terrorist infiltration that resulted in the [Kargil War](/wiki/Kargil_War "Kargil War") in Kashmir, derailing a promising peace process that had begun only three months earlier when Prime Minister Vajpayee visited Pakistan, inaugurating the Delhi-Lahore bus service. Indian forces killed Pakistan-backed infiltrators and reclaimed important border posts in high-altitude warfare.[[143]](#cite_note-edition.cnn.com-145)

Soaring on popularity earned following the successful conclusion of the Kargil conflict, the [National Democratic Alliance](/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance "National Democratic Alliance")—a new coalition led by the BJP—gained a majority to form a government with Vajpayee as prime minister in October 1999. The end of the millennium was devastating to India, as a [cyclone](/wiki/Cyclone "Cyclone") hit [Orissa](/wiki/Odisha "Odisha"), killing at least 10,000.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

## 2000s

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: 2000s")]

### Under Bharatiya Janata Party

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Under Bharatiya Janata Party")]

In May 2000, India's population exceeded 1 billion. President of the United States [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton") made a groundbreaking visit to India to improve ties between the two nations. In January, massive [earthquakes hit Gujarat state](/wiki/2001_Gujarat_earthquake "2001 Gujarat earthquake"), killing at least 30,000.

Prime Minister Vajpayee met with Pakistan's President [Pervez Musharraf](/wiki/Pervez_Musharraf "Pervez Musharraf") in the first summit between Pakistan and India in more than two years in the middle of 2001. But the meeting failed without a breakthrough or even a joint statement because of differences over Kashmir region.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

Three new states — [Chhattisgarh](/wiki/Chhattisgarh "Chhattisgarh"), [Jharkhand](/wiki/Jharkhand "Jharkhand") and [Uttarakhand](/wiki/Uttarakhand "Uttarakhand") (originally Uttaranchal) — were formed in November 2000.

The National Democratic Alliance government's credibility was adversely affected by a number of political scandals (such as allegations that the Defence Minister [George Fernandes](/wiki/George_Fernandes "George Fernandes") took bribes) as well as reports of intelligence failures that led to the Kargil incursions going undetected, and the apparent failure of his talks with the Pakistani President.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)[[145]](#cite_note-147) Following the [September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"), the United States lifted sanctions which it had imposed against India and Pakistan in 1998. The move was seen as a reward for their support for the [war on terror](/wiki/War_on_terror "War on terror"). The tensions of an imminent war between India and Pakistan again rose by the heavy Indian firing on Pakistani military posts along the [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control") and the subsequent deadly [2001 Indian Parliament attack](/wiki/2001_Indian_Parliament_attack "2001 Indian Parliament attack") on 13 December 2001 and the [2001–02 India–Pakistan standoff](/wiki/2001%E2%80%9302_India%E2%80%93Pakistan_standoff "2001–02 India–Pakistan standoff").[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

On 27 February 2002, 59 Hindu pilgrims returning from Ayodhya were killed in a train fire in [Godhra](/wiki/Godhra "Godhra"), Gujarat. This sparked off the [2002 Gujarat riots](/wiki/2002_Gujarat_riots "2002 Gujarat riots"), leading to the deaths of 790 Muslims and 254 Hindus and with 223 people reported missing.

Throughout 2003, India's speedy economic progress, political stability, and a rejuvenated peace initiative with Pakistan increased the government's popularity. India and Pakistan agreed to resume direct air links and to allow overflights, and a groundbreaking meeting was held between the Indian government and moderate Kashmir separatists.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112) The [Golden Quadrilateral](/wiki/Golden_Quadrilateral "Golden Quadrilateral") project aimed to link India's corners with a network of modern highways.

### Congress rule returns

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Congress rule returns")]

In January 2004 Prime Minister Vajpayee recommended early dissolution of the [Lok Sabha](/wiki/Lok_Sabha "Lok Sabha") and general elections. an alliance led by the [Congress Party](/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") called [United Progressive Alliance](/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance "United Progressive Alliance")(UPA) won a surprise victory in [elections](/wiki/2004_Indian_general_election "2004 Indian general election") held in May 2004. [Manmohan Singh](/wiki/Manmohan_Singh "Manmohan Singh") became the Prime Minister, after the Congress President [Sonia Gandhi](/wiki/Sonia_Gandhi "Sonia Gandhi"), the widow of former prime minister [Rajiv Gandhi](/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi "Rajiv Gandhi"), declined to take the office, to defuse the controversy about whether her foreign birth should be considered a disqualification for the Prime Minister's post. Apart from the Congress party, other members of UPA included Socialist and regional parties. The alliance had outside support of India's [Communist parties](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India "Communist Party of India"). Manmohan Singh became the first [Sikh](/wiki/Sikh "Sikh") and non-[Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu") to hold India's most powerful office. Singh continued economic liberalisation, although the need for support from Indian Socialists and Communists forestalled further privatisation for some time.[[146]](#cite_note-newsweek.com-148)[[147]](#cite_note-Giridharadas-149)

By the end of 2004, India began to withdraw some of its troops from Kashmir. By the middle of the next year, the [Srinagar–Muzaffarabad Bus](/wiki/Srinagar%E2%80%93Muzaffarabad_Bus "Srinagar–Muzaffarabad Bus") service was inaugurated, the first in 60 years to operate between Indian-administered and Pakistani-administered Kashmirs. However, in May 2006, suspected Islamic extremist militants killed 35 Hindus in the worst attacks in Indian-administered Kashmir for several months.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

The [2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami](/wiki/2004_Indian_Ocean_earthquake_and_tsunami "2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami") devastated Indian coastlines and islands, killing an estimated 18,000 and displacing around 650,000. The tsunami was caused by a powerful undersea earthquake off the Indonesian coast. Natural disasters such as the [Mumbai floods](/wiki/Maharashtra_floods_of_2005 "Maharashtra floods of 2005") (killing more than 1,000) and [Kashmir earthquake](/wiki/2005_Kashmir_earthquake "2005 Kashmir earthquake") (killing 79,000) hit the subcontinent in the next year. In February 2006, the [United Progressive Alliance](/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance "United Progressive Alliance") government launched India's largest-ever rural jobs scheme, aimed at lifting around 60 million families out of poverty.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

The United States and India signed a [major nuclear co-operation agreement](/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_Civil_Nuclear_Agreement "India–United States Civil Nuclear Agreement") during a visit by United States President [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") in March 2006. According to the nuclear deal, the United States was to give India access to civilian nuclear technology while India agreed to greater scrutiny for its nuclear programme. Later, United States approved a controversial law allowing India to buy their nuclear reactors and fuel for the first time in 30 years. In July 2008, the United Progressive Alliance survived a [vote of confidence](/wiki/2008_Lok_Sabha_vote_of_confidence "2008 Lok Sabha vote of confidence") brought after left-wing parties withdrew their support over the nuclear deal. After the vote, several left-wing and regional parties formed a new alliance to oppose the government, saying it had been tainted by corruption. Within three months, following approval by the [U.S. Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"), George W. Bush signed into law a nuclear deal with India, which ended a three-decade ban on American nuclear trade with Delhi.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

In 2007, India got its first female President as [Pratibha Patil](/wiki/Pratibha_Patil "Pratibha Patil") was sworn in. Long associated with the [Nehru–Gandhi family](/wiki/Nehru%E2%80%93Gandhi_family "Nehru–Gandhi family"), Pratibha Patil was a low-profile governor of the state of [Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan "Rajasthan") before emerging as the favoured presidential candidate of [Sonia Gandhi](/wiki/Sonia_Gandhi "Sonia Gandhi").[[148]](#cite_note-150) In February, the infamous [Samjhauta Express bombings](/wiki/Samjhauta_Express_bombings "Samjhauta Express bombings") took place, killing Pakistani civilians in [Panipat](/wiki/Panipat "Panipat"), Haryana. As of 2011, nobody had been charged for the crime, though it has been linked to [Abhinav Bharat](/wiki/Abhinav_Bharat "Abhinav Bharat"), a shadowy Hindu fundamentalist group headed by a former Indian army officer.[[149]](#cite_note-OI-151)

In 2008 October, India successfully launched its first mission to the Moon, the uncrewed [lunar probe](/wiki/Lunar_probe "Lunar probe") called *[Chandrayaan-1](/wiki/Chandrayaan-1 "Chandrayaan-1")*. In the previous year, India had launched its first commercial [space rocket](/wiki/Space_rocket "Space rocket"), carrying an Italian [satellite](/wiki/Satellite "Satellite").[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

On 26 November 2008, [Mumbai attacks](/wiki/2008_Mumbai_attacks "2008 Mumbai attacks") took place. India blamed [Lashkar-e-Taiba](/wiki/Lashkar-e-Taiba "Lashkar-e-Taiba") militants from Pakistan for the attacks and announced a "pause" in the ongoing peace process.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

In July 2009, the [Delhi High Court](/wiki/Delhi_High_Court "Delhi High Court") decriminalised consensual homosexual sex, re-interpreting the British Raj-era law, [Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code](/wiki/Section_377_of_the_Indian_Penal_Code "Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code"), as unconstitutional in regard to criminalising consensual sex between two homosexual adults or decriminalising such acts between adult heterosexuals or other consenting adults, that may be deemed unnatural.[[150]](#cite_note-CNNIBN-152)[[151]](#cite_note-BBC1-153)

In the [Indian general election in 2009](/wiki/2009_Indian_general_election "2009 Indian general election"), the [United Progressive Alliance](/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance "United Progressive Alliance") won a convincing and resounding 262 seats, with Congress alone winning 206 seats. However, the Congress-led government faced many allegations of corruption. Inflation rose to an all-time high, and the ever-increasing prices of food commodities caused widespread agitation.

On 8 November 2009, in spite of strong protests by China, which claims the whole of [Arunachal Pradesh](/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh "Arunachal Pradesh") as its own,[[153]](#cite_note-155) the [14th Dalai Lama](/wiki/14th_Dalai_Lama "14th Dalai Lama") visited [Tawang Monastery](/wiki/Tawang_Monastery "Tawang Monastery") in Arunachal Pradesh, which was a monumental event to the people of the region, and the abbot of the monastery greeted him with much fanfare and adulation.[[154]](#cite_note-Majumdar-156)

21st-century India is facing the [Naxalite–Maoist rebels](/wiki/Naxalite%E2%80%93Maoist_insurgency "Naxalite–Maoist insurgency"), in the words of Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, India's "greatest internal security challenge",[[155]](#cite_note-www.bbc.co.uk-157) and other terrorist tensions (such as Islamist terrorist campaigns in and out of [Jammu & Kashmir](/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir") and [terrorism in India's Northeast](/wiki/Insurgency_in_Northeast_India "Insurgency in Northeast India")).[[155]](#cite_note-www.bbc.co.uk-157)[[156]](#cite_note-158) Terrorism has increased in India, with bomb blasts in leading cities like [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai"), New Delhi, [Jaipur](/wiki/Jaipur "Jaipur"), [Bangalore](/wiki/Bangalore "Bangalore"), and [Hyderabad](/wiki/Hyderabad "Hyderabad").[[143]](#cite_note-edition.cnn.com-145) In the new millennium, India improved relations with many countries and foreign unions including the United States, the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), Israel, and the People's Republic of China.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112) The [economy of India](/wiki/Economy_of_India "Economy of India") has grown at a very rapid pace. India was now being looked at as a [potential superpower](/wiki/Potential_superpower "Potential superpower").[[146]](#cite_note-newsweek.com-148)[[147]](#cite_note-Giridharadas-149)

## 2010s

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: 2010s")]

### Congress rule continues

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Congress rule continues")]

The [concerns and controversies over the 2010 Commonwealth Games](/wiki/Concerns_and_controversies_over_the_2010_Commonwealth_Games "Concerns and controversies over the 2010 Commonwealth Games") rocked the country in 2010, raising questions about the credibility of the government followed by the [2G spectrum case](/wiki/2G_spectrum_case "2G spectrum case") and [Adarsh Housing Society scam](/wiki/Adarsh_Housing_Society_scam "Adarsh Housing Society scam"). In mid-2011, [Anna Hazare](/wiki/Anna_Hazare "Anna Hazare"), a prominent social activist, [staged a 12-day hunger strike](/wiki/2011_Indian_anti-corruption_movement "2011 Indian anti-corruption movement") in Delhi in protest at state corruption, after government proposals to tighten up [anti-graft legislation](/wiki/The_Lokpal_Bill,_2011 "The Lokpal Bill, 2011") fell short of his demands.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

In June 2010, [violent unrest](/wiki/2010_Kashmir_unrest "2010 Kashmir unrest") broke out in [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir") over the fake encounter killing of [three Kashmiri people](/wiki/2010_Machil_encounter "2010 Machil encounter") by security forces suspected to be Pakistani terrorists along the [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control").

Despite all this, India showed great promise with a higher growth rate in gross domestic product.[[157]](#cite_note-159) In January 2011, India assumed a nonpermanent seat in the [United Nations Security Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security Council") for the 2011–12 term. In 2004, India had launched an application for a permanent seat on the UN Security Council, along with Brazil, Germany and Japan. In March, India overtook China to become the world's largest importer of arms.[[110]](#cite_note-BBC_India_Profile_and_Timeline-112)

The [Telangana movement](/wiki/Telangana_movement "Telangana movement") reached its peak in 2011–12, leading to formation of India's 29th state, [Telangana](/wiki/Telangana "Telangana"), in June 2014.

In August 2010, cloudbursts and the ensuing [flooding](/wiki/2010_Ladakh_floods "2010 Ladakh floods") in the [Ladakh](/wiki/Ladakh "Ladakh") region of North India resulted in the deaths of around 255 people, while affecting 9,000 people directly.[[159]](#cite_note-bbc20100806-161) In June 2013, a [multi-day cloudburst](/wiki/2013_North_India_floods "2013 North India floods") in Uttarakhand and other north Indian states caused devastating floods and landslides, with more than 5,700 people "presumed dead."[[160]](#cite_note-AP-162) In September 2014, [floods](/wiki/2014_India%E2%80%93Pakistan_floods "2014 India–Pakistan floods") in the state of [Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(state) "Jammu and Kashmir (state)"), following heavy rains due to [monsoon](/wiki/Monsoon_of_South_Asia "Monsoon of South Asia") season, killed around 277 people and brought extensive damage to property.[[161]](#cite_note-HT1-163) A further 280 people died in the neighbouring Pakistani regions, particularly in [Pakistani Punjab](/wiki/Pakistani_Punjab "Pakistani Punjab").[[162]](#cite_note-NYT-164)

A series of border skirmishes broke out between [India](/wiki/India "India") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") along the [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control") in the years [2011](/wiki/2011_India-Pakistan_border_shooting "2011 India-Pakistan border shooting"), [2013](/wiki/2013_India%E2%80%93Pakistan_border_skirmishes "2013 India–Pakistan border skirmishes"), [2014](/wiki/2014%E2%80%932015_India%E2%80%93Pakistan_border_skirmishes "2014–2015 India–Pakistan border skirmishes"), [2015](/wiki/2015_India-Pakistan_border_skirmishes "2015 India-Pakistan border skirmishes") where [India](/wiki/India "India") accused [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") of ceasefire violations.

The [2012 Delhi gang rape & murder](/wiki/2012_Delhi_gang_rape_and_murder "2012 Delhi gang rape and murder") case on 16 December 2012 led to subsequent protests which resulted in [changes in the laws](/wiki/Criminal_Law_(Amendment)_Act,_2013 "Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013") related to rape and offences against women. In April 2013, the [Saradha Group scandal](/wiki/Saradha_Group_financial_scandal "Saradha Group financial scandal") was unearthed, caused by the collapse of a [Ponzi scheme](/wiki/Ponzi_scheme "Ponzi scheme") run by Saradha Group, a consortium of over 200 private companies in [Eastern India](/wiki/East_India "East India"), causing an estimated loss of INR 200–300 billion (US$4–6 billion) to over 1.7 million depositors.[[163]](#cite_note-165)[[164]](#cite_note-H1-166)[[165]](#cite_note-167) In December 2013, the [Supreme Court of India](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India "Supreme Court of India") overturned the Delhi High Court ruling on Sec 377, criminalising homosexual sex between consenting adults once again in the country.[[166]](#cite_note-1861_law-168)[[167]](#cite_note-169)

In August – September 2013, [clashes between Hindus and Muslims](/wiki/2013_Muzaffarnagar_riots "2013 Muzaffarnagar riots") in [Muzaffarnagar](/wiki/Muzaffarnagar "Muzaffarnagar"), Uttar Pradesh, resulted in at least 62 deaths,[[168]](#cite_note-timesofindia.indiatimes.com-170) injured 93, and left more than 50,000 displaced.[[169]](#cite_note-171)[[170]](#cite_note-fp1-172)[[171]](#cite_note-hindu2-173)[[172]](#cite_note-htt-174)

In November 2013, India launched its first interplanetary mission, the [Mars Orbiter Mission](/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Mission "Mars Orbiter Mission"), popularly known as *Mangalyaan*, to Mars and, was successful, so [ISRO](/wiki/Indian_Space_Research_Organisation "Indian Space Research Organisation") on 24 September 2014, became the fourth [space agency](/wiki/List_of_space_agencies "List of space agencies") to reach Mars, after the [Soviet space program](/wiki/Soviet_space_program "Soviet space program"), [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA"), and the [European Space Agency](/wiki/European_Space_Agency "European Space Agency").[[173]](#cite_note-175) ISRO also became the first space agency and India the first country to reach Mars on its maiden attempt.

### 2014 – Return of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) Government

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: 2014 – Return of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) Government")]

The [Hindutva](/wiki/Hindutva "Hindutva") movement advocating [Hindu nationalism](/wiki/Hindu_nationalism "Hindu nationalism") originated in the 1920s and has remained a strong political force in India. The major party of the religious right since the 1950s had been the [Bharatiya Jana Sangh](/wiki/Bharatiya_Jana_Sangh "Bharatiya Jana Sangh"). The Jana Sangh joined the Janata party in 1977 but when that party fell apart in a short period of three years, the erstwhile members of Jana Sangh in 1980 formed the [Bharatiya Janata Party](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party") (BJP). The BJP grew its support base in the following decades and is now the most dominant political party in India. In September 2013 the [Chief Minister](/wiki/Chief_Minister "Chief Minister") of [Gujarat](/wiki/Gujarat "Gujarat"), [Narendra Modi](/wiki/Narendra_Modi "Narendra Modi"), was named the [BJP](/wiki/BJP "BJP")'s candidate for prime minister ahead of the [2014 Lok Sabha election](/wiki/2014_Indian_general_election "2014 Indian general election").[[174]](#cite_note-Chhibber-176)[[175]](#cite_note-177) Several BJP leaders initially expressed opposition to Modi's candidature,[[176]](#cite_note-Jaffrelot_2015-178) including BJP founding member [L. K. Advani](/wiki/L._K._Advani "L. K. Advani").[[177]](#cite_note-179) Contrary to the strategies used by the party during previous elections, Modi played the dominant role in the BJP's presidential style election campaign.[[178]](#cite_note-180)[[179]](#cite_note-T&NM_2015-181)[[174]](#cite_note-Chhibber-176)[[180]](#cite_note-Chacko-182)[[181]](#cite_note-Srivastava-183)[[176]](#cite_note-Jaffrelot_2015-178)[[182]](#cite_note-184)[[183]](#cite_note-Basu_2014-185) The 16th national general election, held in early 2014, saw a [landslide victory](/wiki/Landslide_victory "Landslide victory") for the [BJP](/wiki/BJP "BJP") led [NDA](/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance "National Democratic Alliance"); the alliance gained a landslide victory and [formed a government](/wiki/First_Modi_ministry "First Modi ministry") under the premiership of [Modi](/wiki/Modi "Modi"). The Modi government's landslide victory in the [2014 Lok Sabha election](/wiki/2014_Lok_Sabha_election "2014 Lok Sabha election") and popularity helped the BJP win several state assembly elections in India. The Modi government implemented several initiatives and campaigns to increase manufacturing and infrastructure – notably — [Make in India](/wiki/Make_in_India "Make in India"), [Digital India](/wiki/Digital_India "Digital India") and the [Swachh Bharat Mission](/wiki/Swachh_Bharat_Mission "Swachh Bharat Mission").

On 18 September 2016, a [terrorist attack](/wiki/2016_Uri_attack "2016 Uri attack") took place in an [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army") base in [Uri, Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Uri,_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Uri, Jammu and Kashmir") which killed 19 soldiers and 4 militants behind the attack.[[184]](#cite_note-186) It took place at a time when the [Kashmir Valley](/wiki/Kashmir_Valley "Kashmir Valley") was facing extremely high levels of [violent unrest](/wiki/2016%E2%80%932017_Kashmir_unrest "2016–2017 Kashmir unrest") after the killing of [Burhan Wani](/wiki/Burhan_Wani "Burhan Wani") by security forces on 8 July 2016.[[185]](#cite_note-187)

On 29 September 2016, in response to the [Uri attack](/wiki/Uri_attack "Uri attack"), teams of Indian Army [Para (Special Forces)](/wiki/Para_(Special_Forces) "Para (Special Forces)") conducted [surgical strikes](/wiki/2016_Indian_Line_of_Control_strike "2016 Indian Line of Control strike") along the [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control") in [Pakistan occupied Kashmir](/wiki/Pakistan_occupied_Kashmir "Pakistan occupied Kashmir") on terrorist hideouts.[[186]](#cite_note-188) This led to the start of [border skirmishes](/wiki/2016-2018_India-Pakistan_border_skirmishes "2016-2018 India-Pakistan border skirmishes") between India and Pakistan along the [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control").

In April 2017, during the [2017 Srinagar by-election](/wiki/2017_Srinagar_by-election "2017 Srinagar by-election") a [human shield incident](/wiki/Kashmir_human_shield_incident "Kashmir human shield incident") took place involving a 26 year old man Farooq Ahmed Dar being tied in front of an [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army") jeep and Major [Leetul Gogoi](/wiki/Leetul_Gogoi "Leetul Gogoi") of the [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army") sparked outrage and debate on [human rights abuses in Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Human_rights_abuses_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Human rights abuses in Jammu and Kashmir").[[187]](#cite_note-189)[[188]](#cite_note-190)[[189]](#cite_note-191)

The largest tax reform in India's history, the [Goods and Services Tax](/wiki/Goods_and_Services_Tax_(India) "Goods and Services Tax (India)") (GST), was introduced in 2017. On 20 July 2018, the [Narendra Modi](/wiki/Narendra_Modi_government "Narendra Modi government") led [NDA](/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance "National Democratic Alliance") government won the first no confidence motion moved by the [Telugu Desam Party](/wiki/Telugu_Desam_Party "Telugu Desam Party") over the non-allocation of funds to the state of [Andhra Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh").[[190]](#cite_note-192)[[191]](#cite_note-193) In August 2018, a series of [flash floods](/wiki/2018_Kerala_floods "2018 Kerala floods") took place in the state of [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala "Kerala") which killed more than 483 people and displaced more than one million people.[[192]](#cite_note-194)[[193]](#cite_note-195) On 14 February 2019, a vehicle-borne suicide bomber assaulted a convoy of cars carrying [Central Reserve Police Force](/wiki/Central_Reserve_Police_Force "Central Reserve Police Force") (CRPF) troops on the [Jammu-Srinagar National Highway](/wiki/Jammu%E2%80%93Srinagar_National_Highway "Jammu–Srinagar National Highway") in the [Pulwama](/wiki/Pulwama "Pulwama") area of [Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory) "Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)").[[194]](#cite_note-196)

On 26 February 2019, India carried out the [2019 Balakot airstrike](/wiki/2019_Balakot_airstrike "2019 Balakot airstrike") when its airplanes flew across the [de facto border](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control") in [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir") and dropped bombs in the town of Balakot in Pakistan's [Khyber Pakhtunkhwa](/wiki/Khyber_Pakhtunkhwa "Khyber Pakhtunkhwa") region.[[195]](#cite_note-197) This led to [violent border skirmishes](/wiki/2019_India-Pakistan_border_skirmishes "2019 India-Pakistan border skirmishes") between India and Pakistan along the [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control"). After a dogfight between Indian and Pakistani fighter pilots. [Abhinandan Varthaman](/wiki/Abhinandan_Varthaman "Abhinandan Varthaman"), an Indian wing commander, was taken prisoner by the Pakistani side. Acting nonetheless under pressure from various world leaders and constrained by the [Vienna Convention](/wiki/Vienna_Convention_on_the_Law_of_Treaties "Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties"), Pakistan was compelled to free the Indian pilot.[[196]](#cite_note-198)

General elections were held between 11 April 2019 to 19 May 2019 in seven phases to elect members of the [17th Lok Sabha](/wiki/17th_Lok_Sabha "17th Lok Sabha"). The BJP led NDA alliance won a landslide victory with 353 seats(BJP 303 seats) with [Narendra Modi](/wiki/Narendra_Modi "Narendra Modi") taking oath as the [Prime Minister of India](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India") for the second time.[[197]](#cite_note-199)

By repealing [Article 370 of the Indian Constitution](/wiki/Article_370_of_the_Constitution_of_India "Article 370 of the Constitution of India") on 5 August 2019, the [state of Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(state) "Jammu and Kashmir (state)") was separated into two separate [union territories](/wiki/Union_territory "Union territory") known as [Jammu and Kashmir](/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory) "Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)") and [Ladakh](/wiki/Ladakh "Ladakh").[[198]](#cite_note-200) The bill came into effect as a law on 31 October 2019. After the cancellation of [Article 370](/wiki/Article_370_of_the_Constitution_of_India "Article 370 of the Constitution of India"), millions of people in Jammu and Kashmir didn't have communication with the outside world as the state remained under a [complete lockdown](/wiki/2019-2021_Jammu_and_Kashmir_lockdown "2019-2021 Jammu and Kashmir lockdown") until February 2021. On 9 November 2019, the [Supreme Court of India](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India "Supreme Court of India") delivered a landmark judgement by ruling in favour of the [Hindus](/wiki/Hindus "Hindus") in the [Ram Janmabhoomi Temple](/wiki/Ram_Janmabhoomi_Temple "Ram Janmabhoomi Temple").[[199]](#cite_note-201)[[200]](#cite_note-202)[[201]](#cite_note-203) The [Parliament of India](/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of India") passed the [Citizenship Amendment Act](/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019 "Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019") on 11 December 2019, sparking widespread [protests](/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests "Citizenship Amendment Act protests").[[202]](#cite_note-204)

* Prime Minister Modi at the launch of the *[Make in India](/wiki/Make_in_India "Make in India")* programme which was meant to encourage companies to manufacture their products in India and also increase their investment.
* 10th [President of Israel](/wiki/President_of_Israel "President of Israel") [Reuven Rivlin](/wiki/Reuven_Rivlin "Reuven Rivlin") and [Chief of General Staff](/wiki/Chief_of_General_Staff_(Israel) "Chief of General Staff (Israel)") of the [Israel Defense Forces](/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces "Israel Defense Forces") [Gadi Eizenkot](/wiki/Gadi_Eizenkot "Gadi Eizenkot") with PM Modi, the first Indian Prime Minister to visit Israel.
* [Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle Mark III](/wiki/Geosynchronous_Satellite_Launch_Vehicle_Mark_III "Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle Mark III") is intended as a launch vehicle for crewed missions under the [Indian Human Spaceflight Programme](/wiki/Indian_Human_Spaceflight_Programme "Indian Human Spaceflight Programme") announced in Prime Minister Modi's 2018 [Independence Day](/wiki/Independence_Day_of_India "Independence Day of India") speech.[[203]](#cite_note-205)

## 2020s

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: 2020s")]

In February 2020, [riots broke out](/wiki/2020_Delhi_riots "2020 Delhi riots") in Delhi.[[204]](#cite_note-206) The [Citizenship Amendment Act](/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests "Citizenship Amendment Act protests") protests have been described as an instigating factor.[[205]](#cite_note-207) Tensions escalated on the Indo-China border after [aggressive skirmishes](/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_China%E2%80%93India_skirmishes "2020–2021 China–India skirmishes") between Indian and Chinese troops beginning on 5 May 2020.[[206]](#cite_note-208) The [Rama Janmabhoomi](/wiki/Rama_Janmabhoomi "Rama Janmabhoomi") temple construction officially started after a Bhoomi Poojan (Hindu ground breaking) ceremony by Prime Minister Modi on 5 August 2020.[[207]](#cite_note-209)[[208]](#cite_note-210) [Farm reform laws](/wiki/2020_Indian_agriculture_acts "2020 Indian agriculture acts") which subsequently became quite controversial were passed with less than three hours of debate in either house in September 2020.[[209]](#cite_note-211)

In November 2020, a series of [border skirmishes](/wiki/2020_India-Pakistan_border_skirmishes "2020 India-Pakistan border skirmishes") broke out between [India](/wiki/India "India") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") along the [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control") which killed at least 22 people including 11 civilians.[[210]](#cite_note-212)[[211]](#cite_note-213) The fight ended on 25 February 2021 with a ceasefire agreement.[[212]](#cite_note-214)

After a year long [protests by farmers](/wiki/2020%E2%80%932021_Indian_farmers%27_protest "2020–2021 Indian farmers' protest"), Prime minister Modi in November 2021 repealed the laws in three minutes in the [Lok Sabha](/wiki/Lok_Sabha "Lok Sabha") and nine minutes in the [Rajya Sabha](/wiki/Rajya_Sabha "Rajya Sabha") without debate.[[213]](#cite_note-215)

### COVID-19 pandemic

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: COVID-19 pandemic")]

Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in India](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India")

The [COVID-19 pandemic in India](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India") began on 30 January 2020, when the first case was reported in [Thrissur](/wiki/Thrissur "Thrissur").[[214]](#cite_note-216) Two months later in March 2020, prime minister Modi imposed a [complete lockdown](/wiki/COVID-19_lockdown_in_India "COVID-19 lockdown in India") in the country at four hours notice to stop the spread of [COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19"). This led to millions losing their jobs and many lost their lives. The Indian economy also shrunk in percentage terms by double digit numbers. In September 2020, India's health minister [Harsh Vardhan](/wiki/Harsh_Vardhan_(Delhi_politician) "Harsh Vardhan (Delhi politician)") stated that the country planned to approve and begin distribution of a vaccine by the first quarter of 2021.[[215]](#cite_note-217) Vaccination against COVID-19 started in India on 16 January 2021. By early April 2021, second wave of infections took hold in the country with destructive consequences.[[216]](#cite_note-218) According to Christopher Clary, assistant professor of political science at the State University of New York, technocratic competence had been entirely missing from government's response to the second wave of the [COVID-19 pandemic in India](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India").[[217]](#cite_note-219) The second wave placed a major strain on the healthcare system,[[218]](#cite_note-220) including shortage of liquid [medical oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen"). The number of new cases had begun to steadily drop by late-May and vaccination gained momentum again. India administered 1 billion doses of COVID-19 vaccine on 21 October 2021.[[219]](#cite_note-221) Although official number of Covid related deaths in India during the pandemic is less than half a million, [excess mortality](/wiki/Excess_mortality "Excess mortality") rates for all causes has been estimated at between 3 and 5 million deaths.[[220]](#cite_note-222)

## Economy

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Economy")]

The economic history of the India since 1947 can be divided into two epochs: 1.1947-91 which saw heavy government involvement in the economy, and a slow growth rate in GDP 2.1991–present which saw deregulation and a rapid growth in GDP, and reduction in poverty.

### Pre-liberalisation period (1947–1991)

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Pre-liberalisation period (1947–1991)")]

Main article: [Licence Raj](/wiki/Licence_Raj "Licence Raj")

Indian [economic policy](/wiki/Economic_policy "Economic policy") after independence was influenced by the colonial experience, which was seen as exploitative by Indian leaders exposed to British social democracy and the planned [economy of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Economy_of_the_Soviet_Union "Economy of the Soviet Union").[[269]](#cite_note-AtIndependence-271) Domestic policy tended towards protectionism, with a strong emphasis on [import substitution industrialisation](/wiki/Import_substitution_industrialisation "Import substitution industrialisation"), [economic interventionism](/wiki/Economic_interventionism "Economic interventionism"), a large government-run [public sector](/wiki/Public_sector "Public sector"), [business regulation](/wiki/Regulation_(socio-legal_concept) "Regulation (socio-legal concept)"), and [central planning](/wiki/Central_planning "Central planning"),[[270]](#cite_note-272) while trade and foreign investment policies were relatively liberal.[[271]](#cite_note-273) [Five-Year Plans of India](/wiki/Five-Year_Plans_of_India "Five-Year Plans of India") resembled central planning in the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"). Steel, mining, machine tools, telecommunications, insurance, and power plants, among other industries, were effectively nationalised in the mid-1950s.[[272]](#cite_note-staley-274) The Indian economy of this period is characterised as [Dirigism](/wiki/Dirigisme "Dirigisme").[[100]](#cite_note-:1-102)[[273]](#cite_note-275)

Jawaharlal Nehru, the first prime minister of India, along with the statistician [Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis](/wiki/Prasanta_Chandra_Mahalanobis "Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis"), formulated and oversaw economic policy during the initial years of the country's independence. They expected favourable outcomes from their strategy, involving the rapid development of [heavy industry](/wiki/Heavy_industry "Heavy industry") by both public and [private sectors](/wiki/Private_sector "Private sector"), and based on direct and indirect state intervention, rather than the more extreme [Soviet-style](/wiki/Economy_of_the_Soviet_Union "Economy of the Soviet Union") central command system.[[276]](#cite_note-278)[[277]](#cite_note-279)[[278]](#cite_note-Cameron-1-280) The policy of concentrating simultaneously on capital- and technology-intensive heavy industry and subsidising manual, low-skill [cottage industries](/wiki/Cottage_industries "Cottage industries") was criticised by economist [Milton Friedman](/wiki/Milton_Friedman "Milton Friedman"), who thought it would waste capital and labour, and retard the development of small manufacturers.[[279]](#cite_note-milton-1-281)

Since 1965, the use of [high-yielding varieties of seeds](/wiki/Hybrid_seed "Hybrid seed"), increased [fertilisers](/wiki/Fertilisers "Fertilisers") and improved [irrigation](/wiki/Irrigation "Irrigation") facilities collectively contributed to the [Green Revolution in India](/wiki/Green_Revolution_in_India "Green Revolution in India"), which improved the condition of agriculture by increasing crop productivity, improving crop patterns and strengthening forward and backward linkages between agriculture and industry.[[280]](#cite_note-282) However, it has also been criticised as an unsustainable effort, resulting in the growth of capitalistic farming, ignoring institutional reforms and widening income disparities.[[281]](#cite_note-283)

In 1984, [Rajiv Gandhi](/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi "Rajiv Gandhi") promised [economic liberalization](/wiki/Economic_liberalization "Economic liberalization"), he made [V. P. Singh](/wiki/V._P._Singh "V. P. Singh") the finance minister, who tried to reduce tax evasion and tax receipts rose due to this crackdown although taxes were lowered. This process lost its momentum during the later tenure of Mr. Gandhi as his government was marred by scandals.

### Post-liberalisation period (since 1991)

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Post-liberalisation period (since 1991)")]

Main articles: [Economic liberalisation in India](/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India "Economic liberalisation in India") and [Economic development in India](/wiki/Economic_development_in_India "Economic development in India")

The collapse of the Soviet Union, which was India's major trading partner, and the [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War"), which caused a spike in oil prices, resulted in a major balance-of-payments crisis for India, which found itself facing the prospect of defaulting on its loans.[[282]](#cite_note-Ghosh-284) India asked for a $1.8 billion bailout loan from the [International Monetary Fund](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") (IMF), which in return demanded de-regulation.[[283]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETask_Force_Report20067-285)

In response, the [Narasimha Rao](/wiki/P._V._Narasimha_Rao "P. V. Narasimha Rao") government, including Finance Minister [Manmohan Singh](/wiki/Manmohan_Singh "Manmohan Singh"), initiated [economic reforms](/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India "Economic liberalisation in India") in 1991. The reforms did away with the [Licence Raj](/wiki/Licence_Raj "Licence Raj"), reduced tariffs and interest rates and ended many public monopolies, allowing automatic approval of [foreign direct investment](/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment "Foreign direct investment") in many sectors.[[284]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETask_Force_Report20067–8-286) Since then, the overall thrust of liberalisation has remained unchanged since 1991, although no government had tried taking on powerful lobbies such as trade unions and farmers and on contentious issues such as reforming labour laws and reducing [agricultural subsidies](/wiki/Agricultural_subsidy "Agricultural subsidy").[[285]](#cite_note-Gandhi-1-287) By the turn of the 21st century, India had progressed towards a free-market economy, with a substantial reduction in state control of the economy and increased financial liberalisation.[[286]](#cite_note-288) This has been accompanied by increases in life expectancy, literacy rates, and food security, although urban residents have benefited more than rural residents.[[287]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTETask_Force_Report200617–20-289)

In the second decade of this century, the [economy of India](/wiki/Economy_of_India "Economy of India") rose from the ninth-largest to the fifth-largest economy in the world by nominal GDP, surpassing the [UK](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), [France](/wiki/France "France"), [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") and [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil").[[288]](#cite_note-290) The economy had started to slow down in the second term of Manmohan Singh's tenure but started a recovery in 2013–14 when the GDP growth rate accelerated to 6.4% from the previous year's 5.5%. The acceleration continued through 2014–15 and 2015–16 with growth rates of 7.5% and 8.0% respectively in the early early years under Narendra Modi's first term. However the growth rate subsequently decelerated, to 7.1% and 6.6% in 2016–17 and 2017–18 respectively,[[289]](#cite_note-291) partly because of the disruptive effects of [2016 Indian banknote demonetisation](/wiki/2016_Indian_banknote_demonetisation "2016 Indian banknote demonetisation") and the [Goods and Services Tax (India)](/wiki/Goods_and_Services_Tax_(India) "Goods and Services Tax (India)").[[290]](#cite_note-292)

#### COVID-19 pandemic and aftermath (2020–present)

[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present)&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: COVID-19 pandemic and aftermath (2020–present)")]

During the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India"), numerous [rating agencies](/wiki/Rating_agencies "Rating agencies") downgraded India's GDP predictions for FY21 to negative figures,[[291]](#cite_note-:49-293)[[292]](#cite_note-294) signalling a recession in India, the most severe since 1979.[[293]](#cite_note-295)[[294]](#cite_note-296) The Indian Economy contracted by 6.6 percent which was lower than the estimated 7.3 percent decline.[[295]](#cite_note-297) In 2022, the ratings agency [Fitch Ratings](/wiki/Fitch_Ratings "Fitch Ratings") upgraded India's outlook to stable similar to [S&P Global Ratings](/wiki/S%26P_Global_Ratings "S&P Global Ratings") and [Moody's Investors Service](/wiki/Moody%27s_Investors_Service "Moody's Investors Service")'s outlooks.[[296]](#cite_note-298) In the first quarter of financial year 2022–2023, the Indian economy grew by 13.5%.[[297]](#cite_note-299)

results.title: Timeline of the Indian Independence Movement - Britannica
results.content: After a century-long struggle for freedom, India and Pakistan won independence from British colonial rule at midnight on August 14–15, 1947. This moment marked a major turning point in world history, signaling the decline of Western colonialism. From the early revolt of 1857 to Gandhi’s nonviolent satyagraha campaigns, this timeline explores the saga and societal renaissance which was the Indian Independence Movement and its impact on the identities and destinies of millions.

After a century-long struggle for freedom, [India](https://www.britannica.com/place/India) and [Pakistan](https://www.britannica.com/place/Pakistan) won independence from British colonial rule at midnight on August 14–15, 1947. This moment marked a major turning point in [world history](https://www.britannica.com/topic/world-history), signaling the decline of [Western colonialism](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Western-colonialism). From the early [revolt of 1857](https://www.britannica.com/event/Indian-Rebellion-of-1857) to [Gandhi](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Mahatma-Gandhi)’s nonviolent [satyagraha](https://www.britannica.com/topic/satyagraha-philosophy) campaigns, this timeline explores the [saga](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/saga) and societal renaissance which was the [Indian Independence Movement](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Indian-Independence-Movement) and its impact on the identities and destinies of millions.

## ARTICLE

# India's Independence

# India's Independence

India’s independence from England was the result of many generations of resistance, culminating in a series of large-scale independence movements from 1919 to the early 1940s led by Mahatma Gandhi.

### Grades

###### Loading ...

In the 1600s, India was ruled by the Mughal empire, which had been in control for hundreds of years. India was made up of smaller city-statesand had established trade routesand a long history of art and culture. However, there were colonial powers like England, Portugal and the Netherlands that were taking control of pockets of land. Companies from those countries were using trade to gain power. One of the most prominent companies was the East India Companyfrom Britain, which at one time controlled half of the world’s trade. It recruited its own army and began seizing control of India region by region. Sometimes it took control through military force, such as through winning the Battle of Plassey in 1757. Other times it gained power through economic dominance.

For a time, the British government allowed the East India Company a lot of leveragein taking over regions in India because England was benefiting financially. However, when decades of unrestand resistance by Indians against the East India Company eventually resulted in Sepoy Mutinyof 1857, the British government dissolved the East India Company but kept control of its land. This is how Britain took over large portions of what is now modern-day India.

**The Sepoy Mutiny and the British Raj**

One of the first united actions that Indians took against British control was the Sepoy Mutiny. Indians were angered by the increasing pressure to convertto Christianity by the British, and they were also growing concerned about attempts to Westernizetheir country. When Hinduand Muslimsoldiers were seemingly forced to use guns and ammunitionwith animal products, which is against both religions, a rebellion was sparked. The fighting spread through northern and central India over the course of several months, uniting groups of Indians in a common cause. There was a lot of violence and death on both sides, and the conflict stretched on for more than a year. The rebellion ended on June 19, 1858 when the British recaptured a town called Gwalior and fighting ended. This victory marked the beginning of the British Raj(meaning “rule”) in India, but modern Indians note this mutiny was an early example of nationalisticaction taken by Indians.

Throughout the end of the 19th century and into the 20th, India generated large amounts of wealth for England, with people referring to it as “the jewel in the crown” because of its valuable natural resourcesand industry. Despite this, conditions for Indians under British rule grew worse and worse over the same time period. Povertyin India increased from about 23 percent to more than 50 percent from 1810 to the 1950s. The death rate increased, and the life expectancyof the average Indian was less than 22 years. Resistance to British rule rose due to these conditions, and Indians advocated for more representation and control over the local government. A British man named Allan Octavian Hume brought together a group of Indians to serve on the Indian National Congress in 1885. Hume purposely chose Indians that were Western-educated because he hoped that they would be more agreeable to British rule, culture, and politics. Despite being supportive of British rule at the beginning, the Indian National Congress would slowly become a nationalist entity, and later members would be strong supporters of an independentIndia. One of these leaders was Mahatma Gandhi.

**Gandhi and the Modern Indian Independence Movement**

Mahatma Gandhi was born in India and went to law school in England. He also worked as a lawyer in South Africa. He returned to India in 1915 as a strong supporter of Indian nationalism, and he joined the Indian National Congress to advocate for Indian self-rule. He used many forms of nonviolentresistance, also called passive resistance, to draw attention to the cause of self-rule and gain support. These methods included writing speeches and letters, leading marches, organizing protestsand demonstrations, boycotting British goods and institutions, leading prayer meetings, and more. In addition to bringing the people of India together behind the cause of an independent country, his protest methods inspired future civil rightsleaders around the world, including Martin Luther King Jr and Nelson Mandela.

The first major movement Gandhi led was in response to violence after the Rowlatt Act was passed in 1919. The Rowlatt Act took away many civil rights of Indian people. After the British began firing on a crowd at a peaceful protest against the act, Gandhi organized a large-scale protest campaign, the Non-Cooperation Movement, in response. As part of the campaign, he organized a boycottof cloth goods made in Britain and famously weaved his own cloth. The spinning wheel became a symbol of independent India.

Gandhi continued to lead major protestsinto the next decade, gathering more support from the Indian people. In 1930, the Indian National Congress declared independence from England, which was ignored by the British government. In response, Gandhi organized the Salt Satyagraha, in which Gandhi led followers on a long march to the sea and made his own salt from seawater in defiance of the law. This was a symbolicact protesting the British sale and control of salt, as well as commenting on India’s ability to provide for itself. Gandhi was arrested and thrown in jail in 1930 because of these actions, but jailing Gandhi did not put a stop to the protests. Sarojini Naidu, a famous female poet, led a non-violent takeover of the Dharasana Salt Works, a British-owned salt company, after Gandhi was arrested.

**India Achieves Independence**

During World War II, India’s industrywas growing while England was suffering losses from the war, and by the end, the British lacked resources to hold onto their colonies. They began losing power politically as well as economically. Indian leaders began setting up parallel governments, where, in certain areas, Indians had their own rulers and laws alongside the British ones. In 1942, Gandhi organized the Quit India Movement, a large push to get the British to agree to leave India. Many British officers and policemen responded to the protests of the Quit India Movement with violence. In response, Indians destroyed bridges and railroad tracks and sometimes reacted with physical fighting. Unlike previous situations where Gandhi chastised Indians for not using passive resistance, Gandhi did not condemn the non-peaceful actions of the protesters and instead blamed the British for having not given up control.

After World War II, several different factors came together at the same time for India to gain independence. Because of the war, Britain had depletedresources, and it seemed unlikely that it would be able to continue controlling India. In 1946, the Royal Navy in India went on strike due to poor working conditions and low pay. There was also violence and fighting between Hindus and Muslims, which further strained British control.

On August 15th, 1947, India became an independent country. Pakistan also became an independent country and cites its independence day as August 14th. At the time, leaders in the British, Hindu, and Muslim communities thought that if they divided British-controlled land into a Hindu-led country and a Muslim-led country, it would stop the violence. Though the partition of India and Pakistan led to violence between the two groups, independence was at last achieved after generations of resistance and advocacy by Indians.
